reviewText:
Is it good?
-YES

Is it good for everyone?
-NO... - depends!

Why?
...well it's a good mixture of:
- L4D game mechanics (4 players vs AI with those special enemies, swarming hordes, but no PVP)
- Chivalry: Medieval Warfare melee combat style with charged attacks, parry and dodge
- Kinda pure ranged combat is possible with mage class, limited ranged capabilities due to ammo with others (might change with good loot luck)

Features atm:
- Good graphics (GTX770, i5-4x4.2ghz, 16gig RAM here playing smoothly on high settings – and I know folks that run the game on a first gen i7-860 with a gtx460 on low but are able to play ok'ish)
- Responsive and smooth game engine if the hosting player is in the same region and has a decent connection (play with friends!)
- Nice and atmospheric maps so far
- Random map events you need to deal with keeping the same map re playable (as there where only 3 later 4 maps in beta)
- On the run adjustable difficulty (Grimoires to pick up or not - more loot but group debuffs)
-Team play is key – all loot improving items are shared at the end of the round no matter who carries them home!

Stuff to be aware before buying this game:
- The game play features getting permanently swarmed, little room to breathe or mistakes, it's hard survival after all even on normal difficulty. this is not a game to chill out and snipe some AI's off on a cake walk... no no no it is not!
- Playing the game public may be kinda frustrating due to some players still have no clue what to do at all, run off and get killed quickly so having friends playing the game is a big difference to difficulty and success in general. You should join/form a group/clan in the long run or just be fine with those random dudes in public games – it's not impossible to master higher difficulties in public games but it's less likely for sure in WH:Vermintide.
- 1st person melee combat may not be liked by everyone - but I was surprised how many of my friends who disliked the combat in Chivalry: Medieval Warfare now enjoy this game as it is PvE not PvP. A big difference!
- hard difficulty means HARD DIFFICULTY atm, epic and legendary loot tiers require high game difficulties to get any chance at all rolling them ... you need a team of capable FPS/Chivalry players to proceed to those nice and shiny loot things! (I hope it stays this way... good loot should always be a challenge to get not only a matter play time and pure grind)
- head bobbing" can't be turned off yet so ppl with motion/simulation sickness be aware of this (or avoid 2H-weapons to minimize the shaking effect)
- No color blind mode yet
- Just one master volume slider meaning loud music all the time or low game volume... I got used to it but meh
- No dedi servers yet (but promised)
- Once again: playing public games is not ideal as some ppl (as like in any game) may not care about team play that much or have (yet) no clue how to react to certain events - I recommend to play it with friends or to quickly make friends with good players along your runs to master that learning curve together! Individual player skill is one thing
date:
to form a successful permanent team needs time but it's very rewarding.
- The loot system is very very random atm. If you're unlucky you won't get a good item for your preferred class after days of game time.

State of game development:
-The game has still some flaws with stability that might need treatment by the user...
for e.g.: GTX680/GTX770 users might need to down clock their GPU by 40mhz with nvidiainspector.exe to avoid crashes (common problem in a lot of games these days...)
-The game does not feel finished and polished balance and hit box wise
recommended:
but it's playable - good luck finding another good COOP vs AI game those days so it's ok for me :)
- The game Devs seem to care and fix stuff kinda quickly - so that's promising for existing and future issues.


To sum it up:

This game is an awesome TEAM CHALLENGE!
L4D and L4D2 PvE are a cake walk compared to this.
Like it or not
hoursPlayed: you will first fail
voteText: then hopefully learn
helpfulPercent: group up
votesHelpful:
maybe give up (!) or succeed through higher tiers of swarming PvE COOP madness!


Or you don't care about good loot
votesTotal:
(get drunk) play it on easy with friends and have a good time for some hours - totally fine too ;)


===
*edit  2015-10-26th :
Situation in public games has slightly improved since more and more ppl are kinda experienced and the Devs set the in game VoIP to “ON” by default so others can at least hear you talk to them.
I'm still missing some tactical shout outs like in Killing Floor or Insurgency like “follow me!”
votesFunny:
take cover here!” (best with 3D marker) etc. to improve basic and quick communication.

The random special enemy spawns make any run on any difficulty very unpredictable as you might encounter a Rat Ogre plus a Scaven swarm plus 2-3 special enemies at once! I have to say I like this randomness because if you master that … that's just awesome!
On the other hand this means any run “only” on hard difficulty with 4 experienced mates in Teamspeak can end in a disastrous wipe – you never know!
However
commentsCount:
this is quite rare on lower difficulties so plz don't nerf this too hard... it keeps the same map tense like any small village you enter in DayZ - like you never know what's waiting for you around the next corner. A possible adrenalin rush and that feeling on a successful comeback - not many games aside from close competitive league games may trigger this on me:)

Some helpful links and tips for beginners to break that hard learning curve:
- Tome and Grimoire locations: http://www.vermintidedb.com/missions.php
- Tutorials on the official forums: http://forums.fatsharkgames.com/categories/tutorials
- New player advice on Reddit: https://www.reddit.com/r/Vermintide/comments/3oujwq/new_player_advice_thread_odoom/

If you start the game for the first time you should set your FOV to 90 and the “Player Outlines” to “always on” so you won't be hitting the dwarf and elf all the time like I did in the fist hours of game cause you may confuse them with Scavens … no offense ;)

Also I recommend to rebind “Target” from “T” to “F” or something as marking special enemies and equipment is very helpful and the T-key feels to be too far off as you should need it a lot. Also enable/bind push to talk for public games and you may increase the gamma by a good bid to see what's lurking in all those dark corners waiting to back stab you...

Many thanks for your nice replies guys – have fun slaying those rats!
==="

reviewText: One of my personal 'sleeper hits' of this year. Basically Left 4 Dead with classes, a loot system and fantastic melee combat. Very satisfying as I've been yearning for something to fill the void that Left 4 Dead left many years ago. It's a little rough around the edges at times (bugs, questionable design choices, glitches etc.) but for the majority of the time it's very good fun. Even more so on higher difficulties – Left 4 Dead became a cakewalk after several months even on 'Expert'/'Hardcore', while the highest difficulty ('Cataclysm') in Vermintide is seemingly impossible (which is a good thing)!\n\nI really, really, really hope they keep working on the game, because it's so much fun when it works! There's a lot of things to fix that are shying regular and new players away, but I believe if those things are fixed this game could very well be one of the most enjoyable co-op survival games in recent memory. Looking forward to seeing what happens in terms of new content too!

reviewText:
Do you like Left 4 Dead?
Do you like games which embrace action with RPG?
Do you like crafting and upgrading your weapons?
Do you like killing endless waves of enemies which react responsively to each hit?
Do you like random events which makes every match unique?
Do you like playing with dumb teammates that often get you killed and then tell you to go f*ck yourself?
Do you like Victorian architecture, which seems very similar to Bloodborne?
Do you like a game that doesn't hold your hand?
Do you like dice?
Do you like getting rewards at the end of each round?

If you answered the first question as a ''yes'', don't worry about the others. Just get your wallet and buy the damn game!

9/10

reviewText:
Left 4 Dead meets Warhammer: Online meets a quick start RPG.

PROS
-good set of loot drops for each class (rolls based on performance in each mission)
-each class has at least 2-3 different style of play to them with both close quarters to ranged.
-Skaven AI is very, very good. Even on easy.
-Visceral, first person combat.
-Amazingly fun.
-difficulty curve is just right.
-light crafting mechanic

CONS
-hitboxes can feel a bit weird at times, meaning you sometimes miss shots you expect to hit and vice versa.
-small bugs exist but are rapidly addressed by the developers (so this is more of a neutral item)
-Only 5 classes at launch (although see above about differing playstyles for each class).

Do I recommend this game? Yes. If you love Warhammer and you liked/enjoyed games like L4D, pick this title up. Even if you don't know a thing about Warhammer, it's still a fun title.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying that I am not the biggest fan of Left for Dead style games nor the actual L4D series itself.

That said, I can whole heartedly recommend this game to anybody who likes team oriented hack and slash gameplay.  Why?  Well, keep on reading.


Pros:
Fun, addictive gameplay.  Doubly so if you have friends.
Tough difficulty, rarely holds your hand
Gorey, visceral feeling combat
Great SFX
Good GFX, really portrays the doom and gloom feeling of Warhammer
Loot based system keeps you playing
Randomly spawning enemies keeps things fresh
All 5 characters have unique playstyles

Cons:
Difficulty(yes, both a pro and a con) If you try to bite off more than you chew too often, soon you'll find yourself 3 or 4 games without a victory or any loot
Very little reward for failure
Hit boxes are a bit strange, sometimes you will hit when you don't expect to or miss when you expect to contact
Frustrating pick up groups.  It sucks to jump into hard mode with a guy who is level 3 and will probably die at any moment.


This is a game that you want to get your friends into and play with people you can depend on.  Sticking with randoms can work too but it can also be very frustrating. It borrows many elements from the L4D series and if you are even slightly familiar with those games you will instantly recognize them, but this turns out to flow well in it's own way, succeeding to differentiate itself nicely from the L4D style.


Overall, buy this game if you enjoy simple, gorey team-oriented action with a dash of RP elements.

Or if you hate rats.  A lot.

reviewText:
WHAT THIS GAME IS:
Left 4 Warhammer.
A hectic fast paced hack and slash action game intended to be played co-op with friends. You play one of five characters each with slightly different play styles and each with a variety of possible weapon choices unique to them. You play through missions with simple objectives and recurring crescendo events against a horde of rat men, finding supplies on the way. You get a random piece of loot after each mission. Weapons can be upgraded/broken down/crafted with the Shrine and Anvil in the inn lobby.

WHAT THIS GAME IS NOT:
A deep RPG with lots of choices and builds with narrative and story.


I recommend playing with friends and I recommend not playing on difficulties higher than your item level. The experience is severely diminished by the crap AI bots. However, if you do try to play solo, I've compiled some useful information that may help.

TIPS FOR PLAYING SOLO:
-AI partners are awful in many ways. Be prepared for frustrating deaths for stupid reasons.
-Get good with Sienna, Victor, and Markus. If you play as Sienna or Victor, you will get Kerillian Bot, Bardin Bot, and Markus Bot. If you play as Markus, you'll get Kerillian Bot, Bardin Bot, and Sienna Bot. There is no Victor Bot. Kerillian Bot is by far the best, Bardin Bot is decent, Markus Bot is mediocre, and Sienna is wholly terrible in all ways.
-AI Bots have whatever weapons and equipment the host player has them equipped with. Recommendations from my experience: Bardin, axe and shield plus handgun or crossbow. Kerillian, dual daggers or sword and dagger plus swift bow or hagbane bow. Markus, great hammer or sword and shield, plus handgun. Sienna, bolt staff with longsword or flaming sword.
-Bots get regularely trounced by big armored enemies. This can be helped significantly if their weapons have the Devastating Blow perk.
-The AI will religiously persue ratling gunners and ignore everything else, including you and the gutter running stabbing your face, and the rats who are attacking them while they take cover. I recommend a handgun, crossbow, bolt or beam staff, or other such high power long ranged weapon so you can quickly deal with gunners yourself.
-Rat ogres will probably kill you, as the AI is bad at dealing with them. Keep a strength potion and a black powder bomb on hand. Strength potions double damage of bombs as well as your weapons, so take the potion and then throw the bomb at the ogre if you want to stand a chance. Victor's double pistols, Kerillians Hagbane bow, and Sienna's beam staff are very good at killing rat ogres.
-AI will only pick up healing items if you already have one. They won't pick up bombs or potions ever. The AI will pick up tomes, but only if no healing items are available and if you are already carrying a tome or healing item.
-Friendly Fire is active on Nightmare and Cataclysm difficulty only, and only applies to ranged weapons and bombs. Don't worry about friendly fire from the AI; they barely ever use their ranged weapons, and when they do they can generally be trusted to be accurate. The AI however does not take into account when you are using your ranged weapon. If you play as Victor or Sienna, be prepared to shoot your AI partners fairly often as they like to stand behind you when idle and then run through you when an enemy approaches. Try to use slightly higher ground when available, like standing on boxes or stairs.
-The AI does gain benefits from trinkets. Trinket recommendations: reduced damage from poison gas, faster revival, healing all allies when healing self, healing self when healing an ally. Do not equip bots with the luckstone; this only affects you when you open a chest, and bots will never open chests.
-The AI is extremely bad at avoiding Stormvermin Patrols. If you hear one, run very very far away and hide in a corner until they pass.
-Man the Ramparts has no Stormvermin Patrols, nor a rat ogre. Good map for grinding.
-The AI does not do a good job of keeping up with you if there are any rats about. Move slowly and methodically clear locations before proceeding so you don't accidentally leave their stupid asses behind.
-Ignore Sack Rats if they are already running away. Be an ambush predator if you want to kill them. If you can, snipe them in the head with a handgun, but if you miss, don't chase them; the AI won't be able to keep up with you.

reviewText:
Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide is a co-operative first person action game developed and published by Fatshark studio. The game is best described as Left 4 Dead set in the Warhammer fantasy universe with a much heavier emphasis on melee combat, with a few extra bells whistles added to the mix.

The core mechanics are solid and robust, and the weapons feel enjoyable and satisfying. You can really feel the weight of the two handed hammer and the damage it causes when you pulverize a Stormvermin with a charged attack. Do not worry if you’re not a fan of bulky, blunt weapons however, as the game features five heroes on launch, each with unique playstyles and specialized equipment to aid them in combat. For example, the Waywatcher, Kerillian, uses her bow to pick off unaware targets from afar but can also get up close and overwhelm her enemies with her signature twin Elven daggers. On the other hand, Sienna Fuegonasus, the Bright Wizard, would rather use her staff to rain fiery death upon her foes, decimating the Skaven rank one fireball at a time, so no matter what your combat style is, there is a hero build for everyone.

The loot system for many players would be the primary motivation to keep on playing the game. Every time you emerge victories, you’re given a chance to roll for a new piece of equipment, completing side objectives such as securing tombs, the infamous grimoires as well as winning on higher difficulties will give you a better chance at securing a rarer loot. Rarer equipment comes with better stats as well as additional passive traits which in turn will give you the much needed edge on the blood soaked battlefield.

With a diverse hero selections also comes a good selection of enemy types, Stormvermins acts as the shock troops of the Skaven army, soaking up damage with their heavy armour and dishing out punishment with their long reaching halberds, while the Poison Wind Globadiers lobs poisonous globes to deny key chock-points and areas. At the while Gutter Runners and Packmasters tries to pick off vulnerable party members under the cover of Ratling Gunner’s unrelenting gunfire, and if all else fails, the Rat Ogre will be called upon the battlefield, a formidable enemy that can devastate all but the most organized teams. When it all comes together, the combat is hectic, bloody and extremely rewarding.

Having said that, Warhammer: End Times – Vermintide in and of itself is quite a repetitive game, you can finish all the thirteen missions that were offered on launch within eight hours or so, and thus relies on players to replay missions to acquire better loots in order to tackle the same missions on higher difficulties. Some would find this tedious and uninteresting, which is perfectly understandable, but for the others, this can be compelling and satisfying, you’ll have to ask yourself if you enjoy this type of gameplay.

To conclude, Warhammer: End Times – Vermintide is a mechanically sound game with excellent combat and challenging game-play, and best played with a group of friends as teamwork is the key to success. The random loot drop system will keep players entertained should they don’t mind replaying the same missions over and over again for progression. That, and the competitive launch price of $29.99 USD or your regional equivalent, makes this title worth checking out.

reviewText:
A very co-op intensive game that never lets up in terms of action and combat. It is most enjoyable when played with friends while communicating on voice chat.

Vermintide has a heavy emphasis on melee combat with ranged weapons being more reserved for sniping and situational combat scenarios. So be prepared to hack and slash your way through hordes of rat monsters most of the time.

The gameplay mechanics are very well-balanced and have been refined to play smoothly. There are a number of quirks regarding the range of the special rats, notably the Packmaster, but I suspect these issues will be fixed over time by the game developers.

Overall, difficulty-wise, when I first started Vermintide, I thought that the hardest difficulty level: Cataclysm was undoable. However, once I fully understood the game's combat mechanics, rhythm and tactics & strategies, I realised that this game simply requires combat skill, timing, positional awareness and a good communicative team to complete it on any given map and difficulty setting.

Now, having completed the game and cleared everything, I await to see what new content Vermintide will receive with its upcoming patches and DLCs.

reviewText:
Regardless of what others have said about sticking with good friends in Vermintide, I think the best gameplay are those in which you pull out an A team by random lot.
On a recent set of rounds I played, at the time of this post, I was not kicked out from the team for being a low level (below level 20) for hard difficulty. I don't even know if there really is an option such as that (the kicking), that may stem from me never needing to try to kick someone out from the team.
As for the teamplay with random people, while searching around during a calm phase of a map, my random partner and I stumbled on a health kit. We both suffered a certain degree of injuries in which a health kit would be advised. We had a few seconds of staring at one another to decide who gets to heal themself. My partner took the kit, but then healed me.  After that one moment of kindness, I stuck with that person regardless of how suicidal things got (such as frontal charges at a ratling gunner). Needless to say we failed a few games due to such recklessness, but we failed with humor.
Coordination with a random team is usually based on intiative. There are occasions in which the entire team hesitates. But once someone takes a step, everyone, in most experiences, jumps right into the hot mess and throws anything they haven't thrown yet at the ratling onslaught.
Compared to when I play with friends, where the tendancy for horse play is large. I do feel like that there is a degree of purpose in this since teamworks mean better everything in the game. I am happy to say that I have not yet, luckily, had a good game screwed over because of the purposeful action of a team member.

reviewText:
Vermintide is an incredibly fun co-op game that shares a lot of similarities with Left 4 Dead
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N-kaMjdgC-M
The fighting mechanics feel very meaty and satisfying. Rats that you kill will topple over eachother, and throw guts everywhere. You can go decently in-depth with push attacks, blocks and charged attacks.
The game forces you to stick with your team, due to the fact that there are special rats that can pin you down. You can't do anything to help yourself, and must rely on teammates to free you. There's a good variety when it comes to these special enemies. One that pulls you away and requires your teammates to run after you to help, another that throws poisonous gas that can separate the team, one that has a gattling gun, and one gigantic rat that will require everyone's efforts.

The game is actually very hard, which is a refreshing change from most games nowadays. Luckily everyone I've run into so far has been very friendly and willing to co-operate.

The maps have decent variety, and many times allow you to interact with the world by exploring secret rooms that could contain loot that might help you in the level, like speed up or healing potions. You can also things like Tomes or a Loot die, which will give you better loot at the end of a level.

Speaking of loot, there's a lot you can gather for each class. If you don't like the stats of some of your equipment, you can salvage it with other loot of the same rarity for something new.

All classes that you can choose from play quite differently, and allow for some strategic play. One character can pierce through armor with normal attacks, where as others would have to do charged attacks. One character can shoot fireballs at far away enemies and hurt a wide area. I personally find them all fun to play, and find myself cycling through them.

The game does a good job at sucking you into its world. It's very immersive due to the beautiful graphics, well realized environment and natural dialogue. Characters will have funny banter, or communicate to one another about a specific found item, or area they have stepped into. It's really well done.

Overall, I really enjoyed this game. It's very well polished, takes a lot of fun elements from other games, and improves upon them. Check it out!

reviewText:
In Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide, you play as one of the five unique heroes and work together with up to three other players in a fictional town named Ubersreik to save the town by doing various missions while killing every Skaven (rat-men) that gets in the way.

While showing many similarities to Left 4 Dead series, Vermintide differs in the sense that it puts a lot of emphasis on melee combat, kind of like Chivalry. Ranged combat is possible but there are a lot of restrictions, mainly the limited amount of ammunition you get.

Pros
* Character interactions with each other showcases their unique personalities nicely, rather than just five generic characters that looks different
* Having many ways (decapitation, caving heads, explosives, etc) to kill rats is satisfying
* Collecting books and grimoires adds challenge regardless of difficulty, and can improve loot quality
* Levelling also rewards you with loot, so your progression isn't halted should you find yourself not winning often.
* Different characters having different playstyles adds variety and replayability
* Rat Ogres make L4D Tanks look like babies

Cons
* Cannot sprint - You will have to rely on your own dodging and parrying skills if there are no one to cover you
* Optimisations need improvement - CPU/graphic card usage remains high even for high-spec computers
* Matchmaking is 'First come, first serve' rather than lobby browsing (You deal with the same people for a particular map until slot is filled, forcing you to play different map or host your own lobby).
* Weapon balancing needs work, some weapons are underpowered making them undesirable
* No shared equipment besides trinkets (already somewhat rare itself depending on luck)
* Rewards don't fully justify difficulty - Common weapon is possible reward for nightmare/cataclysm difficulty
* Unpredictable spawns can feel rather punishing at times even on easier difficulties
* Bot intelligence makes solo play rather unfun
* Curse those near unstoppable, physics defying Zeratul rats- Oh sorry wrong game, I meant Gutter Runners

Despite these flaws, Vermintide is still very promising as the development is very active, and you can expect a lot of these issues to be resolved in the upcoming updates.
voteText: 88 of 107 people (82%) found this review helpful 11 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Set within the Warhammer lore, Vermintide is a four player co-op survival game based in the fictional city of Ubersreik. Under attack from endless hoards of vermin known as the Skaven, four unlikely heroes must use teamwork to stand a chance against overwhelming numbers.

When starting the game for the first time, players will first notice the lack of any tutorial or practice arena as they find themselves thrown into a tavern which operates as the mission hub. Players can select missions from the tavern which will then find them a game or allow them to host it themselves. This Is where I met my first problem within Vermintide, confused and with no information I found myself unable to find any games. After checking the forums I found that servers had been disabled for maintenance. After maintenance I joined my first game and soon found that games were managed with a peer to peer system. It seems unusual that matchmaking must be taken down and all games must come to a halt when the game lacks the use of dedicated servers. Many games that run with a peer to peer system can find games without needing a matchmaking server. After finally getting into my first game I immediately got to the fast paced hack and slash I had been waiting for.

Combat within Vermintide can be described as “simple yet satisfying” as it lacks depth but still provides a gratifying experience. Weapons operate with a simple system which takes into account damage, reach, knockback and speed. With a total of five characters, each character having their own selection of weapons there is plenty of variety to find the weapons to suit your playstyle, be it defensive, one hit wonder or crowd control. Shields are great for players who want to defend their friends and keep the tide of vermin back. Two handed swords to slice huge groups into a pink paste that leave you somewhat slow. Fast daggers with little reach for devastating damage against a single target one at a time. With each character having their own arsenal with its own variety you can play as any character you want, however you want to play. If the loot system lets you. Each weapon has the option for a quick and heavy attack, the differences between the two attacks depend on the weapon used. Players looking for heavy depth won't find it here but those looking for a tactical hack and slash will find it satisfying for many hours. While combat is basic there is a simple learning curve which is heavily focused on movement management to avoid taking damage. There isn't really too much to say, simple but effective and sometimes simplicity can be much more satisfying then complexity.

Teamwork is a heavy focus of the game, as four players will be the victim to a number of special enemies that excel at killing anyone who strays alone. The Packmaster carries a hook which can pull players away from the group amidst the chaos of a hoard, reminds me a little of the smoker from Left 4 Dead. The Globadier prays on campers by covering large area of the map in a toxic cloud. After taking enough damage he'll suicide and explode into the group, heh that reminds me of the boomer from Left 4 Dead. The Runner rat pounces around the map and once it catches a player it will leave them helpless as it claws away. Okay I hope I am not the only one starting to see a pattern here. The biggest and final special enemy is known as the rat ogre, a huge mass of muscles that flings players around the map. Considered the boss of each map they take teamwork to take down with the heaviest of fire-power. Yep.. it's a tank, it looks almost identical with similar sound effects complimenting it. This game is Left 4 Dead and it's not subtle about it in any stretch of the imagination. Four players fighting through mindless hoards of enemies as they progress through the map, looking out for special enemies that are specialized at killing anyone who wanders off alone. Yes, this is Left 4 Dead with rats and we'll come back to this! Disregarding the extreme similarities these enemies still work well, forcing the team to quickly change tactics to adapt to new threats.

When looking at the characters, elf caught my eye and was immediately my first choice. After completing my first mission I was rewarding with two new weapons, a mace and a magic staff. I scratched my head a little as I soon realized neither of these were for the character I actually wanted to play. This brings with one of the greatest and most frustrating issues with Vermintide, the loot drop system. After each mission players roll six dice in an attempt to get better loot. Unfortunately the loot selection is completely randomized leaving even a perfect roll with frustration as you get another item not for your character. Currently after playing roughly 30 hours as elf I own 3 exotic staffs for the mage but have yet to find a single bow for the elf I enjoy using. It can destroy the motivation to play as you feel unable to play as the character you enjoy most. Better gear for other characters constantly piling up, never to be used if its for a character you don't enjoy playing. This issue desperately needs attention and can be a real killer for the game for those looking to invest a lot of hours. While the game offers players a number of ways to play, if you simply don't find the gear you need to play that way it can only harm your motivation to play.

A number of other issues I also experienced was poor optimisation and numerous bugs. At periods of gameplay my framerate would remain consistent but the game would slow down as well as separate occasions of high frame rate dropping. While these issues were minor I soon found myself with a long list of little things that irritated me as I played.

Lets get back to the elephant in the room, this game showing extreme similarity to Valves Left 4 Dead games. With many enemies having identical roles and combat being almost identical in many aspects  its clear that heavy inspiration was taken from Left 4 dead. Is this a bad thing? No, not on its own. In gaming many games have taken inspiration from earlier titles and improved upon them, I don't feel there is anything wrong with it as long as it finds its own place within the market. This leads us to the question, does Vermintide have enough originality to give it its own identity? If you already owned Left 4 Dead, would it be worth buying? My answer would be yes, but only just. While its clear that both games are extremely similar, a focus on melle combat over guns and medieval setting does give it enough to become its own branch in the co-op survival genre. Though you can complain all you want, I'm still going to call the rat ogre a tank every time! Old habits die hard.

Putting the similarities between Vermintide and Left 4 Dead to the side, lets look at Vermintide on its own merits. This is one of my reviews where I read through it and feel I didn't give enough praise. A number of bugs and issues throughout the game can be frustrating however with everything said the core concept is an entertaining and challenging hack and slash. Great weapon variety leave open a number of playstyles that all have their own role within a team. Defensive or aggressive there will be a weapon set that fits you perfectly, with that said Vermintide needs a lot of polish to smooth its rough edges. Will the developers give this title the polish it desperately needs to be something sensational? We'll have to wait and see.

If you're looking for something to play with your friends it's definitely worth looking at and a sure buy if you see it on sale! At full price, be cautious and aware of the game's faults before you spend your cash but many people will be satisfied with their purchase. If the game gets continuous support from its developer and improve some of the major issues, i'd happy suggest it to anyone who enjoys cooperative gameplay.

reviewText:
https://youtu.be/c1rqroGvTd4

Once in a while the task of putting together a video review for a title is such a pain… mostly because you have to stop playing the game you’re really enjoying. I love Vermintide. This game came out of nowhere and has just truly impressed me.

Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide was developed by Fatshark, best known for Lead and Gold, War of the Roses, and Krater. Without a doubt, this is their finest product yet and one of my favorite games this year.

Vermintide shares a ton of similarities to Left 4 Dead (a formula I’m a little surprised hasn’t been emulated much). It’s a four player cooperative experience where you and a your team need to get from point A to B while fending off hordes of monsters. This time (thankfully), it’s not roaming herds of zombies. It’s giant rat men.

There are a total of five characters to choose from, each representing their own distinct class. The Dwarf Ranger and the Empire Soldier are primarily built as tank classes. The Elven Waywatcher and the Bright Wizard deal out heavy damage from from away. And the Witch Hunter falls somewhere in the middle, he can play as a ranged class or as a primarily melee class. But since it’s Warhammer, everyone carries ranged weapons to compliment their melee weapons. The game finds a great balance between the two styles of fighting for every character and the best players will know and when is ideal to quickly switch between the two

As you finish maps, you roll the dice to get new gear, and every piece of gear can drastically change how each character plays. There are opportunities to obtain more dice in each map to increase your chances of getting better loot. A sword and shield will play much differently than a two handed hammer or a one handed mace. There are a variety of bows with a range of special effects. The Bright Wizard can go from crowd control to dealing pure pain. And special weapons have traits that can be unlocked through the games simple crafting system. Increased range, reduced stamina cost, health vamping, and more. The higher level you are, you are likely to come across and develop more and more complex loot that will help in the brutally tough levels of the game. The loot in this game is what will keep players coming back for more.

But the loot isn’t the only draw. The world and map design is stunning. It’s just beautiful. The game doesn’t hold your hand either (thankfully). Finding your way to the end of a new map is a big part of the fun. The maps are all unique to one another, ranging from creepy graveyard ruins, to the outdoors, to vacated city streets, to a twisted MC Escher-esque wizard tower. The world feels like it was once lived in, but abandoned because of the catastrophe.

There’s a good number of maps, but also a great challenge to go along with them. Each map can be set either as easy, normal, hard, nightmare and cataclysm.

Most importantly, it’s fun. The realm of video games is in staggeringly short supply of enjoyable and challenging cooperative experiences. And though this is is heavily inspired by Left 4 Dead, in many ways it exceeds it.

There are a few elements that irk me a little. A couple maps, particularly the ones where you have to gather scattered supplies and bring them back to a central location, feel imbalanced to me. Even set on normal difficulty, these maps can quickly wipe a moderately experienced team.

Twice in my twenty hours of playing the game, I’ve had servers reset… or something. All of the players will stay in the game, but the map would restart and we’d all be playing as a different character than the one we selected. Really weird.

When playing with 2 people or more, the NPC bots do a great job of holding their own. Unfortunately, I found when playing solo, they tend to do some really stupid things, like getting stuck in the environment… or jumping off of buildings… and then the rest will jump off of buildings to save their buddies. I hope they get a little patch.

And finally, the game does NOT feature any competitive multiplayer like Left 4 Dead. I personally never enjoyed the competitive play in Left 4 Dead, but I know that might be a dealbreaker for some.

I’ve had a few different friends ask me about the game, if you only fight against rodents of unusual size. Yes, giant rats of various shapes and classes are the only enemy. If that sours the experience for some, I have to say the action and excitement far outweigh any minor issues I had with the game’s choice of enemies.

The developers have made promises for some DLC for the game and NO microtransactions. With a universe as rich as the Warhammer series, I’m hoping to see some greenskins, or maybe even some space marines action.

If you’re a PC owner, Vermintide is a must-own, especially at its budget price of $30. It’s just pure fun, cooperative arcade action set in a wonderful world.

reviewText:
In short: Wait and see how it is after release unless you're willing to endure crashes, bugs and poor performance.

The game is actually great, not very innovative, but what it does it does very well.

Did you like Left4dead2? Then you'll most likely like this game. This game borrows a lot from L4D2, so i will be comparing the two. It's the same basic formula, 4 people cooperatively advance through a semi-open map trying to achieve an objective, encountering enemies along the way. Some enemies appear randomly at random times, so you don't always know what to expect. There are several different enemy types to spice things up.

What is does different from L4D2 is classes and melee, melee is the focus of the game. All classes have ranged and melee attacks, although your ranged attacks are limited by ammo or energy, which you can resupply by exploring the enviroment to find supplies. The melee feels heavy and responsive, it's also diversive and most importantly, fun.

Classes could be more specialized and diverse in my opinion, but they still all offer enough to make them unique. They are customizable as well, so you can actually attempt to specialize them to your liking.

The loot system is a hit and miss, depending on who you ask. It's random, and the only thing you can semi-control is how good your odds are. I'm not the biggest fan of that, but i can't argue with the gambling feeling of rolling the dice. You also get no loot if you fail the level, so you can spend 20-30 minutes only to loose in the final fight and get nothing but XP, or as in my case, the game crashing or losing connections, or the host leaving, which is a poor design, let someone else take over the host. So, it's subjective, i guess, you be the judge.

However, it's buggy, very buggy. I have a 50/50 chance of the game crashing when i play. I seem to encounter the same bug over and over, that is the game crashing when i fire a weapon. There are also other less severe yet still annoying bugs. The game runs decent, but not nearly good enough to be acceptable.
Mind you, the game is to release in 4 days, and i honestly don't see how they can fix all the issues before that. So i'd advice you to wait and see after release.

All in all, huge potential, great core features, fun gameplay and well crafted from the ground up. But yet again, unstable at the moment.
I give it a thumbs up despite the problems solely because it's still in Beta, problems like this at launch (or soon after) are unacceptable and i will change the review to a thumbs down if they're not properly handled.

Edit: Since this is getting some views which didn't expect, i cleaned up the grammar a bit and clarified a few points for easier reading. I did not change anything significant that could affect the conclusion of the review.

reviewText:
I played through the first level of Vermintide with a random group as the Dwarf Hero on the free weekend of May 27th.

It was the most Dwarvish experience I could have hoped for.

A horde of ratmen threatened to swarm myself and my taller companions, who had become wounded in the ceaseless fighting. The grotesque creatures chittered dementedly, their eyes were full of a gleeful malice. The believed us to be near our ends. They underestimated the stoutness of Dwarves.

I strode to meet the ragged and filthy monsters, shield raised, axe in hand. Filling the doorway, I let them come like the wave they were, and they broke over me like a storm whipped wave upon a mighty and craggy shore.

My axe swung, feeling heavy and powerful, into the arms, torsos and repulsive faces of the gibbering and crazed enemy. My shield caught them in their furred guts, sending them tail over snout, sprawling back into their filth ridden kin. I stymied the spears and daggers of those which scrambled over their winded cousins. The flood of ratmen was greeted with an unstoppable tide of dwarvish making, sharp as you please.  My axe raised and fell, raised and fell, over and over. The ratmen squealed. The ratmen shrieked. The ratmen fought. And the ratmen died.

I had held the line.

Tl;dr: You want to feel like a proper Dawi? Here you go.

reviewText:
Warhammer themed co-op game with many similarities to Left 4 Dead (which I never really could get into).

I don't know if it's the more interesting theme, the more detailed evironments, ai oppoinents that seem to have a bit of a personality, the loot system, character progression or the focus on melee combat... but i'm really enjoying this 25 hours in and expect to play a lot more of it.

It has a few rough edges, but nothing to stop me from recommending this if you have the inclination and the $$$

reviewText:
Developer: Fatshark
Publisher: Fatshark
Release Date: October 23th, 2015

Note:Check the website for an extended view into the lore and playstyle of the different heroes and more information about the different type of Skaven[www.vermintide.com]

A boomer! … I mean … A Rat Ogre!
Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide feels like L4D and reminds one of such but it’s not just a copy it’s actually quite a good game.
I’ve been in love with Warhammer Online: Age of Reckoning so I’m more than happy that such a game is now here on Steam.
I really miss it …

No time to cry we have to fight some Skaven!

StoryTaken straight from the store page:

Vermintide takes place in and around Ubersreik, a city overrun by Skaven. You will assume the role of one of five heroes, each featuring different play-styles, abilities, gear and personality. Working cooperatively, you must use their individual attributes to survive an apocalyptic invasion from the hordes of relentless rat-men, known as the Skaven. Battles will take place across a range of environments stretching from the top of the Magnus Tower to the bowels of the Under Empire.

So there’s that.

GameplayIf you’ve played Left 4 Dead then you’re more than prepared for this game.
Or to be honest you aren’t. Warhammer: End Times- Vermintide requires a fair amount of teamwork and to be completely honest I feel like it’s even more important than in L4D.

You can choose between five heroes.
First up is Viktor Saltzpyre, a Witch Hunter[www.vermintide.com]. Next up we have Kerrilian, a Waywatcher[www.vermintide.com].
Easy to oversee is Bardin Goreksson, a Dwarf Ranger[www.vermintide.com]. Heating things up, literally, isSienna Fuegonasus[www.vermintide.com], a Bright Wizard. Last but not least have Markus Kruber, a Empire Soldier[www.vermintide.com].
Fans of the Warhammer Universe need no introduction to the heroes or rather classes and for everyone else I linked to the website for further information on the furious five and I highly recommend to check it out.
I mean if I would start talking now about Sienna and Bright Wizards in general let’s just say it would take up the whole review.
What I can say about the heroes is though that they’re all truly unique. Not only in appearance but also in the way you play them.

Let’s give a quick look into the equipment of the heroes so you do have an idea on what you can expect their playstyle to be.
Actually let’s not do that. Again it would take up the whole review.
Please for the sake of the game and yourself visit the website to get a good look into each of the characters.

So let’s just say they’re all different.
Most unique one is by far the Bright Wizard.
Spamming your magic will build up too much heat and ultimately turn your friends, the flames of course, against you. You’ll notice a bar’s building up whenever you cast a spell which slowly decays if you’re not using any magic. If you do have to use magic however you can vent. What that means is that you can get rid of excess heat in form of smoke. Venting will damage you however but sometimes it’s the only thing you can do if you find yourself surrounded by a horde of Skaven.
Depending on your staff you’re able to use different kinds of spells like the fireball, a signature move, or the CONFLAGRATION OF DOOM, marking an area on the ground ot create a pillar of fire which will ignite enemies within. And yes I had to put that one in caps because of it’s bad ♥♥♥ name! Don’t judge!

The game features different levels, with different objectives but it’s always the same.
Get in, ♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ up, and get the hell out of there!
You can choose the difficulty level of each mission and to be fair I find normal to be too easy while hard gives you really a good challenge.

You’ll find potions, which will gives you a short bonus so strength for example, bombs, tomes, which will give you bonus experience at the end of the game and many more things that you can use and abuse to make your way through the levels.

At the end of the mission you’ll get experience points based on your score.
You’ll unlock new traits and equipment that way.

The game features a forge which you can use to either upgrade your favorite weapon or let’s you fuse five items of the same rarity to forge a new one.

You see the game’s quite a bit grindy but that’s actually quite enjoyable because the nightmare difficulty will make you hate your life and fear the Skaven and Rats in general!

VisualsThe game looks absolutely gorgeous.
I’ve seldom seen a game that blows me away even at the lowest graphic settings but Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide manages just to do that.
The blood, shadows, light … everything looks just so good. Especially the Skaven. Fatshark has really pulled it off!
Another sweet note is that you should pay attention to the behavior of the Skavens. For example I was heartbroken to see a Skaven shiver in pain when he see Markus and Kerrilan walking towards him. He pressed himself against the wall and looked left and right for a way to escape.
I’m not joking. They will and do behave just like that .. just incredible.
It really breaks my heart to see such behavior since I’d love to play as a Skaven but … it’s just so good.
Seriously it’s a magnificent looking game!

AudioThe game sounds incredibly good. I guess that’s a no brainer considering that Jesper Kyd[www.jesperkyd.com] made the sountrack for the game. The Kyd is responsible for the OST of Borderlands, Darksiders II, Assassin’s Creed, Hitman and many many more. Considering that this isn’t your first so called vidya game it’s safe to say that you’ve been blown away by the Kyd’s music more than once.
It’s fitting, it’s a promise of danger, it suits the Skaven theme and … what is there to say?
The Kyd’s created another master piece … ‘Nuff said.
I mean my favorite track by far is The Skaven Come Out To Play. It’s a short track but … god damn it just listen to it!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IfsZhYiCNfA

SkavenThere’s a huge variety of Skaven, please don’t call them rats … have some respect will ya?, in the game is just fantastic.

One just has to love the Skaven. I might be biased because the Skaven are by far my favorite Race from the Warhammer Universe and it’s just awesome to see them getting their own game … Well yeah it’s a bit ♥♥♥♥♥♥ that they get destroyed the whole day but hey … one has to start somewhere amirite?
For example you have the Pack Master. Players refer to him as the Hook Rat … kids these days have no respect. Anyway he’s one pesky lil’ bugger!
If you don’t pay attention you’ll find yourself or one of your teammates choking to death and dangling from his polearm.
Let’s not forget the Rat Ogre. He’s, as the name implies, not as little as his brethren and one could go as far as to say that he’s the Hulk of the Skaven. Seriously he’s going to ♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ up!

There’re a lot more such as simple clanrats, cannon fodder basically, and personally I hope they’re going to implement new types of Skaven in the future.

What else can I say?Buy it. I mean it probably will be an insta buy for Warhammer fans, just like me, but you should really consider it.
It’s a welcome addition to the warhammer games and so far it’s excellent I can only recommend it I mean … Skaven! That’s reason enough to buy the game!

reviewText:
Hmm... What to say about this game...

Like Warhammer?
Like Left 4 Dead?

Like 4 player co-op?
Have friends to play with?

Like PvE?
Hate rats?

If you answered yes to any pair of these, you'll probably enjoy this.

These pairings pretty much sum the game and gameplay experience up.

1. Vermintide is pretty much Games Workshop's Warhammer spin on Left 4 Dead.
Everything from the hordes, through to the Specials. With an End Times twist.
The only real difference being a Class base to your heroes. Each with a specified weapon set (no weapon swaps/pick ups), which you can edit at the beginning of each map, if you don't do so at the Tavern (lobby) between missions.
Also, ammo is somewhat scarce, so the combat is predominantly melee based.

2. The game is a 4 player co-op, with 5 playable characters.
Each has his own pros and cons, gameplay-wise.
When playing with less than 4 players (full lobby), AI bots will fill the role of your teammate(s).
Unlike other 4 player co-ops, teamwork is a lot more vital to mission success. Not only when dealing with the Skaven in numbers, but also completing objectives.
You can play solo (with AI assist" - I used that term loosely)

reviewText:
Edit 13 March 2016:

I've taken a two month hiatus that started back in January, and the game still has a multitude of bugs.

1. Still present even past beta, you can randomly fall over and die. It seems that you can also randomly take fall damage for no apparent reason now. The frequency of such occurrences has increased  judging from the multitude of reports on this bug.

2. The framerate seems to have taken a noticeable hit, I am now averaging 30 fps on horde heavy sections which is a heavy detriment to combat.

3. The game can crash and freeze randomly, with very severe aftereffects. You can play an endurance round up to a very high number of rounds, but if the host's computer decides to crash or you randomly disconnect, then you (and other players in the lobby) will immediately restart the entire game with no compensation.

4. If you die, you can possibly spawn behind your team, meaning that you spawned before a no-return point that your team has already passed.

I know that my plea falls on some deaf ears, but my hope is that the developers make fixing these issues a top priority. For players who are looking to buy this game, the positive reviews you read are mostly true. They simply do not mention the various issues that you will come to be familiar with once you play for more than 40 hours or when you visit the forums. Consider these issues before you press the Add to Cart" button.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I like this game for its combat and lore.

However I can't wholly recommend a title like this with the bugs it currently has.

1. Rats really love to hit you through everything in this game.

reviewText:
Gore drenched, chaotic co-op jaunt through the unfortunate town of Ubersreik. To live is to stick together- seriously, even on 'easy' stick together even Sigmar needed an army- survive and try your luck at Randald's Bones, a dice baced loot reward system. Its then on to the comforts of your very own Inn where you plot your next move and equip and change heroes of which there are currently five. It is here you also get to try your luck at forging new weapons from those you've collected and upgrading the higher tier weapons that have traits by using resources from salvaged weapons.

The rinse and repeat gameplay is still highly addicting and the random events make for periods of quiet anxiety followed by intense frenzied battles, particularly at the higher difficulties. It is here you'll benefit from a strong party so playing with friends is recommended; and it is with friends that you'll have the most fun.

If you're a Warhammer fan you'll want this.

reviewText:
Yes, yes and yes, I haven't been this smitten by a game in a long time.

Vermintide wears it's obvious Left 4 Dead inspiration on it's sleeve, however it's set in the oft underused Warhammer Fantasy setting; features a horde of angry, plagued and militant rat men instead of zombies and has a heavy focus on melee combat instead of ranged.

While it may not have the same depth as some other first person melee games, it makes up for it with extremely satisfying animations and sound effects while still retaining a subtle degree of complexity. You will need to learn to use charge attacks, pushblock and dodge, without those nuanced skills you will find yourself taking alot of needless damage. Ranged weapons are primarily utility, as ammunition can be scarce. However, swapping between melee and ranged weapons is very quick with your only limitation being the associated weapon's reload speed, allowing them to be used reflexively based on the situation (such as taking out that pesky Ratling Gunner on the roof).

CautionThe game advertises mountains of shiny loot"
date: which will flip a switch in some people (myself included). Don't come into this game expecting an action RPG
recommended: don't expect to have a "main character" that you level up exclusively
hoursPlayed: don't come into this thinking the main point of the game is to grind for loot. This is Left 4 Dead
voteText: you play the game because you find it fun. Unlike L4D you will have a chance at earning loot upon successfully completing a level which can be used only by a specific character
helpfulPercent: but you won't always get an item for the one you are playing. This is likely to encourage you to try out different characters.\n\nI point this out because many people are understandably miffed by how heavily RNG focused the loot system is
votesHelpful: comparing it to Destiny. Unfortunately it seems alot of these (valid) criticisms are made by people who are putting the loot first and the game second
votesTotal: perhaps because they had the wrong idea about what this game's design philosophy seems to be.\n\nSummary if you want an extremely competent and challenging co-op FPS game with an atypical melee focus and are willing to put the loot as a secondary motivator for playing instead of the primary one
votesFunny: I highly recommend you pick this one up."

reviewText:
Warhammer: End Times – Vermintide is a first person action game developed and published by Fatshark who have brought us a few notable titles to Steam over the years such as Bloodsports.TV and War of the Roses. The game was released on PC in October 2015 but is due to be released on PS4 and Xbox One in early 2016.

The game play is very similar to that of Left 4 Dead. You team up with three other players to battle through stages taking on rodent like creatures, the Skaven. There is also an element of character progression in the terms of equipment. At the end of each stage you get a reward of dice to roll, the better you roll, the higher quality item you get.  Each character has its designated role within the group of playable characters. There is a good mix of range damage dealers, melee and tank characters.  The combat melee system is really well put together, the blocking system in this game is very key to playing a melee character correctly as you will just take too much damage to be beneficial to your party. The mage class does a ton of damage, but also runs the risk of dealing damage to herself through overpowering her magic. I particularly liked the mage class as there is a pretty high skill ceiling between playing the character OK and playing it really really well.  You can play the game single player with bots, but you are going to get the most enjoyment out of playing it in a group of four.

The visuals in Vermintide are really good. They capture the Warhammer feel and atmosphere perfectly. The animations of all the characters are nicely put together with no weird movement cycles or attack animations. The lighting is extremely well done too as you delve deep into dark parts of the city. There is a loosely connected narrator to the game as well; the narration is done in real time as you reach certain locations on the stage, and this also provokes a reaction out of the party members, each character will react differently to what is happening. I thought this was a nice little addition that breaks up the repetitiveness nature of the game.

Each stage has a variety of different difficulties to play on, the higher the difficulty you play, the better chance you have to get improved loot at the end of a successful run. You can jump straight into doing “Normal” runs, but you will find yourself being severely overwhelmed due to your equipment not being up to par, once you get yourself a decent set of gear you can start jumping into the normal runs and then work your way up from there into the harder difficulties.

The stages are all nicely designed. It reminds me so much of Left 4 Dead with the layouts and how there is different styles of Skaven enemies to take on. Throughout the stages you will also have the chance to find treasure chests which also can reward you with additional dice for the end of the level, as well as health potions or stat potions.

At the moment I have been playing Vermintide for just over five hours; I can see myself dipping in and out of the game for a few reasons which I will go on next, but there is a good level of replay ability here. The loot factor being the main element that will keep people coming back; everyone loves getting loot and you will get plenty in this game. The other key factor is the multiplayer/team based, if you can find yourself a group of friends to run stages with, you will find yourself being sucked into this game for hours at a time.

Now, onto the technical issues. First of all, the performance on Vermintide is pretty poor, even when playing on SLI 970s I wasn’t able to push out 4k graphics without sacrificing frame drops. I was happy to drop my resolution down to 1440 whilst also keeping settings on max. The major technical issue I ran into would be random crashes.  Every two runs I did, I would get at least 1 crash throughout, and sadly if you crash, you can’t reload your game and jump straight into the last party. This became very annoying and to the point where I don’t see myself playing this game too much in long stints, I’ll jump in for a run or two here and there, but nothing more than that.

To sum up, Vermintide is a very good game in thought, and when it works it is absolutely awesome. I really hope they manage to fix the random crashes because this game would be right up my ally. The fact the game has such stellar gameplay which reminds people of an even better game, Left 4 Dead, will do this game huge favours. The game is retailing for £22, 99 on Steam and that is almost as low as it’s been since it was released. I will recommend this game with the premise you get it when on sale, purely because of the technical problems.  If you are lucky enough to get by without having crashes, Vermintide is an awesome game that will give you hours and hours of content.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please give it a thumbs up. If you would also like to follow my reviews more easily, be sure to join my group by clicking here.

You may also be interested in checking out a PC gaming podcast, be sure to head here.

http://store.steampowered.com/app/235540/

reviewText:
First off: I wish there were more options than yes and no to judge on a game, and it's especially true for this one.

Now now... Warhammer The End Times: Vermintide is in no way a bad game. Well, it shouldn't be at least.
As you probably know or guessed, it's a 4 player, CO-OP based game and the comparison with Left 4 Dead or even Payday seems kind of obvious. The main difference with this game is that it's mostly melee based. Well duh, it's based on Warhammer, not 40K.

It's a pretty good thing really. Feels refreshing and all that.
Now why am I not recommending this game?
Thing is, I cannot recommend it AT THIS POINT. This might as well evolve in the future and I'll edit my review accordingly, but as of now, I'd say stay away from it and wait for the devs to actually do what they're saying.

There are a number of issues with Vermintide, I'll try to list all I can think of. First, let me begin with the fact that there are no dedicated servers and that the netcode is absolute garbage, resulting in desync, lag (that can easilly cost you your life) and other happy stuff.

1) Melee. It's a great idea to have a melee based FPS, especially when successfull titles like Shadow Warrior or Dark Messiah opened the way. Problem is, Vermintide seriously lacks feedback in that regard. Most of the time it feels more like you're sweeping wheat than actual Skavens. As a result, you'll often end up taking hits thinking you killed a mob when you missed it, or them, if you aren't careful enough.

2) Distance. Now I know the game is supposed to be melee based so of course, that ain't where it's going to shine, just like how most FPS don't shine on the melee side. Still, the ranged combat aspect could very well use some polishing, with a better feedback for example or, mostly, not having your allies push you as you're aiming. Which brings us to the third problem...

3) CO-OP. Cooperation is vital in this game. More so than in L4D or Payday. The game is unforgiving, and if you leave a team mate behind, you can be sure as hell he's going to die. Problem is, the game severely lacks anything in that sense. Some audio lines telling you that you left a team mate behind could fix that, though the audio could be revamped as well as it's not loud enough. Add the special enemies bugs like the Packmaster pulling you behind houses or the Rat-Ogre sending you all the way down, below buildings, and COOP becomes really tedious.

4) Variety. EDIT OF 11/27/15: Previously, I complained about the fact that we are only fighting rats when Warhammer has such a large story. What I didn't know is, Vermintide is a part of Warhammer lore so it makes sense, as they would have needed to program an entire new AI for new enemies, had they not been rats. However, the point still stands about the lack of variety.
The maps are very similar, the objectives are dull and you just end up missing that feeling of satisfaction whenever you complete one, resulting in the farm of the same 2 maps over and over for the loot. It can also be quite tricky to tell a rat from another, including specials, or from a pile of bricks. Everything is grey, it's night time all the time. It's... boring.

5) Equipement and loot system. Great idea in itself. It makes for the replayability, and it's always interesting to get new stuff or customize your gameplay a bit more from just the classes. Problem is, the loot system is totally unrewarding, you end up grinding and grinding never to get the weapon you so want. The fuse system is a good idea, you fuse 5 weapons and you get another one... problem is, the forge works based on the weapons you input. So it's great to get a better quality hammer if you have 5 hammers, but what are you gonna do with all those 1 handed swords? I'd say, give us some more options as to what we can get. Let the players choose which weapons they want, and let the die choose the quality and bonuses. Easy enough fix ain't it?

6) Performance issues, desync and a various set of bugs are common, so beware.

Finally. The game has great promises and I could very well see this becoming as popular as Payday or Left 4 Dead, but certainly not at this point. I'm kind of addicted to it, but god damn am I going to be mad if they don't give that potential gem the polishing it so needs! I'm not exactly sure why the game went out of beta so early... marketing strategy?
voteText: 145 of 220 people (66%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Pros:  Currently 5 classes to pick from: Witch Hunter, Bright Wizard, Dwarf Ranger, Waywatcher, and Empire Solider
Graphics are awe-inspiring, stunning to look at, and successfully conveys a skaven-ridden world
Music captures the eve of the end of the world perfectly; done by Danish composer Jesper Kyd, who also did music for the Assassin's Creed franchise, Borderlands 2, and Hitman
Respectable forge system, e.g. you can fuse items together, use plentiful, common, and rare materials to upgrade weapons, and you can salvage weapons into materials to be used for other weapons
Melee combat is extremely satisfiying, that is every swing when it connects with the enemy feels powerful
High replay value, especially if played with friends
13 reasonably-sized maps
The more side objectives you complete, the better your chances of getting rarer weapons/items
Numerous enviroments: towns/villages, markets, castles, and the underground. More will be added, such as forests, when it comes out of beta
A nice variety of special Skaven (similar to Left 4 Dead's Jockeys, Boomers, Spitters, etc)
Patches are being continuously implemented throughout beta and official release, and the developers are very transparent about issues, e.g. made several statements regarding the server downtime in beta
Feel very similar to and is heavy influenced by Left 4 Dead 1 and 2
Neutral:  First person melee and ranged combat
All classes can perform melee and ranged attacks, though ranged require ammo
Secrets and collectibles to be found in all maps
Collector's Edition available. Includes a map of Ubersreik, some high resolution wallpapers, the original soundtrack and a behind-the-scenes pack containing documents, concept art and development footage, and a unique item for each of the five heroes.
Cons:  Game suffers from heavy stuttering (fps drops from 60-70FPS, down to 30-40FPS)
If you're playing in PUG matches, you can rush and steal items, forcing players against the idea of team play
The difficulties are perhaps too challenging, e.g. easy feels like normal, and normal feels like hard
The forge section can be somewhat daunting and confusing at first
No dedicated servers at the moment
RNG on what weapons/items you receive at the end of the match
Can be repetitive/grindy
Internet connection required to play
Conclusion: I haven't had this much fun in an RPG co-op game since Payday 2 and Left 4 Dead 2. If you like co-op, RPG based games, I would recommend End Times. It's a game you can sink a lot of incredibly fun hours into! Not only that, but the developers are very pro-active with regards to their fan base/community, as is to build a lot of goodwill and trust.

Related games:  Left 4 Dead franchise
Payday franchise
Chivalry: Medieval Warfare

WARNING! NONE OF THESE ISSUES HAVE BEEN FIXED AS GAME HAVE NOW BEEN OFFICIALLY RELEASED, PROCEED WITH EXTREME CAUTION!

--

A game that has a series of unfortunate problems, many of them originating from the L4D franchise from which this game has been designed from. Not to say that the core experience makes it a bad game by any means, the melee and gore is very satisfying when It works but there's just too many glaring problems for me to personally enjoy it for more than a few hours at a time and following an incredibly bug-filled release that yet remains to be fixed, the developers have also gone out of their way to mislead the community by announcing how they have such BIG PLANS" for the game just to utterly STRUGGLE to release the world's weakest DLC including 3 maps

recommended: they've done zero effort to try and balance the 5 that currently exist) that cost 10€ whilst leaving the old maps that are bugged to all hell in the dust with even weaker updates inbetween fixing nothing but crashes that should have been solved at release.\n\nDo NOT buy this stagnating

HP is precious like all hell and having huge amounts of it be lost to quite frankly bull sh*t scenarios is a big no-no and these frustrations are only reinforced by the constant clumsy slow-downs all character suffer from before

reviewText:
Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide is an awesome co-op hack and slash game requiring a ton of team work set in the Warhammer fantasy universe.

You and 3 of your closest friends head off on a series of adventures where your job is to try and stay alive against a seemingly endless wave of rats.

If your familiar with Left for dead 2 you'll see some similarities. Screams signal an incoming horde, there are a variety of nasty special" mobs
date:
and any mistake by a single member of your party pretty much means your doomed.

What special monsters can you look forward to?

Rats that hook you and drag you off to basically be crucified while their minions slowly poke you to death. Did I mention a team mate has to save you?

Rats that stealth and pounce on you surprisingly enough anytime your by yourself. Hey guys let me loot this real quick BAM. You gotta get saved by a team mate again.

Rats with machine guns? Yep

Rats with poison gas bombs? Yep

Armored rats that are hard to kill? Yep

Oh and the super big rat ogre thing that takes your entire team beating the crap out of it for 5 minutes while it murders you all.

All of these encounters are completely randomized. You may get them immediately upon starting the level
recommended:
or all hell may break loose at the moment a party member is down. It definitely makes no run the same twice.

Loot is based on a dice roll system. You MUST complete a level to get a chance of getting loot. Once you do you can boost your chances of a green or a blue by getting tomes or grimores.

Keep in mind grimores reduce your health and seem to also kick the difficulty up a notch.

All of this mixed in with a combat system that is so much fun its hard to put into words. You can dismember your opponents
hoursPlayed: do massive sweeping attacks with 2 handed swords
voteText: shoot your enemies with guns
helpfulPercent:
or sit back and cast fiery doom. All play styles are an option!

Overall the game is a blast and should offer tons of hours of entertainment!

Check out my full video review here
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U6ubslo6UoM"

reviewText:
One of the most fun game I've played so far.

Gameplay is smooth, graphics are fine (I can't run it on Ultra just lowest but yeah.) learning curve is really easy and game pushes you to act as a team which what I've been searching for so long.

There are little problems when it comes to connection. When lagging enemies tend to hit after you defence and some little annoying places enemies hit you through walls and stuff similiar to that. ALSO I forgot something really needs to be changed and it's called Player Hosting. Why it's bad you might ask (as a customer who thinks to buy this game.) answer is simple. When the host player leaves or crashes match/map you are on restarts, this thing really annoys me with a lot of others. Only thing we can do is hoping at this point but I doubt they will change it near future.

Aside from game, lore is awesome in general. I mean come on IT'S ♥♥♥♥ING WARHAMMER.

About the new DLC maps. (Castle Drachenfels)
Development team really worked on this one. Map's atmosphere is great, you really feel like you are in a vampire castle. A LOT of new things been added such as a torch to aid you in darkness. New little stuff has been added to with the DLC like pull the lever and boom secret doors open and one of the most fun which is added to the game is traps, there aren't many but pressure plates are really fun to annoy your friends also I think it's possible to push enemies to wall spikes and iron maidens which scattered around the first map. Well when it comes to dark envoirments nothing says we've done it as Warhammer fantasy, vampire lords. Castle Drachenfels is really accurately made in game. My only complain would probably not getting any new enemies aside from that new update added new weapons to the mix such as axes for Waywatcher (Which I still didn't get but saw for now.) and a volley crossbow for Witch Hunter. Overall the new DLC is fun, go grab one or grab an friend who has the DLC and roll with it!

Let's go back to the point. Game is really nice, loot grinding is important for difficulty levels. Teamplay is important. Worths every cent you've spent.

9/10

reviewText:
I really want to give this game a thumbs up but there are a few issues stopping me from doing so. If you're looking for a game you can kick back and play with friends then by all means grab Vermintide. However, if you grab this expecting to play with random players online don't expect to find many people; the player base has only shrunk since release day.

Pros:
+ hack n' slash
+ Warhammer Fantasy setting
+ great character design/dialogue
+ several weapons available for each character

Cons:
- dwindling player base
- severe lack of missions (becomes very grindy and repetetive)
- frustrating dice-based loot system
- optimisation issues
- bugs that have gone unfixed for a while

EDIT: supposedly a recent update has fixed some of the bugs and introduced host migration. While this is good it doesn't solve the fact that it's difficult to find a match, thanks to the dying player population. Overall though, I don't recomment picking this game up at full price but definitely consider grabbing when it's on sale and if you have a few friends to play with.

reviewText:
Pretty darn good game so far.    It has optimization issues at times but Fatshark seems to be handling critcial/high issues fairly well for such a small company.

Pros:
-Great melee system - every weapon feels responsive and is different to use.
-Loot based system that adds replayablity.
-Really nice graphics that set the mood and atmosphere of a fantasy world on the eve of the end of the world.
-Five different classes with their own play styles and personalities.   The voice acting is pretty great.
-Great co-op experience with okayish AI partners.
-Very challenging game - at least right now on normal.   You will need to have good teamwork and gear to go past Normal.
-Similar vein to L4D with enough tweaks to make it stand out enough.
-13 levels at release - the three levels they have in the pre-order beta are enough fun for a few hours though, and each level will have a lot of replaybility thanks to the tomes and grimories, which are optional objectives that will give you better loot if you get to the end with them.

Cons:
-Some odd bugs here and there still with Skaven appearing out of thin air, or through walls.   Nothing majorly breaking with the exception of the now and again crash.
-Some performance/optimization issues need to be ironed out a bit but I have faith that the devs will get that taken care of.

Bottom line is that if you like co-op games, you like L4D or Warhammer Fantasy in general ,you need to buy this game.  At 30$ the game is very reasonably priced.
voteText: 45 of 61 people (74%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Some time after I bought this game I wrote a positive review, because the game was a lot of fun, despite having some serious bugs and problems. The reasoning was that it seemed that the team behind the game was truly committed to fixing the game and adding more content. But after half a year, many of the bugs in the game and performance issues are still a problem. On top of that almost no content was released, with the exception of the Last Stand DLC. The problem with this DLC is that it's just a game mode that rehashes previous maps into an arena. This means that Last Stand was pretty much a lackluster DLC.

With some severe performance issues, several bugs still present and little content to keep players engaged, the player base has been fading away.
So now, I'm changing my review to negative. It's sad to see a game with so much potential dying like this.

reviewText: It took me a while to get into this one--I think because it was a bit messy and unbalanced in the beginning. However, once I found my niche it captured my attention and managed to hold onto it, which is quite an achievement given my level of gaming ADD. The rounds are short, the maps are just the right amount of challenging, and the addition of the survivor modes was a wonderful idea. My only complaint is that the reward aspect is horribly skewed and doesn't seem to be showing any signs of improvement. The online community is the same mixed bag that you'll find anywhere else: there are amazingly talented, friendly players; there are players who think they speak with the voice of Sigmar and will criticize everything you do for no apparent reason; there are dumbass newbs and fantastic newbs. All it takes is one a-hole to ruin your whole game, but if you get into one where you all just click it's a great feeling.\n\ntl;dr, great game if you don't mind grinding for little payoff and the usual online gamer interactions.
