reviewText:
Vermintide is a fun game for the first few hours, until the glaringly obvious game-breaking bugs become apparent. If you are interested in playing a game with strategic depth to co-op play that rewards good reflexes and accuracy, then this game is NOT what you're looking for. This game is broken in its current state. Fatshark, the developer, has made it abundantly clear that they are more concerned with early DLC, cross-platform distribution (of an unfinished game), and randomized gear grinding than creating a balanced and functional game. The bugs are numerous and many of them have persisted since the first release of the game despite several patches. Here is my list of the most game-breaking issues:

1) Spawn Logic:

There is little sense in how/when/where enemies spawn. Often you will catch waves of basic or special skaven spawning right in front of you. Watching enemies materialize in front of you not only destroys the immersion, but also increases the difficulty of the game in a non-meaningful way. Enemies will spawn directly in front of your path, trapping you in areas where enemies just beyond your line-of-sight can then attack you through walls, which bring us to the next issue...

2) Hitboxes:

There are several issues with hitboxes:

2a) Object irrelevance. Skaven can attack you through nearly any object. It doesn't matter if you're standing behind a bookshelf or a wall, under a platform or set of stairs, or on top of a platform or pillar, because the skaven will hit you through them. They can hit you through almost anything as long as you're within melee range, and that melee range extends beyond the visible range of the attack animation. Sometimes they'll even hit you while you're blocking (even with full stamina). Additionally, horde events set skaven hitboxes in place even when the spawning skaven have not yet rendered. This means that it can be impossible to rush through narrow areas ahead of horde events because you will be blocked by collision detection with skaven that don't yet exist.

2b) Hit registry. Many shots do not register hits, even when using hitscan weapons like the rifles. This can happen at any time. In my experience this happens more often when there are more skaven on the screen. A related issue is that high-penetration weapons (like the Soldier's rifle) will not register any hits whatsoever if the number of potential targets is too high (for example when a wave of skaven is stacked on top of each other). Additionally, your pushes can fail to register, seemingly at random.

2c) Hitbox size. Allied hitboxes are much larger than they appear. They seem to extend about 0.5m beyond the character models in all directions. This is very frustrating when trying to use ranged weapons to assist your allies. Shooting over an ally's head requires a steep angle. Additionally, allied hitboxes can clip through each other, so you'll end up shooting your friend who is standing 0.5m behind you because their hitbox is clipping through you without any visual cue to let either of you know.

2d) Terrain clipping. Put simply, you will trip and snag yourself on far too many objects. Is that a lone decorative brick on the floor? STUCK. How about a gradual slope upward? BETTER JUMP CONSTANTLY, otherwise you'll get stuck on literally nothing.

3) Optimization:

The game runs like molasses and crashes often. Even with decent hardware (I have a GTX 650 Ti, for example) and the lowest graphical/physics settings the game can rarely maintain >50fps, even with zero enemies spawned. The game bogs down to <20fps frequently when fighting larger waves, tanks, or during finale events, further crippling anyone's ability to rise to the challenge. This happens to every single person I know who has played the game (about 10 people), even those with hardware vastly superior to mine.

*****

On top of these absolutely critical gameplay issues, there are many smaller bugs that become more and more annoying with time. Sound bugs (music, environmental effects, and horde event effects will sometimes stop playing for the entire level), graphical bugs (invisible and unblockable skaven), and lobby bugs (sometimes if someone leaves your party during a level then you will be unable to complete that level because the game somehow recognizes the former player as still being a player rather than a bot, and since the bot will not enter the wagon at the end of the map it won't allow you to trigger the map finish) are but a few. There are STILL more bugs to write about, but instead I'll finish with one last gripe:

Gear is an integral part of this game. The customization is welcome but it is also terribly balanced. Many traits are vastly inferior to the few good traits, and good gear is essential to being able to complete the hardest gamemodes. Since the gear drops and trait rolls are random, you had better be ready to grind your face off trying to get decent enough gear to continue playing the game. I know people who have played HUNDREDS of hours and don't have any orange trinkets.

4/10 game. Good music, good voice-acting, good art, and good lore. Everything else is terribly lacking.

reviewText:
As a variation on Left 4 Dead theme, Vermintide is a coop survival game based on a simple yet polished and intense game mode.
Five different and brilliantly depicted characters, together with their own weapon sets, offer several combat moves and play styles, based on both melee and ranged weapons. Weapon feel and combat animations are well-refined and great to enjoy, as well as the mission settings (Stingray graphic engine is powerful but suffers from some performance issues).
End-mission reward system and five difficulties push the player to refine his skill and coop tactics, granting diversity and longevity to a basic simple format.
Vermintide is a perfect example of how well-realized simple ideas are enough, and should be the core, to build an amazing gaming experience.

91/100

reviewText:
Well with 150 hrs of play time ill be honest, There are good and bad things to point out.
The game was sold incomplete for sure a lot of things dont add up and its quite obvious it needs some work. In spite of this it is a great game non the less. The item drops take a very long time to get anything decent and it took me about 30 hrs to actually get anything good while playing on nightmare with horn of magnus. Which i recommend as its fast and easy to finish for items. A down side is getting trinkets or even good trinkets is practically impossible. With 150 hrs on record i have no good trinkets to speak of not even a legendary one so that is somthing they need to work on big time, All the while im always playing nightmare so item drops are better but you rarly see trinkets on there.
If you dont buy the collectors editions then you cant buy it after the fact since there is no in game store which is a downside but since there isnt a store and the collectors edition doesnt do anything for you (i think it gives you some hats which are just for decoration on your character no perks) its not worth the double price. Save your money.
Overall this game is very fun especially with a good team with microphones so i recommend this game but it does need a lot of work and i belive with all the patches they are doing they are working on making it better so give it a try, just dont buy the collectors edition as its not worth the extra cash. Thanks for reading

reviewText: This game is, hands down, a better version of Left 4 Dead. If you enjoyed that game, this one is taking that one to the next level. It's a grim-dark fantasy FPS co-op game with personal advancement and a small side-crafting-like system. It encourages, nay... DEMANDS cooperative play. If you're the 'lone-wolf' type of player, you can still shine, but if you try to go it alone, you will fail. Stay together. Stay alive. FOR THE EMPIRE! FOR THE EMPEROR!

reviewText:
For TL:DR, scroll to bottom for summary score.

Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide is a coop-oriented first person shooter where you take on the role of a freelancer who ventures throughout the war-torn cities of the empire, killing endless lines of Skaven in the glorious name of Sigmar. In this game, you have the honor of serving the Emperor and Empire; with sword, gunpowder, bolts, magic and finesse. This game is action-paced, and as many have mentioned this before: It plays very similar to Left 4 Dead, except the Zombie cliche was knocked out and you actually have more variety and things to do.

The cast: An edgelord witchhunter who sneers like a jolly ol Englishman, an alcoholic elf-bashing dwarf stereotype with an axe, an mysterious and agile dwarf-bashing elf, an old lady that lights people on fire; and finally, a poster child empire soldier who lives up to the Landschneckt namebrand.

The Antagonists: A wide variety of filthy and disgusting Skaven rat-like humanoid creatures, varying in size and capability. You have Skaven specialists which resemble the behavior of certain L4D specialty zombies; with some differences to separate them. For example, a Hunter equivalent from L4D in Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide would be the Gutter Runner; which is slightly easier to hit but can also disappear and you may not notice before it comes back to strike. Specialty Skaven like the Gunner has no distinguishible L4D counterparts; thus is unique in its own way. You have the Rat Ogre which replaces the Tank; but also you can parry its melee and dodge its attacks better. There is sometimes an armored Skaven which requires an armor-penetrating attack or weapon, as will be discussed further.

The Gameplay: The gameplay follows a similar route to Left 4 Dead; except it has more of an emphasis on Melee weapons. You have access to a multitude of potions which buff your character in some way, and is distinguishable from Left 4 Dead since some buffs give you more strength for example. You start at the beginning of a level and have to slowly make your way to the endpoint, and in between that is a struggle with skaven hordes, specialists, side-objectives and so on. The levels in Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide are usually long, and like Left 4 Dead: You can hit specialty monsters randomly with different spawn counts. Unlike Left 4 Dead, Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide offers some extra goodies to contend with, such as having a lobby" level where you are in a tavern with a chest to check your equipment (you have persistent weapon drops and gear)
date: an altar to make trinkets as well as a forge to combine items (Of same rarity) and upgrade some.\n\nThis game rewards you with experience points and level ups
recommended: which allow you to have better access to more Trinket slots
hoursPlayed: weapon drops as well as new levels (assuming you beat the beginning ones). In each mission
voteText: there is a chance to loot a dice which you can then roll at the end of the game which may give you the chance to strike a better weapon drop. Unlike CS:GO
helpfulPercent: these weapons are NOT skins and are instead fully functional with different stats and function; thus you aren't riddled with such annoyances of pointless textures slapped on weapons you use. In the lobby area
votesHelpful: you can form a group and use the interactive map to decide which mission and difficulty you want to do
votesTotal: and you can change your hero from one of the 5 heroes.\n\nWhile the game behaves similar to Left 4 Dead
votesFunny: it offers enough unique experiences and extra features that I don't consider it a retextured Left 4 Dead mod. The level design in this game is great
commentsCount: there is more of an emphasis on vertical heights and bridge crossings; making the navigation experience a fresh change. The specialty Skaven as I mention: have similarities to the Left 4 Dead specialty Zombies
column16: except some small details in their behavior and functionality. The game puts a emphasis on teamwork. If none of this matters and you are a Warhammer Fantasy fan
column17: then by all means; you will not be let down by this culturally rich Warhammer Fantasy game. But let me hope that you do at least care about the background features and overall framework of the game first. One other thing: Every character has a variety of weapons to choose from

reviewText:
Warhammer: The End Times - Vermintide is a 1-4 player cooperative game in the style of Left 4 Dead. The action is unequivocally fast-paced and sticking together is vital for avoiding the team dying a quick death. It was clearly built with a primary motive of supplying replay value, but it of course depends largely on your investment in the atmosphere, mechanics, and loot system.
I'll note here that I know very little of Warhammer fantasy but still enjoyed the game and the setting, and also that I bought the game pre-release.

Variety of missions from short objective-focused missions (search, protect, etc.) to long adventure missions with a changing dynamic.
Attention to detail on the maps, combined with the fast paced nature of the game, means you'll be able to notice new intricacies with new playthroughs.
Element of randomness means items and enemies can appear in different places, keeping suspense high.
Unique characters capable of handling different weapons means you will be able to and encouraged to experience and learn different styles of play.
Five (current number) unique characters as opposed to four means you will always have a choice as to whom you wish to play as.
Dropping into games after they've started, replacing a bot, is possible. It is therefore easy to get into a game and not too problematic if someone exits yours.
Mission rewards and experience are handed out when a mission ends, meaning people are a little more inspired to stick around for the full duration (even if the mission is a failure, there is a small bonus).
Forge/ upgrade and prayer systems give you something to do with rewards you don't care so much for, letting you turn them into something better.
Hidden items which better your chances of getting higher-tier rewards are fun to discover and also add an interesting risk-reward dynamic, as you can wound your chances of success to improve your chances of desirable loot.
Up to five (current number) levels of difficulty also adds to the risk-reward (higher difficulty: more experience points), and lets you choose between casual or more intense play.
The soundtrack is good and it appears to fit the setting and the skaven hordes well.
Some DLC was released for the game but the developers seem to have taken measures to avoid it splitting up the playerbase too much. You do not necessarily need to purchase the DLC in order to play the DLC.
Sigmar's Blessing and Last Stand were just free updates to the game. The first was to improve the loot system and the second adds a survival mode with one free survival map (based on a section of a regular map).
The Schlusselschloss DLC was a second survival mode map (this time unique). You can play it without paying for it by selecting 'Last Stand' and then selecting to play a 'Random' level or by having a friend with the DLC invite you to the game.
The Drachenfels DLC adds three more regular maps, and again a friend can invite you to the game even if you don't own the DLC yourself (you're still fighting Skaven and it's largely more of the same, to some people's dismay).

However,
It won't take too long to play through all of the missions just once, at least on the easier difficulties. Although the game lends itself to replayability, if you don't want to replay anything, you should buy it with a high % off. The same goes for current paid DLC.
Although missions and characters are justified with a short bit of background, you shouldn't expect to be sucked into a story as much as you should expect to be sucked into glorious rat genocide.
There is only so much you can do locally. You can't play splitscreen/ local coop, and human teammates have more potential to help you survive and prosper than the bots do. Higher difficulties may just mean frustrating deaths if you're play alone.
Of course, human teammates can mess up too, and this is a game where it's expected that you'll die a few times anyway (or not get the loot you want). If you can't relax or enjoy tragic humour then you may have occasional 'issues'...
I find the first-person perspective in this game feels a little weird. Things change in scale noticeably, and your hands can float slightly inside the walls. You, and enemies, also seem to hit further than I would first expect. Related to that, I know some other want the ability to play in third-person, but so far you can only view your character like that.
So finally... it's a fun game for people who like frantic cooperative gameplay. It's fairly easy to get into but also requires you to learn and evolve in order to tackle the higher difficulties. And it's essentially a multiplayer game. Attention to detail and loot progress mean replayability is the focus.

reviewText:
I'll recommend this game if you have 1-3 friends to play with, or you're a fan of the L4D type of gameplay. If none of those apply to you, you might want to wait with this until it's on sale.

This game is 4 people who work together to get to the end of a map, usually doing small events during the map that involves holding out an attack by a horde of enemies, or transporting sacks of grain/barrels to key locations, all while being attacked by hordes of enemies. On top of the normal enemies who are mostly just fodder, there are special types of enemies, much like in Left 4 Dead, that require teamwork to kill.

The maps are very linear, with small areas to explore for various loot that can spawn in set locations. There's a total of 13 maps varying in length and difficulty. The different maps help to keep things fresh, but there's just one problem. You most likely wont be playing most of these maps at all.

The progression system is what fights against the different maps, because only some maps are long enough to contain special items that you can pick up during the mission, to improve your loot drops at the end of a mission. This bonus to your loot is so significant, that it feels completely useless to play any other map than one where you can get all the bonus loot items.
Additionally, some maps are just easier than others, but they all drop the same loot. You can see this on the matchmaking time, people are mainly just playing the same map over and over, because there's no reason to ever go to another map.

If you love getting loot, then you will most likely end up in the same situation as me. Clearing the same map over and over, so that's definitely something to keep in mind. I personally still like doing that one map, because of the special enemies that spawn randomly, every run is never completely the same, and even though there's effectively only a very small number of maps, the different classes add spice to the game.

There's 5 classes: A bright wizard, who can shoot fireballs or beams of fire and other fire related destruction, depending on what weapon she uses. Then there's an elven archer with a variety of bows and fast melee weapons. A Witch Hunter, who can dual wield pistols. An Imperial Guardsman, who can choose to be a tank, or use a slow firing but strong gun. Last a dwarf, who can also be a tank, with interesting gun choices too.
All the classes have a few different ranged and melee weapons to use, that change up the gameplay. You have limited ammunition, so you will have to use a mix of melee and ranged combat, which is a lot of fun.

The loot that drops at the end of a game has 4 different types of quality. White, green, blue and orange. Each step up in quality gives the weapon one extra random trait, that you need to unlock by salvaging other weapons . That ends up being a lot of random. You get a random weapon type, for a somewhat random class (higher chance for current class), with random quality with random traits. The chance of getting that one weapon type with the traits you want, is really low. The randomness and different quality gives you incentive to try out another class after you've found that cool orange weapon for him, but it can also be really frustrating to keep getting items for a class that you do not want to play.

It should be mentioned that the AI bots are horrible. If a player disconnects, or you're having problems finding people through the matchmaker, you gotta think twice before going on as only 3 people. Playing solo with 3 bots is basically impossible, so if you're not keen on playing with other people, then this game is not for you.

Conclusion
The game has decent map variety, if you're okay with getting severely worse loot drops. If you aren't okay with that, the game makes up for it with great class diversity and randomly spawned special enemies. A fun game to enjoy with a few friends =)

reviewText:
After 400 hours I figure it's time I gave this game a review.

Obviously having that much time in the game I find it to be a challenging and rewarding experience. Those rewards, however, are intrinsic to a difficult game. Do not expect this to be a loot driven, MMORPG-esque experience. It isn't. In fact I daresay that if you play this game with loot on the brain, expect to be disappointed. This game is about taking three other people and doing some of the most challenging and visceral melee combat that I've ever encountered in a game. Completion of missions offers the reward of self satisfaction and, sometimes, maybe a piece of loot you can use.


There are five difficulty levels and the differences between each are noticable and substantial. Easy is basically a check to see if you understand mechanics and is good for the first map or two. Normal is a fantastic way to farm your first 10-15 levels. Once you begin playing Hard the hits will begin to hurt and you will run the legitimate risk of having a team wipe. Nightmare introduces friendly-fire and challenges players well up to level 100. Finally, Cataclysm offers the ultimate challenge. In Cataclysm difficulty, just four hits from even the most basic enemy can down your character.

I recommend this game to anyone who is interested in the four player co-op genre. Do not purchase this if you're not willing to work together with your fellow players in order to achieve a common goal. Do not purchase this if you're primarily concerned about the weapons/trinkets/items you recieve along the way. Loot isn't a big part of this game, ultimately. DO purchase this game if you enjoyed Chivalry, Dark Souls, or similar challenging melee combat titles. DO purchase if you enjoy being legitimately challenged in a group environment. You will need friends to keep up in Vermintide, and once you're in the zone, the experience is unparalled.

reviewText:
This review is about Ai.
I guess I'll try to be the voice of reason. I don't always want to play games with real people, but with this game's difficulty and poor Ai its just a waste of my time. Expect to find yourself with twice as many kills as the next closest Ai and still lose, over and over. Ai doesn't pick up Tomes, Ai doesn't heal itself properly, Ai doesn't prioritize saving you when you go down, the Ai doesn't care that a Packmaster just spawned behind you and is now dragging you away.

If and when you finally do begrudgingly make your way through a mission on Normal with Ai, expect your 7 dice RNG game to give you a white item for your time even if you got both grimoires and a tome because hey RNG is fun right guys? Right? Random chance is really fun guys! Well, no... its not, and playing with Ai is frustrating, unfun and unrewarding.

Here are my recommendations for Ai and loot:
If they have 30% health and have a health potion, yet are standing next to another health potion on the ground, make them heal and pick up the unused health potion, mother of god. If the design philsophy to make Normal easy is to add lots of health potions, make your Ai take advantage of it.
Prioritze a downed player over attacking mobs. Why make me sit there and watch for 2 minutes as we lose because the Ai doesn't care?
Give the player some command, even something simple such as pick up that item". That's all it needs to be
date: really.\nThe entire loot system needs revamped
recommended: it can be extremely frustrating and not-rewarding because its based on RNG. Even going out of your way in a game with Ai to increase the chance at a green is an infuriating experience.\nWith all that said and in conclusion: don't pick this game up unless you have a solid reliable group of friends who will play it with you for thousands of hours. You're not going to want to play with the Ai because you might as well be playing solo
hoursPlayed: and It's going to take you a while to get any decent look because the RNG system is unrewarding.\n\nEven so

reviewText:
Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide....

Well it's just like it sounds , A FPS Warhammer game that plays in the End Times where you slay tides of Vermin.

It is fun , it is incompilcated but yet Challenging on higher difficulties.
It found the right balance between RPG and FPS and combined them to be THE BEST CO-OP FPS i've ever Played.

You Start off In The Inn which is a VERY Detailed Medieval Planning Room with alot of features such as The MissionMap , an Forge , an Shrine and an Inventory stash.

It is also the place where you invite your Friends or other Players join you to play the Mission the Host selected ergo the Mission the group supposedly agreed upon.
After you ended your Mission you can go with your Party/Friends back into the Inn to change Gear Craft or Demolish your goods to create new ones.
It's a Useful feature and makes the Partyplay Simple and takes away the need to leave early.
The Difficulties are all together well made and balanced at this point , from personal Experience i can say that as a matter of fact you can Climb +1 Difficulty per day if you Learn ,  Adapt and Smack the Hell out of Vermin all day long.

The Settings Options on the other hand are Mediocre , you have Only a Limited Choice of Options you can Enable or Disable WITHOUT having access to the important Settings such as adjusting the VRAM Pool for the Texturestreaming , setting the correct Audio Channelsize , changing the Specular Map amount of Static decals etc. list goes on and on.
And therefore you cannot really Optimize the game for yourself , which leads to guaranteed FPS drops on most Systems.

And here we are ... at the Point where we talk a bit more about the Games overall Performance.
Now it is indeed stated that the game is processor Heavy , but what is sold as working game is a Butcher for your CPU it puts 100% Load with X Workers on X cores and still performs only meh , it is neither Optimized for AMD or Intel since both seem to have heavy fps dips with alot of Trash on the Map and yea ... you kinda need your FPS when you have to deal with 50 Vermin don't you? especially when your Hero's loadout requires a bit of aim to work.

It's not only the CPU performance going south ... The GPU performance is even worse , i'm running a r9 390x(not gonna buy an nvidia card so shht) and the Game is using .. uhh 1.5 of my 8GB VRAM .. ye Really. also the Useage of the GPU don't go up with lowering/cranking up the Settings it just stays the same for the Entirety of my Gaming Sessions so is my Temperature . for such an hardware heavy game i Honestly expected more than an Maximum of 53°C after 5 hours for example.

I'm the kind of guy that doesn't really care when it dips into 40 fps because it's still playable yes sure it's annoying but not gamebreaking.
People that don't see it that way might want to wait until the Game/Engine receive a proper overwork aka Patch.

Well ... All in All i got to say i'm having a blast playing this game with Friends and going for the Loot and climbing difficulties together.
Already Killed a Good amount of Hours and Vermin with this Game and will Proceed doing So.

ONWARDS TO VICTORY! :D

reviewText: I have two VERY big problems with this game. The loot system is a complete waste of time, you get a weapon only after completing a level which is then made worse by the rarity being judged by RNG (or RANDOM Number Generation).The loot system is actually the reason I stopped playing the game. The second problem i have is that you are not allowed to play offline with bots. They have bots in the game and you can actually play only with bots and yourself but they cant just include offline? I know for a lot of people this wouldn't matter but with a crap ISP and having to move my tower a lot, it would have been nice for something that could be implemented so easily to be added. (also remember that 3GB patch for a couple bug fixes?)

reviewText:
Gameplay is fun for a while untill it gets old, same thing over and over no real change to any of the missions only some visual aspects at some areas after a few hours of gameplay though the actual missions are all the exact same.

The looting system is a bit worse than Destiny's RNG loot system unless you're lucky enough to get one or two upgrades within hours of grinded farm. You can fuse things toghether to make better items but that as well is competely random since you are more likely to get something for another class instead of the one that you're actually playing.

Pretty much, it's something pretty to look at and might be worth buying at 50-70% off unless you enjoy an endless grind where you have to sit for hours to get no where.

The difficulty's aren't really that hard either since me and a mate completed the first mission on hard with the starter weapons (since neither of us has gotten anything for a period of 9 hours of constant mission and fuse grind) the real difference between Hard and easy is that they take 2-3 more hits and they need 2-3 hits less so sadly there's no tactics needed for the harder difficulty's as of yet.

reviewText:
This is a fun game, the glitches are rare and the sound and lore is spot on. So why am I not going to recommend the game?

The RNG loot system has been vary rude to me, after my 10th Cataclysm run with 2 grims and 3 tomes(31 runs in total on cat but didnt finish with all the tomes so didnt count) only to get average of 3-4 out of 7 possible successes and get a blue for all that hard work... no thanks.

Also the Stars by the dice are misleading, it will show multiple Stars almost like its indicating the number of successes on the faces, the default dice with 3 stars may get you to think that on a 4 5 6 you get a success... not true after taking notes to the success rates, the normal is equal to a 6 up, the loot die is a 5-6, the tome dice is a 4-5-6 and the grim is the 100%.

Try rolling 7 normal dice see how many and what number show up, Now think of it this way your going to spend on average 30 min to get one item, How many 6 can you roll or how many tomes can you finish with to slightly improve your chances, not really that good of a chance to get anything worth wild.

reviewText:
I really love warhammer, but I can't recommend this game in the state it's in. As other reviews have stated, playing alone or with a friend sucks. Bots suck too bad to make the game enjoyable and farming for loot is only fun if it's rewarding; you'll be 70 before getting a rare item.

Unless you have a full team of 4, the game is quite literally hell in most scenarios.
Also.. weapons.
Dwarf has very limited choices when it comes to weapons, the hammer feels too weak and the 2 handed axe fails to be useful when a shield is quite literally the best thing in the game.

I wanted this game to be good, but sadly for myself this just feels like a lazy attempt at reviving the left 4 dead niche genre. Sadly i'll keep playing it when I can get people online with me, because despite the fact it lacks in a lot of ways, smashing rats in the face feels good.

reviewText:
+ L4D in medieval style
+ Amazing graphics
+ Intense atmosphere
+ Excellent voice acting

- AI teammates suck balls
- Random bugs (like enemies get stuck in strange places)
- FPS drops (especially in the final level)
- Poor-designed reward system

Originally I was going to recommend this game, but as the reward I got from every successful mission did not quite match up with the effort, the enthusiasm for running the same level over and over again eventually waned off.

Also, I don't know if It's just me, but the missing gun sound is still missing, even though the latest patch claims it has been fixed.

Vermintide is a good game, for hardcore gamers only.

reviewText: Unfortunatly level design and rewards contradict each othe too much (e.g. a short level rewards you as much as a longer and harder one). Furthermore most maps feature boring design and you will soon end up grinding that one map that doesnt suck and gives you quick rewards. Classes do not posses any skills which would further differentiate them from one another. Unfortunatly also a pure button masher and not a great melee combat sytem like in dark messiah. A lot of potential unused... Oh and did I mention picking up barrels as objective in almost every level is ♥♥♥♥ing boring? Oh and not to mention crashes (yup you just ♥♥♥♥ed your party, thx random crash, and nope you wont rejoin cause someone will join the game in your stead as you can't reserve single slots) and horrible performance on some maps/ and certain effects. Oh and who doesnt want to get butt♥♥♥♥ed by rng at the end of a hard level receiving the same loot with all bonus enhancers you would receive on the lowest difficulty. Also there are several ways to cheese the levels atm which are heavily being abused by the community, which lead to a huge gap in gear for those who do not make use of the possibilites the game currently offers. There are levels where you can completly block enemy spawns no matter what the difficulty level and which are just broken in their current state. Also there are several bugs (e.g. resolution reset on startup) and more crashes than i think are acceptable for a launch title. Just to give a comparison: In the past 5 years not one launch title I played crashed as many times as warhammer did! Sry for the long rant there are of course also things I like about the game but I think the other reviews cover that in enough detail, overall I still would hold of and wait for the game to either be patched some more or on sale, as I do not think they will be able to fix the design issues any time soon.

reviewText:
I really want to like this game, but I simply can't.
The concept is awesome, I love Warhammer and a coop game in the fantasy universe is a great idea. The theme with the Scaven is inventive, usually developers are lazy and go Orcs or Chaos, so a change of pace is nice.
However, everything other than the universe and theme simply feels unfinished,
First off, framerate is a huge issue. I cannot get the game to stabilize at 60fps no matter what I do (within reason, I wont go below 1920x1080). Hovers around the upper 50s most of the time, plummets to mid 40s whenever there are more than 4 enemies on the screen. Not only that, but the game looks awful. I was not expecting much, but mostly everything except the lighting looks dated. Skypboxes are awful and anything at a distance is just ugly, hell, even most things right up in your face are ugly (weapons are the exception). Animations are sloppy at best, terrbile at worst. And the weight" to melee that you've seen mentioned in all the previews is just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. It simply feels disconnected

reviewText:
Like everyone else has been saying this is basically a L4D clone set inside the Warhammer universe. But a great art style, superb voice acting and an interesting setting doesn't save up for the largely unfinished gameplay.

This really does feel like an early access game at times and there is a whole lot wrong with it. I would think this game needs a few months of work to reach its potential because at the moment, it's a combination of the good and the bad that is a bit of a letdown.

reviewText:
Great game with a ton of replay ability. While very much like Left for Dead, there is something about being up close and personal to your enemy and cleaving through them that makes the game more visceral. The loot system is a point of contention, but for me personally I love it.  I had a number of hours played as the dwarf and man at arms, and after probably 20 or so hours I finally started getting some orange weapons....and they were all Bright Wizard staffs!  At first I was peeved but relented and started playing as the BW, turns out she is super fun!  Well worth $30 and a bunch of fun if you have friends.

Quite a challange as well.  The game works you in with managable normal difficulty, but ratachets it up quickly once you hit hard and Nightmare.

All in all a great game that came as quite a surprise to many of us, I highly recommend.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Left for Dead like game play but set in the Warhammer universe. More Melee focused first Person however you do have a secondary weapon which is ranged and very important for taking out special units in troublesome situations.

Unlike L4D there is a actual reason to keep playing for more than just teamwork, LOOT! Zombies are replaced by Skaven (Rat creatures for the uninformed) as you pass through the level you pick items that heal, make you more powerful, ammo and items that give you better chances of da good loot at the end of the game. At the end of the game you roll dice and the number of successful diced roll determines the quality of the loot you receive.

Each race/character has access to race/char specific weapons, those weapons are (Mostly) unique weapons stats/characteristics, so each characater has its own specific play style as well which makes the game unique and replayable.

Great game, especially if you love the Warhammer. Even if you don't give two hoots about warhammer you will still love this game as it is essential that your team coops throughout to be able to complete the levels especially on difficulty levels Nightmare and Above. A breath of fresh air as most games seem said to be designed for coop end up lonewolf encouraging. There is also no benefit in knowing the lore in the Warhammer universe as it the gameplay and skill in blocking that determines players skill.

The game has its occasional bug and you do on rare occasions (like all games) have the odd idiot, however there is a kick player function (thankfully rarely used).

The game is also very reasonably priced at $30 (USD) and much to my surprise these days no day one DLC!

Buy it. You will not be dissappointed!

reviewText:
With Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide, we now no longer have to wait 80,000 years in order to experience what it is like to live in the world of Elois and Morlocks. Vermines, Skavens, rats, beings of the underworld or whatever you'd like to call them decides to invade the city of Ubersreik, and the heroes are there to drive them back to their underworld, while killing their families, burning their homes, nuking their cities and eradicating their existance on the way.

This game, like what many others have said, is very similar to that of Left 4 Dead 2 in terms of game-play, though there are apparent differences as well. You have two type of major weapons, melee and ranged. Both weapons vary depending on which of the 5 classes you chose. Some are versatile killers while others are ranged experts or indispensable tanks which can keep the whole team safe. The missions are similar to those of L4D2 as well, with half of them being campaigns where you have to venture into a place and clear a finale event before evacuating in a wagon-like transport, while the other halves are some defense or smaller event missions. Eneimes are similar as well, with hordes of small and weak rats, special rats with various attrabutes such as pouncing, strangling, gattling guns or toxic gases. There'll be a tank-like boss called rat ogre where the whole team has to gang up to defeat him, and the patrol armored rats where the team will have to hide while they move away, avoding their attention.

There is a leveling and weaponary system in the game as well. The levels means nothing except that they will award you with a new weapon (a rather weak one) with ever level you gained. The are no stats involved for the characters, such as strength or intellegence. The major prupose of the game lies in the weaponary system. At the end of each successful mission, be it the major campaings or smaller event missions, you will have a number of dice which you'll try to roll for better weapons. There is also a weaponary system where you can rank up your weapons or unlock skills for your weapons.

The game itself is not easy, though after a few days of gaming and a few trusted friends you should be able to handle higher difficulties. There are 5 levels of difficulties, though you can increase the difficulty of your game (if you are playing a campaign) by looking for and holding on to tomes and grimoires, of which the former will take up a health potion spot, while the latter a boosting potion spot and reducing the team's health points by a third.

Again, similar to L4D2, this game requires cooperative gameplay, so this is definitely a go if can gather enough friends (you need four players) who can gather together and play on a regular basis, as you'll most likely find rushers who will rush out, get pinned, die, and leave you with nothing but fustration.

P.S. The ending is kind of skimpy, though it's really not the whole purpose of playing this game, so I'll leave it for you to figure it out yourself.

reviewText:
I love this game, and so like all reviews, my opinion is biased.

My quick thoughts on it are that It has amazing and varied combat, with huge depth that will keep you coming back for more and more. It is in my opinion honestly better than left 4 dead as there is more to it than shooting at faceless characterless hordes of targets. Instead it’s a game about pitting you and your friends against an enemy that is beautifully brought to life as scheming, backstabbing, wimpy and yet charming race of rat men.

It brings to life a great world and characters that is just enough to draw you in and yet leaves enough mystery to entice you to go deeper into the lore through other mediums (which is just a testament to the talent of Fatshark and is a huge boon to Games workshop, so if nothing else GM should be throwing cash at this in my biased opinion :D ).

Its down side, in my opinion, are the bugs, the optimisation and the bots. But neither of these are game breaking in my experience and I have actively seen improvements. But be a smart consumer and do look into specs and performance reviews before you buy.

So I feel this is a great game! Worth the buy if you are looking for a meaty co-op focused combat game with great atmosphere, despite a few bugs and performance issues. So I recommend grabbing a weapon hero and joining me in the Reiklands. There be Skaven about!

reviewText: A charming (warhammer grimdark) team-based horde-fighting experience that has differentiated gameplay through its 4 classes and risk-based loot system. Mood of the game crafted through fitting environments and lighting and an atmosphere-driving sound design. From the tell-tale sounds of unique skaven presence to the get-hyped percussive insistence of a rat ogre fight, I felt immersed and invested in the state of hte characters. So much so that straying from the main path to obtain a tome or two gave me pause.\n\nIt might not be good that the mechanics of this game draw heavily from the acclaimed L4D series, but it definitely is not a bad thing. The whole pitchforking re: it's a X clone, shouldn't dissuade you from trying the game out. I believe with sincere development, making a game after a formula" will still yield unique experiences. The combat feels satisfying and the unique skavens
recommended: feel and adds positively to the gameplay. Thematically it definitely earns a place in my heart!\n\nFull disclosure though; While not having owned any warhammer tabletop sets
hoursPlayed: the fantasy (and its 40k cousin) universe has always enthralled me
voteText: so I definitely enjoyed another venture into this setting. I am also curious about 3rd party game engines and the fact that Vermintide was built on Autodesk's Stingray definitely piqued my interest.\n\nProbably the biggest downer is the demanding toll it puts on my laptop (middling i7 with a GTX970). Granted it is not a custom-built powerhouse but I think there can be some safeguards in place that prevents the repeated overheating and crash-to-shutdown occurrences. I did come across suggestions to circumvent the abovementioned on reddit but having to trawl the web for compromises should not be the case. Optimization is a ongoing battle waged by the devs and I do wish them luck on that front as it will heavily affect playerbase growth that is critical for a co-operative game such as this."

reviewText:
Do you like medieval settings?
Do you like left 4 dead?
Do you play D&D and have fun making jokes in-game?

You certainly should give vermintide a chance.


The game has some buggy aspects and it can become kind of grindy at some point but honestly it's fun and rewarding.

And talking about REWARDS this game doesnt give you better armor or defense equipment (except some few very specific trinkets) this game rewards you for being aware of your surroundings, timing your dodges, pushes and blocks perfectly, moving in group, working and battling as a party, keeping attention to every single detail of the enviroment, sounds of all kinds, THOSE are the subtle hints that WILL keep you alive in the higher difficulty settings and will fully immerse you in the actual horror of being surrounded by a horder or be trapped by a deadly PACKMASTER.

reviewText:
Fantastic setting that does wonderful justice to the source material. Yes, the game is totally Left 4 Dead placed in the Warhammer Fantasy setting... but how is that anything less than an ever better reason to get it?

The only problematic item is with the relatively low player population you are often forced to rely on BOTs to fill in the party and the AI seems to have no vague understanding that they need to protect the person that is claiming objectives.

Past that there is literally no reason that everyone should have this game in their library.

reviewText:
Vermintide's gameplay imitates Left 4 Dead competently.  But it lacks the versus mode that made Left 4 Dead great, with playable monsters.

That said, it has gameplay mechanics that put an interesting twist on the Left 4 Dead formula, such as charged attacks and dodging.

Buy this game if you haven't played Left 4 Dead, but wait for a sale if you have.

reviewText: There are plenty of lengthy reviews out there so I'm going keep mine short.\n\nIf smashing rat men with hammers and other mediaeval weapons sounds appealing to you, then you have found the game you've been looking for. reviewText: Ok, this review is aimed at my old KF1 (and KF2 I guess) buddies. Essentially Vermintide places you in the fantasy Warhammer setting and has you fighting your way from point A to point B, using a combination of melee and ranged weapons to survive attacks along the way. Your melee attacks work really well, with a good dodge/push/block/charged attack  system in place. The ranged weapons rely heavily upon finding ammunition so you need to use with care, but there are a wide range of weapons, each with their own strengths. Melee is definitely the focus however. In some ways it may seem similar to KF_Damnation, but dont let this put you off. I hate damnation, but really enjoy this.\nWhat I really like is the reward system. You level up and receive new weapons and gear by successfully completing maps/missions. At the end of the mission, you roll a set of dice, and the more successful dice rolls, the better weapon or gear you will be rewarded with. The weapon goes into your inventory pool, and you can either equip it to the appropriate perked character, or you can 'mess' with it some more. Messing' with it can be done in several ways. Firstly
date: you can try and change the weapons traits. I should explain. Weapons have bonus traits on them. For example
recommended: traits may give you healing when you hit something
hoursPlayed: or provide the chance of an instant kill
voteText: faster attack speed
helpfulPercent: leech ammo etc. There is also a percentage chance applied to this trait
votesHelpful: so for example
votesTotal: my flame sword has a 10% chance of healing me for 5 hp when I hit something. So I can roll some dice and try and change the trait to a some other ability that I would like
votesFunny: or
commentsCount: roll a dice and try and improve the percentage associated with the current trait. It costs a few tokens to do this. Alternatively you can meld 5 weapons of one particular level
column16: into 1 weapon of a higher quality. The final way to mess with the weapons is just to 'salvage' them and convert them to tokens. These tokens can be used to reroll traits on existing weapons
column17: or be used to create entirely new weapons if you'd rather.\nI should also add that the quality of the weapon/loot item you receive at the end of the mission can be influenced by picking up 'tomes' and 'grimoires' during play. These give your end of game dice a better chance of successful rolls
column18: but make the mission harder by limiting your healing options and maximum health throughout. Essentially they allow you to set your risk/reward level as you play. Brilliant!\nI really like that there is a real tangible reward for completing missions. Unlike with KF1/KF2
column19: there is no level cap (that I am are aware of) so you can keep improving your 'cred' if that's important to you. More importantly though
column20: you keep getting weapon/gear drops so can keep modifying and crafting new gear
column21: forever improving and honing your characters loadout.\nThere are 5 perk/classes at the moment
column22: but it feels like only 3 really. Each has basically 4 main melee and 4 main ranged weapons each for you to choose from
column23: but as stated before

reviewText:
Like Left 4 Dead? Wish it had progression and variety? Well this is the game for you.

Seriously, it's about time someone took the L4D formula and improved upon it. This game is pretty much exactly what you would want from a L4D-inspired game. The basic formula is the same but there's so many improvements that make it more refreshing to play. Also the difficulty is much higher. It's much harder to protect yourself against all incoming threats, the chances of you not taking damage are very unlikely.

Satisfying melee combat, effective but limited range capabilities. That's more so the kind of game this is in comparison to Left 4 Dead. There's much more emphasis on melee combat, and you'll really want to save your ranged ammo for special enemies. Funnily enough, this game has its own version of the Smoker/Jockey, the Hunter, the Spitter, and the Tank,

The Smoker-like enemy grabs you from a range much like a Smoker, but he drags you away from your team much like a Jockey. The Hunter-like enemy pounces you, but is capable of teleportation in order to escape. The Spitter-like enemy is much more threatening than a Spitter, as he throws acid jars that cover huge distances and is capable of throwing more than 1. The Tank-like enemy is pretty much the exact same as its L4D counterpart, big huge brute that takes A LOT of damage, while punching and knocking people away from it. The difference though is that in this game, you can block his punches with melee weapons, which while still deals damage to you, it prevents knockback.

Each character you can play as has specific weapon types they can use, and you can change between any of them at any time. You can mix, salvage, and upgrade weapons respectively. You get weapon drops from completing levels via dice rolls. You can improve your chances of good dice rolls by picking up Tomes in the level, which take up your medkit slot. So you have to do some risk and reward stuff. Get better rewards by going without a medkit, or play it save and bring a medkit with you.

Overall, there's a lot more to this game, and I really hope they continue to support it with more content in the future. There's so much they can do with it, and I hope they don't waste their opportunities like Valve did with Left 4 Dead.

reviewText:
I'll try to give an objective review here as well as help

People that might have to buy this game:
- Warhammer universe fans
- multiplayer co-op addicts
-  Left4Dead fans

People who might want to avoid this game:
- People that only play with the ai
- people that prefer to play offline
- you hated left4dead games


Still deciding? Well, here is a list of pros and cons:

Pros:
- Intense, fun gameplay
- Team game where your actions matter (I have had games where I got everyone killed and games where I saved the team repeatedly)
- Excellent character interactions
- Unique characters
- Hordes of enemies to kill
- Game is releasing updates and good DLC at a solid pace

Cons:
- Gameplay can get repetitive
- No Offline play (though honestly not that kind of game)
- Some wonky hitboxes (you will learn to hate the gas rat)
- A bit of a learning curve (combat mechanics take a little practice and learning maps is extremely important)

Is this game for everyone? Hell Naw!

But in all honesty, it is a quality game that is worth the money and then some for its genre. I will end with a note about the devs.  They bring out new content to please the players and they DO fix bugs, but mainly the ones that are player exploits of the game.  I have a suspicion that the odd hit boxes and other small moments in the game that make things more difficult are partly intentional.  This is a game that has Cataclysm as a difficulty level after all.

reviewText:
Crashes constantly, servers constantly have issues, and runs poorly for how the graphics look because the game has no optmization. When the game deigns to function, the spawn AI will likely flip out and auto kill your whole team by spawning every possible hostile event at once. Which you can do literally nothing about except hope it doesn't happen NEXT TIME. The weapons are not balanced in the slightest, most being pointless or outright not functioning properly. Hitboxes need a vast amount of work.

Do not buy this game. Every time a patch note says an issue is fixed, the same issue occurs again and forces another fix. Fat Shark are not truthsworthy devs if you go by their previous products, and Vermintide will likely be abandoned if it hasn't already. From what I have see, the community behind this game is already dwindling despite fervent support early on.

IF, and this is a big IF, the game is patched and still supported a year from now, you can consider a purchase.

reviewText: Right out the gate its safe to say this game borrows many elements from different games. Chivalry esque combat, L4D style groupings and special enemies, D&D esque loot rolling and RPG item tiers. It takes all of these elements and blends them in a unique and enjoyable package. It is highly recommended to play with other people online because the bots are not the best, as expected in a coop game. The levels are unique and satisfying, especially when you collect the special items to increase loot like the Tomes or Skaven Grimoires. The feeling of excitement when you open a chest and find an extra loot die is awesome.

reviewText:
The extinction event that no Games Workshop fan ever thought would happen in the table top genre has arrived on PC for the first time ever. Warhammer: End Times – Vermintide is not just about mindless destruction, mayhem, and violence. It is about the end of the old world in Warhammer Fantasy that we know and love.

Anyone that plays this game is going to die. It’s not a matter of if, but where, when, and how you will die. Everyone is always looking for a way to cross market their ideas, and I think that Fatshark Games nailed it. The incorporation of two genres, Warhammer Fantasy and Left For Dead. It’s been six years since we have had a proper Left For Dead game. I say it’s about time!

30 Second Review

+ Left For Dead and Warhammer fans will both be happy

+ Best melee combat in this style of game to date

+ Finally a game that presents the Skaven in all of their underworld glory

– If you don’t like Left For Dead, you may want to skip this one

– Avoid playing with bots

Click this link to read the full Review:
http://everydaygamers.com/2015/10/23/review-warhammer-end-times-vermintide/

I really like this game and definitely feel it's worth the asking price.

I'm normally not a big co-op kind of guy outside of Left 4 Dead 2 but I enjoy this game. It's like a mixture of Chivalry: Medival Warfare and Left 4 Dead 2 but feels very unique in the way it's all implimented. The characters are fun and I love that they set it in the Warhammer fantasy universe rather than 40K, something I wish I'd see more often. The devs are also active and are listening to the community and always looking for ways to enhance the experience and are adding things down the lines.

It's more than what I was expecting and a really fun game to play with a few friends.

reviewText:
This game has impressed my friends and I overall, but there are some glitches here and there. I would still recommend this to most people. Warhammer is one of my all time favorite franchises and it's very depressing that everyone dies in the end. Litterally everyone.

Pros:    Varying gameplay styles.
Very good matchmaking system.
Pretty graphics.
Good voice acting.
Great storyline.
Vast variety in weapons, hats, and trinkets.
Exciting loot rolling system.
Five playable characters that are very unique.
The Dwarf is comically small and can equip a shield as big as him.
Entertaining quotes with differing personalities.
Difficulty scaling is very good. No huge jumps like in other games.
Cool weapon upgrading.
Cons:    The AI for friendly characters is currently not so great.
There are the bugs that come with new games such as reviving people through walls and rarely getting yourself stuck. There are also a few ways to cheese" the enemy by staying/going to places they can't get to and killing them in complete safety at the loss of self respect.
The "Stranglers" or "Packrats" will grab you from 30 meters away and pull you straight through walls

reviewText:
Take everything about L4D+L4D2, remove zombies, add rats, lots more melee=Game.
A little more appealing/replayable because of the loot factor and getting more items (Kind of D3ish).  Atmosphere is combo of D3+Bloodborne.  May RNGus bring you awesome loot.  And don't get forge - happy and forge actually good items like I did >.<  Also, don't think you can beat cataclysmic after playing a few games on hard + 1 on nightmare.  I'm such an eternal optimist that I think I can do anything.  I died in 25 seconds.  Team hated me.  ;-;

I'm probably like in the top 2% of worst gamers in the world and with a low attention span.  This game keeps my attention and I like the Waywatcher even though she can be kind of cold-hearted.  I think there is a lot of love beneath her tough exterior.  I'm not really fond of the female characters actually.  I think the dwarf needs more love too, but I always mistake him for a rat. LOL.  not good when FF is enabled.

Best thing you can do is be a horrible gamer like me and find someone to carry you through all the rounds and get you awesome loot.  You'll eventually become good after heeding advice of your teammates instead of ignoring it ^_^

reviewText:
Set in the famous Warhammer universe Vermintide is a cooperative adventure game a la L4D: you'll be controlling one of five heroes and face 13 story-driven missions as you try to liberate the city.
While the inspiration is clear Vermintide's stong setting and its melee oriented combat help it create its own identity: as a game is a pretty fun, albeit somewhat forgettable, L4D alternative.

PROS:

-the Warhammer setting is interesting and recreated well

-for the most part the graphics and effects are good, there's also a good variety to the Skaven models

-good soundtrack, the voice acting is also well done with a decent amount of party banter

-the five characters feel different enough and are all fun to use

-the frantic combat, especially during ambushes and when the Skavens swarm, is fun and can get pretty intense

-huge amount of different loot with varied bonuses

-missions sport a good variety

NEUTRAL:

-loot driven gameplay will get old fast for some

-loot randomness is also a very mixed bag, some will be ok with the need for repeated runs trying to collect the best bonuses only to be at the mercy of dice rolls to determine the type and rarity of loot: others'll be frustrated if bad dice rolls mean they can't get good loot for their favourite class

-being a multiplayer game it shines with friends, when joining random groups your enjoyment will depend on how good/ polite they are

CONS:

-some textures and graphics details are below average

-UI feels cluttered and is generally awkward

-lacking tutorial doesn't even cover the basics

-loot driven gameplay coupled with the extremely random dice rolls  and the fact you get nothing if you fail promotes a certain kind of community: don't be surprised if you find people insist on exploiting, speedrunning, kick for simple mistakes or become toxic

-bots are useless making single player a pretty miserable and limited experience

-still buggy, framerate can dip a bit at times, Skaven can sometimes clip through walls or (worse) through party members, enemies might get stuck on walls, certain special enemies can hit you from a weird distance etc...

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=536446385

When I started playing Vermintide my first impressions were lukewarm to be honest, but it slowly grew on me: there's a certain charm in facing tons of enemies (plus their special buddies) while trying to complete objectives and surviving a particularly difficult swarm or special Skaven is satisfying. I had fun playing through the various missions and trying out the different heroes, hence the thumbs up.

But, well, the loot-driven gameplay got boring fast...the fact you're at the mercy of rolls not only for loot quality but also its type means you can end up with good stuff for a character you don't like playing: this happened to me, I like playing a tanky Dwarf but never got anything for him, well not anything tank oriented and at least green....so I played the Wizard due to having a blue staff and green sword drop for it. Sure you can try and repeat missions or fuse items in the forge but, once again, you'll need to be lucky and, considering the huge amount of different items available, it might take quite some time.

In the end trying missions over and over, either on Normal or on Hard (where the community gets way more edgy), got dull and slightly frustrating: there's only so much time I can spend chasing the carrot dangling in front of me.

Vermintide is a decent and quite fun game, having got it for 18$ I'm happy with the 20ish hours I got out of it but all prospective buyers'd consider the loot system and their tolerance for it before hitting the Buy button.

reviewText: I wasn't expecting a (heavily) Left 4 Dead inspired wave-based survival coop game to be this good. The AI is clever and relentless, the melee feels nice and crunchy, the firearms are loud and powerful, and the characters are charming and lovable. That being said, this is a very unforgiving and difficult game. If you don't work as a team 100% of the time, the vermin can and will overwhelm you. So if you're looking for a tough but rewarding experience, then this is a very good title to have in your library. I very much enjoyed the time I've put into it so far and I look forward to the full game.\n\nOh also, ogres can eat my ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
Vermintide was the first game that i bought when it came out. I was on the hype train, and i made a huge mistake.
I got the game at the 2nd beta weekend, almost spent 50 hours in the beta, and i thought it's awsome. Unfortunately i didn't see the bigger picture.

First, the melee combat. It's not bad, it's just mediocore. Almost identical to Skyrim, but you can push. I was expecting something like Chivalry, but no drags, ripostes, nothing, just brainless lmbspam.

Enemies mostly coming from L4d, but it's not a problem, works very well in coop games. The Ai of these creatures, is just meh, cannot say a single positive aspect about it.

Graphics are extremly good in my opinion, but the optimization is beyond bad. it seems none of the options has impact on the fps. For me, the FPS drops are identical on the lowest to medium settings. FPS drops usually followed by a big game slowdown, causes a huge input lag, and driving me crazy.

Maps are well designed, and looking awsome, but there are only 12. (?)

The Networking. This is when the ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan. No hostmigration, No dedicated servers, why ?
Imo, the dedicated servers won't solve the problem. P2P is not as bad as most of the community thinks. I only played l4d in P2P, and it was awsome. My buddies are close to me, so everybody got like 10-30 ms delay, which is fantastic, and everything worked smoothly. However, in Vermintide, even with the same ppl, the delays are insane. The fact that a lot of different rules apply to the host and the guests is bad. When you are playing as a host, the game is great, everything smooth, everything works just as expected. When you are a guest (even with very low ping), first you will start to notice the delays, which is like increasing through the game, and then, the thing that are never happening as a host, like getting hit while pushing, dodge seems a 50 - 50 game as a guest, and a tons of hittrades, which again, doesn't happen when you are the host. Some guy on the forums actually mentioned, that even in lan, the host - guest difference is very noticable, because the game is not synchronizing properly.

There are a millions of bugs that influencing every map you play, just like cannot help your teamate up, because he sank into the textures, getting hit while using potion/nade, sometimes multiplies it, and there are a tons of other bugs that i could mention. That's why i gave a negative review, because they seem to not care about those problems and bugs that i mention above, but they are forcing the console version, and so-called new"

reviewText:
I enjoyed Vermintide at first.  Slowly, my enjoyment was brought down by two things and two things alone

First and foremost, is of course, loot.  The game has loot.  It wants you to get loot.  But it doesn't want to give you loot.  It wants you to run the same map 30 times to get something that might make the game a small bit easier.  For me, I dealt with it, but it certainly impacted my enjoyment of the game.

Second, it doesn't use the AI director that was so intelligent in L4D.  The AI director in Vermintide will randomly decide, you need to die.  In the first 30 seconds in one game, 3 packmasters and an ogre were dropped on us.  We hadn't even fought our first horde yet.  This wasn't a response to use being so good, this was it just suddenly deciding we needed to die.

In another game, we received two specials the entire time.  Only two.  There is no guidance to how it decides to spawn it's forces.  This isn't a DM who wants to see you struggle and prevail.  This is Dewey with a shovel standing over your anthill.  Pray he doesn't smite you randomly.

reviewText:
There is just too much randomness through the entire game for it to be fun in the long run.
The game is fun for the first playthrough of the missions, however once the novelty has worn of you'll be left with grinding a select few of the levels for loot and trust me, you will be grinding.
This is mostly due to how the current loot system works: luck pure and simple. In my personal opinion the loot is just way to random, you either have to be insanely lucky to get the item you want or you'll grind and grind and grind to get the weapon you want.

All games are locally hosted, so you are in the mercy of the hosts connection and if he feels like completing the level. Quite often if the host dies, they'll disconnect leaving you to restart the level. That is ofc if the host migration works, quite often this will crash the game or the migrating will simply fail.

The game has the potential to be great, but falls short. Hopefully the devs will flesh out the gameplay, either that or the game will be deader than Evolve within 3months.

reviewText:
Vermintide is a fantastic game. When all you need is some visceral, powerful violence, this game delivers fully. This game offers a Left 4 Dead type of on-the-move, hoard based gameplay with a gritty melee combat, a looting and equipment system, 13 maps and 5 difficulty settings, 5 classes, and tons of loot to find. Vermintide is a well-crafted game with a combat system that keeps you coming back, bloodthirsty for more rats to kill.

But I can hardly recommend it.

While the combat system is competent, though iterative, the combat alone does not carry the game. This game suffers from a myriad of problems that really hamper it and obstruct your enjoyment of the game.

First off, optimization. It's awful. To save space, I'll at least say I'm running a mid to high range system with an AMD R9 280x, and even on the absolute LOWEST setting, I regularly experience sub-30 FPS. Looking on Reddit and the forums, many others suffer from performance issues, especially other AMD users. This alone gives me enough reason to not recommend the game - to push the game out so quickly out of early access when it could hardly play is a bit of a disgrace. But it doesn't end there.

Second, the loot system. It is not uncommon to play for dozens of hours and not get a single new weapon for your main class. You get one piece of gear per game, excluding bonuses, and you must roll for a random piece of loot. The issue that comes with this system is while I can be tolerant of rolling for rarity, the type of equipment you get is entirely independent of the class that you're currently playing. Essentially, morely likely than not, you can expect to get equipment completely useless to you, and it is not uncommon to never get a specific type of equipment that you're looking for for hours on end. While the loot system is a healthy addition to a L4D formula, it's hampered by how flawed and frustrating it could prove to be.

Third, hosting. This game makes the same mistake that Payday 2 did - making the game entirely dependent on the connection of the host. Should the host disconnect, the whole game ends. Game crashes because,  y'know, the game was rushed out and all of the major bugs weren't wiped out? Too bad. Somebody's trolling the entirely team and decides to end the game moments before you escape? That's it for you. At least Warframe gave you a chance with host migration, but this game? Not even the slightest. Irritating doesn't even begin to describe this issue.

Fourth, uninspired loot. As if it wasn't bad enough that looting ends up being a massive pain and an unrewarding experience, the rarity and the auments that the weapons could come with are hardly exciting. Remember Diablo 3 on release? Remember how meaningless the gear you find were? Well, this game suffers from the same problem. Augments are often uninspired, boring passives that barely distinguish a rare weapon from a regular common one. 20% to not use stamina when pushing? 5% chance on hit to have a 30% increase in attack speed for 5 seconds? I can barely contain my excitement. Even Blizzard realized how unrewarding their own loot system was before they changed it - I could only hope  that Fatshark realizes the same.

Well, there you have it. This game is barely a good enough romp in the park if you just want a hoard-based, stabbing simulator, but all of these problems present make it unworthy of a full-price purchase. Performance issues aside, the other issues I've listed make this game too frustrating of an experience to appreciate outside of a cheap thrill. My only hope is that these issues be resolved soon, and I will happily change my review to a positive, because for what it's worth, it is a fun game - it just pains me to see all of these issues getting in its way.

EDIT: The loot system since writing this review has been changed. You now have an option of which loot to craft using unwanted loot through a new system available at the inn. However, this does not preclude the issue of boring, uninteresting loot. Even with the advent of red rarity loot, the augments and abilities are STILL dull and uninspired. There is almost literally no difference between an orange and a red weapon aside from their color. And honestly? There was barely a difference between orange and white weapons to begin with.

reviewText:
Well i have mixed feelings about this game so read that review instead of that nice thumb up.
+Looks great.
+A horde game in wich you are not killing zombies, that is a nice change.
+Weapon variety.
+The melee combat is satisfying.
+Interaction between characters, they keep talking to each other wich is fun from time to time.

-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Ai, i mean worse than l4d... wich already had the worse Ai i knew of.
-Loot system that would make diable 3 rng drop seems fair in comparison.
-Lack of optimization.
-Extremly repetitve.
-Random ennemy encounters, seems good on paper, now, let us be serious for 5seconds, because of that you will walk through a level on hard like it was easy and the next time you will get rekt in 5 sec because the game decided that a rat ogre, followed by a stormvermin patrol, followed by two hordes was a good idea.

I would recommend this game, it is interesting enough to keep you going a couple of hours but in its current state that is pretty much all there is to it, if they fix the awfull loot system, the overall exagerated randomness, and optimize the game a bit it could be the next huge coop hit, as of now it is not, it is infuriating most of the time in such a  way that you might not play it often, but it is definately worth a buy just because it is different than l4d, kf and such. It is a solid 6\10 that could become a 9\10 if they put a lot of effort into it.

reviewText:
TL;DRThe loot system is horrifyingly bad and the special rats feel a bit out of place, but otherwise the game is incredibly fun. You'll love this game if you like at least 2 of the following: Left 4 Dead, fun melee combat, satisfying decapitation, or the thrill of turning garbage loot into slightly less bad loot until you get the really special and amazing stuff.

===

Okay lemme get the one ridiculous, stupid, and enragingly awful feature out of the way: the loot system. It sucks - really, really badly. I don't think it is humanly possible to devise something that should be awesome and rewarding in a way that could be any worse than the loot system in this game. It really is very bad.

The way it works is you are given 7 dice. These are not dice that have numbers on them; they either increase a point on your loot, or they don't (so, in other words, they have either a 0 or a 1). Normally, you have 7 dice that have a 2 in 6 chance of landing on the 1. However, there are 3 types of dice that you can find to replace some of the normal dice.

You can find loot dice" by exploring the maps
date: but the presence of these is totally random; they have a 3 in 6 chance of landing on the 1. Or
recommended: you can find hidden tomes that provide a 4 in 6 chance; these take up the health slot in-game while you're carrying them
hoursPlayed: so one person has to neglect any health potions or health kits while carrying the tome. Finally
voteText: you can find grimoires that always roll a 1. However
helpfulPercent: these take up a potion slot (potions can be used to get either temporary strength or speed
votesHelpful: and neither are incredibly useful) but more importantly they take away 30% of your entire team's health.\n\nThere are usually about 3 tomes and 2 grimoires in every map; that means that if you have found them all (they are somewhat hidden) and you are carrying them all
votesTotal: by the end of the map you are missing 3 potential health items you could carry and your entire team's max health has fallen to 40% of what it is normally.\n\nAt the end of the level
votesFunny: the dice are rolled and your total is added up. The number of dice that landed favorably get you to better

reviewText:
Few games if any in recent times have captured the grim, dank and mostly misserable world of warhammer: fantasy. Before age of sigmar buggered the franchise like an ogre on cataclysm, we had a world of amazing dark fantasy. The aesthetic and presentation is wonderful for me, i like the loot system, it keeps the game interesting. Getting loot for other heroes can be annoying but encourages playing multiple roles instead of a singular focus. The range of weapons and styles is great. My only issues stem from engine troubles like how skaven seemed to be at times hitting far beyond the weapons they carry or through walls. Stab through blocks or worse just clipping  through walls behind your team and dealing that ever so annoying rear stab.

Even with such issues, that cannot be understated. The detail and passion that has gone into this game is amazing. Hopefully dlc/ flc will expand the heroes and levels with maybe a few tweaks to the loot for good measure. Now who fancies Horn Of Magnus again, feeling abit lucky this time.

reviewText:
Great Game, lots of content and things to do. It draws a lot of inspiration from fellow great games, all while developing its own personality and cornerstones of what a great game should be.
The loot progression is fair and rewarding, and does not promote competetiveness. In the many lobbies I have been in, the community has constantly fostered teamwork that is not seen in many other cooperative games, which allows for a more immersive and enjoyable experience.
The difficulty is challenging but rewarding, and the various settings extend the games lifespan in a meaningful way. Changin things like base damage is all well and fine, but the addition of more storm vermin to a patrol and other such tweaks really change the way the game plays as you progress in the difficulty settings.
Before this game, I had never heard of the developers. But from the road mapping of additional content, to the small details in things like paintings that add a nice touch of immersion, to the way they tackle bugs and treat their customer base with care, I would be more than willing to purchase future games with the same roadmapping.
Overall, there are many warhammer games out there, but this is definitely a game to pick up for the reasonable $33 (canadian).
