reviewText: If you like the Warhammer universe and don't mind playing an absolute Left 4 Dead rip-off, this is a pretty good game. Vermintide adds a bit of depth to characters by means of a tavern where players can forge weapons, pray to upgrade their items and manage the inventory. It's a repetitive experience, with barely 13 co-op missions, but thanks to character development, a satisfying combat system, some challenging difficulty levels and a load of nerve-wrecking rat ogres it certainly manages to stay fresh. It gets better with voice chat and some friends.\n\nAnd when I say it's a Left 4 Dead rip-off, I mean it: after dying, characters appear trapped a bit further away, even with a red halo around them... So expect that and chances are WETV will surprise you positively. :)

reviewText:
A game that follows the Left 4 Dead layout, set in the Warhammer Fantasy: End Times universe/timeline.
The game plays well, the melee combat is genuinely fun, as I'd hope it would be. Given that the game is mostly melee based.
The game is pretty much a more open Left 4 Dead with Skaven instead of zombies, and Fatshark have been pretty open about their paying homage to Left 4 Dead. This I find to be a good thing, over all. Not very many games emulate the Left 4 Dead layout, so its not like a tired concept of anything.
Each class plays differently and fun, and I can't say much else aside from 'I really liked this game and you should play it.'

reviewText:
Vermintide is very fun so far.
Matchmaking is easy to work out and you often get a competent player.
I would definitely recommend VT to anyone who's played and loved LFD and LFD2, and loves the Warhammer world.

8/10 for online play.
6/10 for offline play.

Pros:
13 maps to keep you going.
Plenty of loot that requires skill and a bit of RNG to acquire.
Playing with friends is tons of fun.
Has tons of potential if new game modes, maps, characters, loot, and enemies are added.
Tons of replayability, especially with friends.

Cons:
Bots are currently terrible and not viable for solo play.
If there's no-one online to play with, tough luck.
RNG can take it's toll quickly if you're used to specific or guaranteed loot drops.
Requires a high level of skill to survive. You must keep your head on a swivel.

reviewText:
Let me start with Vermintide is surprisingly fun to play. Before entering the game, I thought it would just be a Left 4 Dead rip-off. And yes, it’s not hard to tell the fundamental idea of the game is based on L4D. But Vermintide extend itself by offering players a different online co-op experiences. That is to say, a lot of features you wished L4D could’ve done better, you might find them in this game.
Here are some examples

- Different characters to choose, each has unique weapons and skills for players to pick.
- Unlockable content and leveling system, which keeps player in the game.
- It’s not another zombie game, you kill rats instead.
- No friendly damage.
- While in the combat, blocking actually take thinking.
- Most of the maps are well-designed.

You might encounter some bugs while playing, but the overall gaming experience is pretty smooth.
I hope the developers are willing to keep the game updated more often.

reviewText:
I have been following this game since it was showcased for the first time. And now that I finished the campaign (at least in normal), I think I can offer some good impressions.

Vermintide offers a Left 4 Dead gameplay style in the Warhammer Fantasy setting, which is absolutely cool, because you get to go melee on waves and waves of skavens and that's fun.
Doing it on your own is not thaaaat fun, it is enjoyable if you wanted the game as bad as I did, so try at least to be in league with another friend, or well, try your luck in the online lobbies.

The game offers 5 playable characters, each with their own set of weapons. Leveling up each character just unlocks equipment space for trinkets.
At the end of each level you get to roll some dices, which determine a piece of random loot that you get (also, loot comes with different types of rarity).
If you crank up the game's difficulty, the best items you can get at the end of the level.
Spread in the most important levels there are some loot dices and tomes and grimoires, items that will generate better loot dice for the after level roll, but that will cost you inventory space and health.

The game itself is kinda challenging, if you have played L4D you will know that you have to keep moving, standing in a single point will not help you, skavens will eventually overrun you.
As it happens with L4D, there are some special skavens that spawn across the levels and that will pester you while you travel across the maps. You have the rat ogre (tank), the globadier (spitter), the gutter runner (hunter), the pack master (smoker), the rattling gunner (armored rat with a huge gun) and the stormskaven (packs of armored skavens).
If you played L4D, the first ones will be easily recognizable.

In terms of graphics, the games looks really nice, even when I got to turn some options down due to the volume of skavens present in the screen.
As far as I have played, I had no problems in connecting with a friend to play, and we were able to enjoy the campaign in normal difficulty.
Taking into account that there are some story missions and some side missions, the game still feels rather short in those terms, but playing each level in higher difficulties is what will make your experience last longer.
If you are here looking for an immersive story, I'm affraid this is not your game. If you like to bludgeon rat men for hours searching for loot and stuff at higher difficulties again and again and again, this is what you need.

The developers should seriously consider releasing some sort of expansion packs with more missions like L4D, or a mode where you can play as Skaven in a match vs the Heroes.

reviewText:
Briefly: Left 4 Dead in Warhammer Fantasy setting.

Things you need to like in order to enjoy Vermintide:
First person shooter
Multiplayer game only (cooperative)
Fast paced gameplay
Personally, I like the setting, enjoyed L4D long time ago and have friends who also play the game. So, for me the game was an obvious pick. I love it. Special mentions to awesome audio and quality character design. There are still bugs (even game breaking ones) but mostly the experience is really good. Nice amount of content, loot system and challenging difficulty settings set the bar for replyability high.

Litte wishlist, in case some devs browse through these comments
If host disconnects/crashes, the progress is lost. Would be nice if the host changed dynamically to another player.
Some missions could have more pacing between constant action. I enjoy fast paced gameplay but the silent moments make the action feel even more fierce.  Especially the one area missions, like Well Watch and Black Powder would benefit from this.
Randomize tome and grimoire locations. Now there is very little reasons to explore once the players know the locations.
More features like Stormvermins! Anything that breaks the normal action cycle of the game would be greatly welcome.

reviewText: I've never been into coop horde games until now. I've played left 4 dead and some others but it was nothing more than playing with friends on split screen. Now I have 140 hours spent in vermintide and I am completely into it. I even gave a break to my main mmo so I can keep making skaven cry. I am in love with warhammer fantasy roleplay setting and I can say without hesitation that in here its done god damn right. Great game to play solo and join random players and even greater if you have steady team. Gear progression and earning it makes it even better and satisfaying. It's not easy when you play trough your first runs and learn maps but after you earn enough experience and knowledge you can jump into nightmare / cataclysm experience which is real essence of vermintide and keeps you busy. Developers also did perfect job with voice acting and gave each character different, far from plane personalities. Even now when I've completed most maps on cataclysm, I still want to play it daily for many hours. Respect to developers and people behind it, keep doing great job and add more dlcs and expansions as soon as possible.

The loot and different character classes allow you to customize how your character plays, and that means its fairly easy to find a niche you fit into.\n\nIts worth the full price, but if you can get this on sale, do yourself a favor and grab a couple copies for you and a friend, and start having yourself a blast.  This one really surprised me with just how naturally enjoyable it is, from the first playthrough to the hundredth.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: A good game ruined by a toxic community surprise surprise. Seriously though it's a great game with plenty of replay value, 5 classes with different playstyles make it interesting, and theres enough levels to playthrough. only thing I don't like is you can't play the higher difficultys from the begining (inb4 someone comments saying thats not how it supposed to be played well all I can say is f*ck off?) I didn't buy this game to be told what to do, so that brings me to my main complaint about this game. The community is so toxic, when I first started the game I went to play on hard difficulty I was getting all keyboard warrior'd at, but we completed it anyway at level 0 so it's not impossible. you then have people leaving, complaining at you constantly or mic spaming because they are incompetent fools, for getting downed or dying or even worse going ahead alone. If you do decide to buy this game try looking on the forums to team up with people or convince some friends to buy it as well.

reviewText:
Great Game, lots of content and things to do. It draws a lot of inspiration from fellow great games, all while developing its own personality and cornerstones of what a great game should be.
The loot progression is fair and rewarding, and does not promote competetiveness. In the many lobbies I have been in, the community has constantly fostered teamwork that is not seen in many other cooperative games, which allows for a more immersive and enjoyable experience.
The difficulty is challenging but rewarding, and the various settings extend the games lifespan in a meaningful way. Changin things like base damage is all well and fine, but the addition of more storm vermin to a patrol and other such tweaks really change the way the game plays as you progress in the difficulty settings.
Before this game, I had never heard of the developers. But from the road mapping of additional content, to the small details in things like paintings that add a nice touch of immersion, to the way they tackle bugs and treat their customer base with care, I would be more than willing to purchase future games with the same roadmapping.
Overall, there are many warhammer games out there, but this is definitely a game to pick up for the reasonable $33 (canadian).

reviewText:
Never knew I could have so much fun killing rats.

Decent graphics and voice overs.

Great characters weapons and mechanics.

Level design and maps are pretty basic.

RPG aspects are kind of cool gives you a little room to adjust to your play style. And who don’t like loots?
The A I Bots suck as  you would expect them too.

And of course its great fun when you get a good group of people or when you’re playing with friends. But frustrating when you get a group of asshats.

Not a masterpiece but all in all it’s worth the price and worth the time if you enjoy co-op FPS  hack n slash games You will find many hours of entertainment in the slaughter of vermin.

However, reguardless of quality you can accomplish anything as this is far more a game of skill than one of trinket aquisition. As long as you are not careless, by Sigmar, you will find victory against the Vermintide.

reviewText: Great game.  The good parts of L4D, with an emphasis on melee combat, and tough-but-fair mechanics.  The loot system provides progression across multiple sessions, and allows you to tweak your playstyle.  Also, great voice acting - intentionally over-the-top in the manner of proper Warhammer characters.\n\nHighly recommend, with no reservations.

reviewText: The recent influx of negative reviews aren’t doing the game any justice. I’ve yet to observe performance issues when playing the game on my fairly outdated PC and nor have I witnessed any experience-crippling bugs so far, but I am aware the Fatshark team are actively on top of this for those that have.\nThis game is the furthest thing from my preferred genre but despite this, I am thoroughly enjoying the game even with my very little knowledge of the Warhammer universe and I urge any negative-thinkers who have played for less than a couple of hours to stick at it - you may be pleasantly surprised! The squelching heard as your weapon penetrates a horde of Skaven is really quite therapeutic and that alone is worth the money imo.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Excerpt of review originally published on Select Start Media.

There’s a game on Steam called Bad Rats. For the longest time, Bad Rats was considered one of the worst games of all time. People would buy it as gifts for their friends as a joke–it became a point of pride to actually not have the game in your library. All this, of course, has been completely outshadowed by the mountains of tripe now available on the storefront thanks to Steam Greenlight, but it’s important to remember the legacy of Bad Rats. It was, however, also among the best rat related games on Steam. Rodent fans really didn’t have much to choose from. That changed in late October, when the Swedish developers Fatshark (War of the Roses, War of the Vikings, Krater) released their most recent game, Warhammer: End Times – Vermintide. Despite having one too many subtitles, Vermintide has stolen my heart as maybe my favourite title when I’m in the mood for co-operative shenanigans.

The specials are almost straight from Left 4 Dead 2, with a few fresh ones and some alterations to the classics...The main difference from Left 4 Dead 2–I mean, apart from the whole Warhammer thing–is the introduction of different player classes and persistent inventories, giving the game a sort of RPG feel to it when you’ve played it for an extended period of time. At the end of each (successful) mission, you’ll gain experience and get a chance to roll some dice, the number of which depends on your difficulty level and any “loot dice” you’ve picked up as you were killing Skaven. The outcome of the dice roll determines the quality and type of the loot you’re given for completing the mission.

I could sit here and talk about my own experiences with Vermintide for hours–how, after losing three of my party members and sitting on like 2% health I fluked a rescue of our Waywatcher, and the two of us held off the oncoming horde to revive our two downed party members and complete the mission. Oh, or the time that my entire party got wiped out within about 30 seconds of starting the Black Powder mission by a totally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t selection of Special Skaven spawns at exactly the same time. At the end of it all, I probably could’ve gotten away with saying what everyone else is saying: Vermintide is an RPG-esque Left 4 Dead successor set in the Warhammer universe with Skaven instead of zombies, and it’s absolutely fantastic–if any of those things tickle your fancy, then you must play it. While it may have rats, and they may be bad, please don’t get it confused with Bad Rats.

reviewText:
I recommend this game for half off. There doesent seem to be enough content to justify a 30 dollar title, is it fun? Yes. Is the loot system as screwy as people say? I think its weird, but its fine in my eyes. I got 5 Sword and Averland shields in a row, so I wasent estatic but I like the difficulty of it, it makes it more worthwhile in replayability.

In regards to replayability I dont think there is any, Tomes seem to be in the same places, no change of route, chests tend to always be in the same location but the loot of whats in it or where is changed. Would I buy this game for the 32.99 price tag? No, its not even remotely worth that, escpecially without mods. On to my next thing.

No mods, and they arent sure if there will be mods. I love the game but it would be awesome to be able to have even just cosmetic mods, mods for player made maps, weapons, loot. It made L4D worth the price tag today. Without them it makes a game thats very fun for a romp, a month thing.

I hate to say these things as I support these devs, I like how they made the dlc playable if with someone who owns it. The game deserved a positive review, but I can only say its positive for the right price. Its not 32.99, for the full game its (In Canada) 46.28, for the base game, the collectors edition with even more paywal content brings it up higher. You can say the games only 19.79 on sale, but thats not true. A games price is every piece of DLC together, without DLC its not a full game. I would pay 30 for this happily, all in all future dlc. There is no story and the only thing that changes is the people you play with and the weapons you choose.

I will buy this game, Im glad it went on a free weekend because I got to try it and realize I like it. Few annoying bugs in regards to finishing a map on the hardest difficulty and it crashing at the end when I got a grimoire and tomes and loot dice so I lost out on the roll.... But still good.

reviewText: Do you enjoy CoD:Zombies? Do you enjoy Left 4 Dead? Do you enjoy Killing Floor? Are you tired of zombies? Then Vermintide is the game for you! Replace zombies with feral angry rat men with chain guns and you've got this game. You are not a one man army, you are one of 5 characters with a very specialized purpose. That doesn't mean you can't play you're way, the ranger can swing a 2handed axe just as well as he can hold a shield, the bright wizard can swing her fiery sword just as well as throw a fireball. This game gets intense and remains entertaining. Oh and did I mention it has loot?

reviewText:
Product received for free

Had it on a free weekend. Worth £10, but only if you have a group of people to play with. For me this is merely a ray of light signalling that one day Hellraid may be released, and may actually be good.

Maps are well designed, with some very fun activities to do in each of them. The unlockables add to the replayability, whilst the range of characters caters to all playstyles. Sadly the actual premise of the melee combat tends to lean towards the clunky side, more often than not sending your character into a frantic spinning of hammers and swords to simply kill a small group of rats. They could have added some mount and blade style depth, but instead this is much more of an arcade style coop game to blaze through with some mates.

The colours in the game are ultimately very bland, though this is obviously intentionally done so to compliment the aesthetic archaic time the game is set in.


Not worth full price, but definitely worth a shot if you are in dire need of some melee fun. I also suggest you take a look at the new fps spacehulk game set in the Warhammer universe if you are interested in Vermintide.

reviewText: An excellent adaptation of the Warhammer end times franchise. It plays like left 4 dead but with a significant focus on melee. The enemies are cleverly designed and the AI system is very similar to L4D. The characters are well written with good voice acting. The character selection choices are excellent and the weapons not only look cool and right out of the Warhammer codex, but they also feel very visceral when used in combat. 5 stars.

reviewText: the best game ive ever seen!!!\n
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
You ever thought about how the world is going to end? Nuclear war, giant meteor, zombie apocalypse?
Well as it turns out, it’s rats! Big, giant, ugly rats… with mini-guns.
You and your group of misfits are caught right in the middle of it and the only option is to work together, decapitate rats and do whatever the local pub’s landlord tells you to do.

Vermintide is a lot of fun. The combat system is fluid and works well in 1st person. With a hack and slash I personally favour 3rd person mode but is helped by game options that can tweak your field of view. You don’t need to hit the enemy right in the middle of your crosshair, instead it simulates well the force and range of a mighty slash and thrust with your weapon of choice.

The combat is fast paced and often manic when pushing back hordes (and I do mean hordes) of stinky sewer rats. Team work is key and each character has their unique playstyle and abilities to help and counter certain enemies or situations.
There’s no real backstory for the characters at the start of the game (although a google search will find great backstories) but through hilarious and well written and voice acted interactions during the game, you start to see who these people are and how they ended up in the sewer storm that is the city of Ubersreik.

There is a nice crafting and loot system for you to personalise and upgrade your warriors, including new blades and blunderbuss’ or a new hat with an even bigger feather! Trust me, in the game the big feather makes sense.

The enemies are also well rounded and varied, from slave rats with daggers, to mini-gun wielding psycho rats and even giant rat ogres! The game system also slightly randomises encounters, so when you replay a level (which you will) don’t expect it to happen the way it did before.

The game is tough, it’s the end of the world after all and there are no auto saves or checkpoints during missions, meaning if you fail, it’s right back to the start like the good old gaming days of old! The missions themselves aren’t long but you will probably make several attempts before actually completing one. Checkpoints would be a nice addition as you will fail a few times and going back to the beginning does start to create level fatigue. I tend to dip in and out of Vermintide for small gaming sessions with friends, rather than a whole weekend of rat-slaying chaos!

Ultimately, this is a multiplayer game with a 4 human/dwarf/elf/wizard/crazy person team. That’s not to say you can’t play on your own, the AI isn’t bad although obviously it’s not as good (or sometimes as bad) as human players. The ability for players to hot join games is great, optional feature.

Although I’ve played solo, the game really shines when I’m playing with friends. Holding your ground, screams of panic, calling for help and cursing as you run crying from a rat ogre!

If you want a fun, manic and wonderfully detailed world with great characters to run around in with friends, then Vermintide is for you.

reviewText:
It's Left4Dead and Warhammer Fantasy together. That's pretty much all you need to know about it. If you like either of those IPs and/or have friends to play with, this is a lot of fun. If you don't like either of those and have no one to play with, this probably isn't the game for you. The game has already led to many memorable and frenetic moments for my friends and me. It was obviously meant to be played cooperatively, so if you plan on playing alone you'd be missing out on a lot of what it has to offer.

A lot of common complaints I saw in other reviews I can't really comment on or don't agree with because:

- bad matchmaking (I have people I play with, and any empty slots get filled pretty regularly)
- bugs (a few, but none that were game breaking. Who knows, that could change)
- repetitive (maybe, but it would be repetitive in the way L4D or any other hack-n-slash is repetitive)
- grindy for items (Not really. Right off the bat you have way, way more diversity in potential gameplay styles through the classes, and after 7 hrs I've already gathered a bunch of functionally different weapons for each class. If you feel compelled to own all things immediately, then yes, I can see how this might seem grindy.)

To be fair I got this on sale for $18, you'll have to decide for yourself how much a co-op slash-em-up L4D is worth to you. With that in mind I'm happy with my purchase, and look forward to many nights shouting profanities at virtual rat-men as I cave in their heads with a giant hammer.

reviewText: Played during the free weekend of 5/27-5/30. Had a great time on it. Character classes are varied and the environments are fantastic, scenarios are diverse and challenging (even on Easy my team got wiped out in one). I always wanted to play Mordheim as a kid, but never had the opportunity. This seems to be the basis for Vermintide, and it absolutely hits the mark, matching how I envisioned it would be.\n\nWhen I have the funds, I plan to pick this up.

reviewText:
Vermintide is a great game even with random people you don't know, and much better with friends. The servers (in EU) have always had enough people playing, when I've checked so the online community is going strong. Most people also have acted like decent people.

There are some bugs, like enemies sometimes hitting through walls, and today an elf got stuck inside the ground. But for the most part Vermintide works just fine.

So I recommend you buy it now in case you're interested. It's one of the good Warhammer Fantasy computer games out there. The level design is pretty nice too.

Hopefully they make new classes and new enemies eventually, but so far the old ones have been good enoug,

reviewText:
A tentative recommendation.

The horde mode genre has finally been given a breath of life. A breath that, although familiar, is still a pleasant scent. The gameplay is solid, melee combat feels great, ranged combat is of your standard fare, and the loot system keeps you hungering for more (although it will irritate you).

The only reason I tentatively recommend this is because if you play solo, it probably won't hold your attention for nearly as long as if you were playing with a group of 3 other friends. That is....if you have any.

8/10 Game needs a bit more content.

Really good game, but this one has some very critical flawes in it.
1. loot system (is not rewarding your class, but is completely random.)
2. no explanations (anywhere and about anything, unless you count basic tutorial stuff.)
3. really weird difficulty scaling (you can clear levels solo hard more easily than you could with 4 players on normal.)

at least those are my opinions, agree or disagree. It's your call to believe me or just do as I love to do. Try it out  and then judge it with your own experience.

reviewText:
This game is a pearl. You need to have two or three friends to play with and you'll have lot of fun.
Some people have issues with FPS, or whatever, but I have none and I don't play on an aw<esome computer. However the game is fun, challenging as hell! And it's feel good for once to have a game where you can't just know perfectly the map and roll over everything and simply play as un buldozer to get loot!

The only bad point I have is the random people you can play with, a low level can join you on hard missions and screw up everything because they just play solo and don't think as a team. Donc stay behind tanks, don't cover you and just hope to get the best kill ration at the end.

reviewText:
Heya Fatshark and co,

Tis I, Scud from the OCC forums. I had the pleasure of bumping into one of your powers-that-be (THE power..?) and age ago.

Just wanted to say - good job! You've successfully critically analysed the mechanics from a game that's delieverd an entertaining play experience (L4D) and improved upon it. Love it!

To you folks out there in gaming land, this is what you want - smart developers that refine and improve, providing you with ever better gaming experiences. It's like SCIENCE!

So, what do we have? Left 4 Dead, framed with a Warhammer context, and then some.

What's been added?

- gambling/unlock system, itemisation and customisation. In the good way, as oppossed to the ever popular 'milk your fanbase's playtime by hiding the goodies behind a time wall'. The core experience is delievered from the start, the rest is simply tinkering things to suit your playstyle.

- focus on melee. Blocking is an important part of play. Not everyone needs to get up close and personal and a shield isn't required to succeed, but oh yes does it help. If you were the type to pick up the fireaxe in L4D, damn everything else, and boldy take point, slaughtering all the deadheads that dared oppossed you, then you're gonna love this game.

- better signalling. You can tag specials for your team mates, helping you cooridinate your efforts. Likewise, the sound effects triggered before a special enemy attacks are clear and add to the atmosphere.

- which brings me to the specials. We've basically got the smoker (pack master), hunter (assassin), spitter (poisonwind globadier.. with less floor-splash, more in-your-face gas distortion and the tendency to self destruct on death), and tanks (rat ogres). Thankfully there's no jockey but we do get the awesome Storm Vermin, who have a habit of clumping up and giving you grief, thanks to their armour.

- Warhammer. Grimdark. Dirt. Rats. Cracks. Stains. It's all there. If you've ever wanted to virtually sniff the docks of an Imperial city, or stain your boots in its fetid sewers, or perhaps simply chill in a gloomy tavern with a very ugly bar tenders, then this is the game for you.

What are we missing?

- Sadly, we can't play as the Skaven.

- There's a crippling shortage of rednecks.

- The colour palette seems washed out, though I figure this is more to do with the confusing Gamma settings instructions. Personally, I wacked things down till they were gloomy and never could find the second symbol...


TL:DR

4 players. Ideally friends. Fighting hordes of ratmen. With axes, swords, fire, guns and bow. In a lavish gothic-fantasy setting.

Good fun. Bring friends!

reviewText: One of the most addictive and yes actually fun games in the steam catalog. A must have for anyone. This redefines the co-op genre and will be looked back upon as the gold standard of co-op experiance. It takes obvious ques from games like LFD/LFD2 and Killing Floor yet towers above both as the genre defining example. The melee combat is superb (much like Skyrim but much more polished and meaty). The graphic fidelty is something to behold and they nail the gritty unforgiving Warhammer fantasy setting. The difficulty is set high even on normal but the introduction of loot drops and random dynamic enemy/chest spawns makes every game feel fresh and new. (Spoiler) You will be grinding for quite some time to get the perfect Weapons for your playstyles for each class.

reviewText:
Im a 40k fan so when I hearx about this game it didnt register on my radar. However, I dont think I have ever enjoyed a compulsive buy as much as I have this game. Be warned, its a LFD clone to the T, but I couldnt care less and im glad it is in many ways.

If you have played LFD1-2 than you will recognize the style of gameplay. Vermintide adds alot of depth by making the levels much more interactive and adding a great loot system with all types of upgrades and sidegrades. The reward system is unique as well and adds a great element to the game; do you want to risk not being able to finish the level or do you want to go for the potential for more loot? Everything about it makes the levels much more replayable than either LFD games.

The combat is great, its much more dynamic than I thought it would be. You wont be successfull in melee fighting by blindly clicking the mouse button. When 50-100 rat warriors are bearing down on you, you have to be able to think and position yourself quick or your going to get wiped out.

All in all, you dont have to be a fan of Warhammer to enjoy this game but if you are it makes it that much sweeter. I highly recommend this game for a fun game to play with feidnds.

One thing that's missing is VS mode PVP like L4D had the bots do okay but humans could do better. Over all though I think the fun factor is there and they are going to be doing DLCs so it should be interesting to see what they add.

reviewText:
Played 2hrs and was immediately and absolutely hooked. After 10hrs, I cannot recommend this game enough. If you like Warhammer at all, or if you had some fun with L4D, get Vermintide. Hell, even if you didn't, and just like co-op games, get it. Just get it. It's amazing. Granted, there are bugs, and issues, but no game is without its share of those, especially in the first year its released.

Content at this point looks very polished, playing through the same levels again and again does not get old, simply due to the fact that the maps are fairly lengthy, and every time you play it, things are different. Not only do spawns change, but the things that you end up fighting can change too.
Melee combat feels quite natural, takes minimal effort to get used to. Ranged combat is a little more challenging but very rewarding. Survival relies more on positioning and quick thinking, as well as staying together and working as a team, which is paramount to victory.
The loot system keeps me coming back for more, and gives me incentive to continue playing. Others might not like it, I'm sure, but the best weapons in the game aren't *that* much better than some of the weapons I own only 10hrs in, which aren't *that* much better than the tier below it, and so on.
And then there's the characters. Each one has so many lines of dialogue that relate to very specific scenarios, or even subtle interactions with other characters. Each voice actor is perfect for their character.

TL;DR - Muy bueno. 10/10 best pest control simulator or some other crappy joke who cares the game's great and I honestly think it's the best game of 2015. Yes, better than Fallout 4. Come at me.

reviewText:
Simpleton's Guide to Vermintide:
1. Choose character.
2. Choose another character since your favourite was taken.
3. Beat rats.
4. Beat more rats.
5. Beat even more rats plus specials rats that still need to be beaten.
6. Encounter ogre, luls ensure.
7. If team isn't wiped, continue on and beat rats.
8. Reach final zone, beat rats.
9. Reach escape vehicle or don't, but still beat rats.
10. See what RNG gives you, and get shafted by trash.
11. Repeat steps 1-10 until results differ, if rash persists call your doctor; He'll prescribe higher difficulties.
12. Get ♥♥♥ handed to yourself by beefier rats and lose on higher difficulty.
13. Get the feel of it, and beat rats.

reviewText:
Too put it blanky Vermintide is a reskinned L4D with inventory. And while it has some issues, I would recommend you get it during sale.

Pros:
- While it is clearly modeled after L4D, it does give it a fresh new set of paint, and doesn't seem all that similar.
- The characters are well designed, voice acting is great and enemies' overall design looks pretty stellar
- The hack and slash first person nature complements the setting very well.
- Very atmospheric, levels are quite long and thought out.
- Has an interactive customization of loadouts and forging system, which help give the player an identity.
- Difficulty setting which restricts players from playing above hard, forcing them to prove their skill to play.
- Has bots capability and host migration now, replacing the annoying Peer-to-peer system where all players are kicked if the host leaves.
- Has a captivating story instead of L4D's generic zombie invasion" plot.
- Requires Co-operative gameplay to work
date:
punishing stragglers and loners.

Cons

- Enemies are hard to destinguish from players due to the lack of borders around them constantly
recommended: also the general dingyness of it makes it difficult too\n- Ranged weapons are underpowered and have limited ammunition
hoursPlayed: making the Mage much easier to play as
voteText:
since her ammo is unlimited and splash damage fire is generally more reliable.
- Optimization issues.
- Crafting system is quite haphazard and awkward to work with.
- Inventory items are only collected after beating a mission
helpfulPercent: making grinding inevitable.\n- As with many games
votesHelpful:
connectivity issues are amok and you'll lag like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ if your ping sucks.
- No workshop or mods.
- Bots are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.
- Some of the objectives are dauntingly repetitive

votesFunny: relying on your teammates to help you really sucks if you're playing with non-cooperative teammates.\n- Incredibily slidy movement
commentsCount: combat can sometimes be clunky.\n- No voice radial option
column16: making communication purely text based.\n- Not much indication in terms of audio or visual cues as to when your teammates are in peril or an enemy is close.\n- The game doesn't seem to aid you at all in terms of finding weapons. You'll constantly find medical equipment during the start while your health is optimum

reviewText: What literally everyone else has said, it's like Left 4 Dead but Warhammer themed, right down to the core just like the other game. Personally I think this is very well executed. Everything from level design, narration, voice acting, and to model design are all really really good. My only complaint right from the 1 match I got to play is the AI still need a bit of work, as well as network optimizations. But I could see myself playing this a lot if I wis rich enough for a L4D clone... Everyone who has played L4D has likely play the sh-t out of it and probably doesn't want anything else to do with it. Why buy a more expensive reskin of a game when you already own the game this is copying anyways? This I think may be the reason the game is struggling to survive. Unfortunately, the player base reflects that...\n\nSince the launch of the game up until the free weekend. the player count has dropped about 89% according to Steam Charts, and continues to dwindle down each month. After this free weekend, there's been about a 12% increase in average players. That's not good at all. In a few months time the player base will average at a few hundred and by the end of the year probably stick to around 300+ people. This game doesn't deserve that kind of demise. I really hope it bounces back somehow because I can tell a lot of work was put into this. Maybe permanently slash the price by half? Just my two cents.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText: One of the funnest experiences i have ever had. This game is gold, and it's a steal at $30. It has the action and graphics of a game worth twice as much, yet, i would rather play this. It's been described as Left 4 Dead with rats; Thats partially true. It is more of a mix between L4D, and Diablo, where you gain loot for every mission completed. Loot is determined by dice roll and sometimes, it pays off; most of the time, not so much, but the great thing is that you can combine your loot to create even better loot. The characters are varied and interesting, the voice acting is lovely, and the soundtrack really fits the game. On the downside, it's still pretty buggy and I get the occasional crash, plus, there is one very important thing to note: YOU NEED CONSTANT INTERNET CONNECTION, BE WARNED. Aside from that, it's a bloody good time. Get a team and slice, dice, smash, slash, mangle, burn, pierce, bisect, lobotomize, stab, shoot, obliterate, poison, behead, and kill the rat menace. Some of the most satisfying combat you will ever experience, right here in this game. Honestly, we need more Warhammer games like this.

reviewText:
The Doom That Came to Kavzar!
This is a great game that follows the Left 4 Dead recipe. You and your companions must go from point A to point B. Fight hordes of Skaven, survive and complete objectives. At the end of each map you will be rewarded with loot to equip your characters. Some items you find will grant you better loot so be ready to search for them!

The game runs perfectly, no issues, no fps drop, nothing. Only some bugs in some maps but nothing affecting game performance. Updates and DLCs are deployed frequently.

PROS:
Graphics are beautiful.
Sound\Music.
Voice acting is great.
Typical Warhammer humour.
Fights are intense.
Many maps to play.
Immersion is amazing.
Frequent updates.
Cheap game for the amount of content it has.

CONS:
Chaos is not available, only Order.

My score: 9/10

reviewText:
I paid $26 for what is a AAA title

And what a god damn good title it is. Holy ♥♥♥♥ Fatshark, I played War of the Roses, War of the Vikings and now I'm hooked on Vermintide. There are so many little details in the game that add to the whole experience and I am happy these guys took the time to put them in! Having a rat hold out his hand and look at his own blood to then collapse is the most metal thing ever.

I don't see why people complain about this game when there are actual ♥♥♥♥ titles like Evolve to complain about. That game was a $60 rip off with the replayability of a firecracker.

In contrast, this game has so much more. From branching paths to hidden loot, right down to beatiful maps, compelling game play and actual force behind weapon impacts.

I'm more than willing to throw down money for ♥♥♥♥ing DLC hats from how much I love this game.

reviewText:
I can't stop playing this game. It is a lot of fun and the itemization is really cool.

The ability to play as either a primary ranged, melee or tank/cc FOR ANY class is awesome. Perhaps not truly as viable as some classes can, but none the less if you find the right gear and with the right mentality, you can make your own character unique.

The skill cap in this game is MUCH higher than similar games which I believe will allow this game to outlive some others that fell short here.

Because of the loot system and the way the game rewards you for taking risks and exploring, the randomization of the levels mobs and waves creates a unique experience almost every time.

If you can find 3 other people, whether you meet in game or know already to form a group, ANYTHING is possible. Beating some of this content is more rewarding than almost any other game I've played because the amount of teamwork and communication needed to really complete all objectives is hard, even on normal difficulty for people.

Try it out if you like co-op. If you want to be a badass solo rat killer, I'd recommend staying away, playing solo in this game punishes you very hard and frankly is a selfish thing to in a truly cooperative game.

reviewText: This satisfies my craving for a frenzied first person melee game. The sword (and axe, and mace, etc) play is quick and responsive. Each weapon or weapon combo has a unique playstyle. The art design is excellent and very much in character with the Warhammer universe.\n\nNow the bad stuff... as usual for inexplicable reasons the average pubber does not use their microphone and ends up getting the team killed. reviewText:
Vermintide is a great addition to the Warhammer storyline, set in an apocalyptic wasteland of vermin rats. A group of four characters, chosen from five, will fight together to go through quests and accomplish feats.

The pros:
-Intrigiuing loot system which rewards you for finding hidden Tomes and Loot Dice.
-Crafting system is interesting, and allows buildup towards exotic weapons the longer the playthrough.
-No microtransactions that make it a 'pay-to-win'. Simply gameplay driven.
-Combat is strong, fast-paced, and requires your individed attention, lest a pack-rat or assassin rat make your life a living hell.
-Enemy AI makes combat fun an interesting.
-An alright diversity of enemies makes combat thrilling.

The cons:
-Nowhere near enough different kinds of weapons.
-A lot of the classes, due to a limitted amount of weapons, feel very restricted in their build pattern. For example, the waywatcher only really ever has a bow for ranged.
-The friendly AI suck miserably. Very miserably. They're just ♥♥♥♥. Always, always play with friends instead. Numerous times, the farther into missions you go, the AI will just sit there and do absolutely nothing. Sometimes they'll just wait in one spot while you progress through the map, and do LITERALLY nothing. Their combat skills are god-awful, often never taking advantage of DPS or anything, and just hold the block button. They get stuck in walls like it's nobody's business, and have no concept of navigation.
-Even in full release, almost all of the bugs from pre-release stayed. For example, many players experience vertice glitches, where one or two vertices of characters will be in the floor, whereas the rest of the body will be either above it, or elsewhere if they've been ragdolled. Also, character models sometimes just have disappearing bodyparts.

Conclusion: All in all, I still love the game. The problems are counteracted by the thrilling combat and intriguing crafting system, which puts a lot of other games to shame. Even still, though, I'd highly recommend playing with friends. The friendly AI are more cancer than I can describe. They just don't function.

reviewText:
I cannot reccomend a game with a cancerous community. But I do reccomend a good game. This is a good game, not a good community.
With a HEAVY (and I mean 3.5 metric♥♥♥♥tons) focus on teamplay and cooperation. This game is golden for friends and players who ENJOY working together. Unlike most of the playerbase who rather exploit and try to solo this game to get loot. (They have fixed an exploit and over a week 50% of the playerbase droppped. Shows something) But instead of a long rant about this game heres a simple list of pros and cons since you prefer those better

Pros:
+(Personal Pro) Warhammer universe shown all in its glorious splender. Not a colorful bloody world but, dark dingy and +dank, with some colorful missions.
+Some well done (but still needs tweaking) melee combat (This is a melee focused game, Guns are more situational than a main weapon even for the Elf and her bow)
+Great atmosphere, Characters talk and bicker with one another, get to see some cool city scapes
+Enemies, most enemies vary and show off a distinct look like the Gutter Runner (Akin to L4D Hunter), Ogre (tank) +Packmaster, (Smoker/jockey), Poison Thrower (Spitter/smoker), and Ratling Gunner. And each one is equally deadly
+Lobby, now this was interesting to me but could still use more work. You start off inside a safehouse/inn working with other players to survive the Vermintide, more or so an interactive UI where you can choose your mission, customize and upgrade weapons.

Cons
-Toxic community, most of the games you will join it will be silent no one wants to chat with one another. From time to time you get a GG"
date: or "Halp me!" but apart from those no one likes to talk. People seem to be reluctant to help you and more inclined to insult you for going down. In fact the player base dropped from 25k to 11k after the devs fixed an exploit on a certain mission.\n-Lootbags
recommended: idk what to call these players but this ties into the con above. The reason why players left was because the said fixed exploit gave players loot
hoursPlayed: whether it be good or bad.\n-Difficulty
voteText: personally I like the difficulty. Hard is MEANT to be hard
helpfulPercent: Nightmare is well. A NIGHTMARE. Starting off at level 1-2 then trying to play on nightmare you are gonna have a bad time. The range of the Skaven are ridiculously long in melee
votesHelpful:
and most newbies dont know that you CAN dodge in this game. (hold down ASD and space and you will slide left right or back) But with a heavy focus on teamwork and noone working as a team. Players will have a bad time.
-Bugs there are still many bugs that were said to have been "fixed" Like when the orge attacks a downed player. That still happens or when the pack master grabbing someone from 2 stories up or through the floor.


Overall I CAN say this is a good game. But I cant reccomend it for people who play solo or matchmaking.
The community is iffy. The gameplay is good but not solid. Hopefully within the coming months we might get some new content.

reviewText:
5/10  (+3) if you have a regular premade group to play with  (-3) if you mostly want a viable single player game


This is a solid, and sometimes enjoyable, four person first person coop game.   However, the limited amount of content, repetetive gameplay, heavy reliance on randomness to drive (slow)progression, and unforgiving game play may be (very)off putting to some.



===PROS/CONS/CONCLUSION===


==PROS==

+L4D CooP alike in many ways

+There are five different characters, with 3 that play differently and 2 that play similiarly to each other.

+Itemization with Progression (mostly through items)

+Well realized grim-dark Warhammer atmosphere

+Well done weapons and animiations give the combat a visceral appeal.   The visceral combat where you slay hordes of Skaven can be especially apealing.


==CONS==

-It is very easy to fail & a failure nets next to nothing as far as progression goes (no loot,  very low experience)

-A failed missions resets you to the very start of long missions.  There are no safe houses as restart points like l4d2.

-If the host crashes/disconnects mid-mission, you lose all progress.  No dedicated servers (yet).

-Rewards are completely random.  The RNG for loot after a mission often results in a very poor reward or rewards for toons you aren't interested in playing.

-You can't trade items with other players.   Items can't be chosen using in game currency.

-Only one game mode, albiet with several difficulty levels i.e.,No survival mode or versus mode

-Repetetive gameplay/limited content: You can play through all the levels at least once in a dozen or so hours of play.  Most people play the same 2 or 3 levels over and over again.   What fun(not!).

-Due to many of the above CONs, this game has the worst PUG experience I have experienced in any game, ever.  This game isn't like killing floor 1/2 where random matches will be fun and provide progression most of the time.

-Poor bot AI.  Don't think you can play this solo to get around the PUG problem.

-No steam integration to see who you recently played with.  If you get DC'ed before the end, have fun trying to find the game you were just in.


==Conclusion==
In the end, while the game is compared to l4d, it isn't anywhere as near as fun to play

This is one of the most compelling games I have played recently, but the game experience is often totally wrecked by the CONS.  I also suspect the CONS will kill the community in relatively short order.

I uninstalled this to make sure I was never tempted to play it again.  Too bad, this was almost a great game.

reviewText:
The good:
- gameplay is fun, you have to play as a team to survive.
- atmosphere is there, warhammer is always so detailed
- receiving items for levelling up, rolling for extra loot after completed missions and breaking down/upgrading weapons to access special traits is a familiar system but really nice to have.
- finding hidden tomes in a level that if you managed to complete the mission whilst holding (they take up a healing slot) then you receive a bonus to your loot roll.
- and again same for the grimoires which take up a potion slot but add a bonus to your loot roll... at the cost of reduced max hp.


The bad:
- invisible rat bug... normal mobs were sometimes invsibile, i would take damage but could not attack them back, this usually stopped after being hit 3-6 times and moving far away from their location but it prevented me trying the harder difficulties as the damage would be too much.
- not enough content, in the free steam weekend i played 13 hours and in that time had completed all of the current content (excluding the DLC) multiple times on a variety of difficulties

I wouldn't recommend buying until more content has been released and some key gameplay bugs have been fixed. Certainly wouldnt pay the price on steam atm

reviewText:
This game is... Buggy. It can crash, it can give BSOD, can make your character stuck and suck very much with a bad team of players.
Than again, IF everything goes right and the team is good, on higher difficulties it is just pure 100% fun.
It's fantasy L4D game. A little bit like Dragon Age Inquisition multiplayer on top of it maybe.
The grind is real, the weapons are limited, but they are enough to keep you going for a little while.

Most of the issues are constantly beeing worked on. So even while the game is released, it still FEELS like a work in progress.
I would still say it's worth it to buy it. With all the issues I would still rate it about 8/10 as of now - and there are promisses of further development.

What is worth mentioning - the game is P2P, meaning NO DEDICATED SERVERS. This CAN be an issue. Games WILL be broken because of that. And if you live in a more secluded place (say, Poland, or even more exotic) you may find it difficult to find players if it is YOU who are hosting, since players will auto-connect to the nearest location, not best ping or connection quality.
If you know there will be few people playing the game in your country, I would seriously suggest removing a point or two from the score. At least I FELT like that.

Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide is a bland copy of L4D franchise but set in the Warhammer Fantasy Universe. What the game takes from L4D

recommended:
Vermintide follows L4D gameplay - fight your way through hordes of Skavens(that use the same tactic as zombies aka swarm you) with 3 of your buddies. Every now and then you will hear a horn and get attacked by a horde(hearing your characters saying "Its a trap/ambush"). I cant denied that those moments can be a lot of fun until ...

Special skaven

Special Skavens are either 1:1 with their l4d brothers or a mix.
Gutter Runner is the hunter but its way more agile and fast + can use smoke bombs to run away quickly.
Rat Ogre is the tank with no change in its behaviour(apart from passing through solid objects like pillars or wells).
Poison Wind Globadier is Spitter but with much bigger AoE and while it do less damage
hoursPlayed: it can disrupt your vision for awhile. It also will run towards you and explode just like Bomber.\nPackmaster(the most broken one) act like Jockey but instead of leaping on you
voteText:
it hooks you with his poll and drags you away from your teammate not caring about collission or pathfinding(it can teleport if he gets "blocked") .
Commander/Stormvermin are just stronger skavens using long halbered to fight from behind the meat shield and also being equiped with heavy armor that makes them hard to kill.
Ratlling Gunner reminds me a bit of the Smoker but instead of having a long tongue that grabs you(like packmaster) it has a gattling gun that charges up before it turns you into Swiss cheese if you arent behind cover. Not that it matters because is some scenarios his bullets passes through solid walls like nothing.

UI and slots

Vermintide uses the same UI as l4d which includes and what where is mapped on your keyboard with the little difference that melee weapons are in slot 1 and ranged in slot 2(in l4d melee is secondary weapon) . Then you have your healing items in slot 3. After it you have switched again slots for bombs and potions: number 4 is for potions
helpfulPercent:
number 5 for bombs(other way around in l4d). So for veteran l4d players it wont need much time to get used to it.

Changed L4D elements with a drop of Vermintide
Consumables

L4D2 consumables are medkit/defibrilator
votesHelpful: grenades(pipe
votesTotal: bile and molotov) and pills/adrenaline.\nVermintide offer some different consumables with some that are import for if you want higher chance to get more rare loot(that doesnt mean it will be better).\nFor healing you have healing potion and medical supplies. While both heals you the same
votesFunny: you can use the potion only on yourself(you cant give it to somebody else) and medical supplies can be used on anybody.\nFor bombs you have exploding and incendiary. First makes BOOM
commentsCount:
the 2nd just set rats on fire.
For potions you have speed and strength: speed increases your attack and move speed while strength gives your attack armor piercing .
Now there are 2 special "consumables" that increases the chance to get rare loot: Tomes(take the place of your healing item) and Cursed Grimoire(takes the place of your potion and lowers the max health of your party by 25% unless "discarded" ) .But more about them later

Levels

The story of Vermintide is spread on 13 levels. You will encounter 2 kind of levels : Linear and "horde" mode.
Linears are going from point A to point B while "horde" mode will give you the task to either gather X amount of barrels/sacks or just need to defend objective while you are getting swarmed.
For me personally the horde mode missions were boring but thats because I overplayed the mode itself in other games.
Linear on the other hand has its charm. Levels are completly linear. They often have small pockets to explore for supplies or tomes. There are also a lot of chests to open but dont get your hopes up(unless RNGesus is with you). Only around 1/4 of the chests I opened had something in them.

Characters

Vermintide features 5 playable characters with their unique personality and "unique" combat skills. You will often hear them exchange lines between each other while playing but whats interesting is their fighting style.
Dwarf Ranger and Empire Soldier feels the same. They both can wield heavy 2hand weapons and can use 1hand weapon with shield which makes them the frontline of the party. Add to that their ranged weapons have slow reload and you will end up shooting only special skavens while sticking to your melee.
Witch Hunter and Waywatcher are more of a fast and agile. They excel in ranged combat because of their fast reload time. But that doesnt mean they are bad in melee combat... they just arent as good as the soldier or the dwarf.
Last but not least is the Bright Wizard who is the only one who actually feels unique duo to her using magic and vent mechanic. While you cast spells your overcharge bar will feel. Bar got 2 levels(lvl1 and lvl2). Below level 1
column16: the staff vents itself automaticly so if you time your attack you may end up rarely passing level1. Upon passing level 1 you will either need to switch to melee weapon while waiting for the staff to cooldown
column17:
or can vent it yourself by hurting yourself. At level2(max charge) you will  lose control of your character until it vent itself.

Fresh from the source
Progression

When you finish a mission(or fail) you will gain experience that will level up your character. When you level up you will obtrain .... an item(white from lvl1-30
column18:
green from lvl30 and above)!!! But on level15 and 30 you will unlock a new trinket slot for your characters. Level is shared between your characters but its not like it matters much anyway. A high level player doesnt mean that he is a good one.

Equipment

To add some sort of RPG system
column19: Vermintide got to offer 4 kinds of equipment(hat
column20: melee weapon
column21: ranged weapon
column22: trinkets) and 4 rarities(plentiful
column23: common
column24: rare
column25: exotic) . And depending on the rarity your item will have 0
column28:
3 traits(bonuses) that you need to unlock.

Combat

L4D is a shooter with optional melee combat. Well Vermintide is on the other end. Its hack'n slash combat with shooting every now and then. Melee weapons got basic and charged attack + you can block attack or push away your foe to open some space. Simple yet effective and fun.


So far everything sounds good and fun

right?

Spawn points

I'm just getting sick of encountering 4 or 5 special skavens at the same time

Now if Fatshark can manage to pull it off and create something similar to l4d's AI director that would be cool.

reviewText:
If you're like me and have played hundreds of hours of Left 4 Dead and Left 4 Dead 2 this game seems like an interesting take on it at first glance. It has a melee weapon focus, loot drops, character customization, and long-form maps. Unfortunately it suffers from a whole suite of problems ranging from terrible balance issues, a wholly unrewarding loot system, and complete lack of optimization.

Starting out on normal the game seems decent enough, killing rats feels nice, you haven't had to deal with the drop system yet, and you aren't familiar with all of the special rats. After several hours however you will start to realize the truth, there's no skill to be had in dealing with any of the special rats unlike the Left 4 Dead series making many of the encounters with them just free damage upon you and/or your party, the drop system isn't rewarding in the slightest and in many cases is downright insulting, and balance issues abound making even clearing basic maps on medium difficulties with a full team of random people nigh impossible.
Unfortunately by the time you realize this game is a massive disappointment, you'll be outside of the range of receiving a refund from steam. Don't be like me, kids.

[My full review of this game was going to be around 1500 words and 9000 characters, but it doesn't fit on the reviews here - that's How many flaws this game has and how disappointed I was.]
voteText: 19 of 36 people (53%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I really want to like this game, I really do.
But in its current state, it's simply not worth recommending.

The idea of it is quite enticing. A four-player co-op horde survival game a la Payday, Killing Floor, L4D set in Warhammer universe with Chivalry-style combat initially had me quite intrigued.

However, the game still plays like it did when it was in beta. It suffers performance issues which in some cases are nearly crippling. Combat with multiple opponents almost always results in quite bad FPS issues. Enemy weapon reach is far longer than the weapons the enemies are holding.
An especially frustrating issue I have encountered is that the player takes damage from an enemy attack as soon as the enemy's attack animation begins, meaning you've got to have some Jedi-level perception in order to block successfully.

Most of these issues have been present since the beta began, yet the developers seem far more interested in patching 'exploits' in the levels than fixing performance problems. This is a practice that was seen in several Payday 2 DLC releases and it earned many grievances against Overkill from their playerbase.

This title still has potential, if the issues with it are addressed. When the game runs well, it's pretty fun. It's gory and full of decapitations and blood, which is always a hit with the crowd. But I would advise holding off on the purchase, either until the game is fixed or there's a decent discount on it.
voteText: 21 of 40 people (53%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: This game is terribly optimized. I get about 120 fps on average, but the second a horde of skaven spawn I dip down to around 30-40 fps until the fight is over. I was dumb enough to play the pre-order beta, and was hoping for some drivers / optimization patches from Fatshark, but nothing yet. I have a GTX 970 FTW+, i7 960 processor, 12gb of ram, and the game is installed on my SSD. I can run Witcher 3, GTA 5, and other newer titles on ultra and get around 80-90 FPS no problem. There is no reason why this game should be using 80% of my GPU and 100% of my CPU while im sitting in the inn (pre-game lobby, very small, almost nothing going on). There is obviously some serious CPU optimization issues with this title, and I would strongly suggest not picking it up until they are hammered out... if they ever are. The other thing I dislike about this game is the loot system. It is way too RNG heavy, and 90% of the time I get some useless item for a class I never plan on playing. If this game ran smoother it might be worth the $22 I paid for it, but it runs like I have a baked potato shoved into my CPU chip slot, and some silly puddy jammed into my PCI slot for a GPU. Melee combat / ranged combat is okay... although chopping through an enemy / enemies isn't as satisfying as it games like Chivalry where you really feel the blow connect to your opponent. Overall the game just feels rushed and not of the greatest quality, I would rate it a 6/10... probably a 7.5/10 if it ran at a solid 60+ FPS without horrid framedrop in combat.

reviewText: I'm very much on the fence with this game. I'm giving it a Not Recommended" rating but depending on the player it could just as easily be "Recommended". It's just that for me
date: it isn't worth it. Allow me to explain.\n\nVermintide is a fun game. You'll find yourself fighting through hordes of ratmen with a group of three others in an attempt to complete a set of objectives on each stage. The combat is generally solid with a couple minor complaints I'll talk about later and the stages are challanging. It plays very much like Left4Dead... Perhaps too much. And that is where my main complaint comes in. This really seems like an unashamed clone of Left4Dead with a new coat of paint. However
recommended: it does have some things that set it apart. Let's look a little closer
hoursPlayed:
starting with a look at some enemies.

Ratling Runner = Hunter
Runs at you
voteText:
leaping on top of you and pinning you to the ground while laying into you with it's daggers. Can stealth. Knocks teammates away when it pounces.

Ratling Taskmaster = Jockey
Grabs you with a long staff and pulls you away from your team until someone kills it.

Rat Ogre = Tank
Extremely tough. Charges in lines at your team.

Poison Wind Globadier = Spitter
Throws poison cloud grenades that force you to avoid camping one spot too long.

Are there any more unique enemies? So far the only ones I can spot is the Gunner and Commander. The gunner is a ratling with a minigun who can pose a bit of a threat if you aren't careful while the commander wears heavy armor that forces you to use heavy attacks or aim for his head.

The overlay and player death mechanics are also near identical
helpfulPercent: with the classic green and red outlines for your teammates and the ability to find a downed teammate awaiting rescue further into the stage.\n\nAs for what sets it apart from Left4Dead. There is a huge focus on melee combat here. Some classes
votesHelpful: such as the mage utilize ranged combat heavily
votesTotal: however most classes will find themselves chest deep in blood and gore within seconds of starting the fight. There are blocking and dodge mechanics and overall the melee combat feels solid
votesFunny: if a little floaty. I sometimes feel there isn't enough weight behind my blows
commentsCount:
though perhaps that's because all the blades seem to cut through ratlings like a hot knife through butter. Combat would feel much more satisfying if there were a little more impact to the blows.

There is also a fun loot system that has you coming back for more as you try to find that awesome new piece of gear that will help you clear that next highest difficulty. Though you may wait quite a while as loot is heavily RNG based and you can get drops for classes you don't actually play...

Overall it's a fun game though. If you like Left4Dead
column16: you're gonna like Vermintide. Just don't expect any huge innovations here."

reviewText:
It's like if Left 4 Dead and the old warhammer game Mordhiem had a very angry baby.... then that baby grew up with a backass beard and a hatred for rodents!

Edit: I felt the review was lacking so i though i should go into further detail.

The characters are very close to the lore of the source material, While the game is similar to left 4 dead in alot of respects the melee combat is vastly superior with the weapons having varity and viewable statistics to them, a better blocking mechanic and even a dodge move that can help you jump to either side or back to avoid incomming strikes.

The only downsides with this game compaired to its predecessor would be the lack of a vs mode though the Co-op side of the game stands on its own just fine, i also hope additional characters are added to the roster and the few bugs the game has is adressed and ironed out, still for a game that is not AAA it certainly had alot of polish and atmosphere to it, even if it does make my CPU boil!

I will recommend you keep an eye open on the system requirements, this one is a bit of a glutton though even at its lowest setting the game is still appealing to look at (bare a few low ress wound textures on the skaven when you kill them)

Best of all its not set in Age of Sigmar! :D

reviewText: Tough game. Players are thrown into the game with no idea of how hard it is. Many players will fail their first few games because of this, and it turns them off from the game. The game itself is pretty cool. I really like the setting, and the graphics are good. Missions are REALLY long, usually around 30 minutes for one mission. If you don't play with friends, just hope and pray you find an expierienced player or two, because new players really pull down the team. There is a decent amount of missions, gamemodes, and enemies. Events are generated randomly, so you don't know what will be waiting for you. Loot system is interesting. In order to get good loot at the end of the mission, you have to find in-game items hidden throughout the mission which make the mission  itself harder by reducing total health and taking up the potion slot. They increase the chance of a higher level item. This system is good in theory, but it leads players to play the same mission over and over and over because they know the locations of these hidden items. This gets pretty boring, and if you fail the mission it is very irritating. It's fun for a while. 6/10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is basically Left 4 Dead: Exterminator Edition.
Pros:
Every weapon feels satisfying to swing, or shoot. The crunch of a rat skull under a warhammer will send shivers down your spine.
All 5 characters feel unique, and because groups are made up of four, you'll never get stuck without a choice.
Unrelenting difficult at higher levels unless you work as a team and communicate effectively.
It will make you tense up. You will be anxious, wondering when the rat ogre is going to show up.
Rat Ogres.
When you win, you'll feel like you've earned it.
Gear doesn't make the player. Skill does.
No pay to win at all.
Free DLC.
Cons
Not all weapons are made equal. While they can all be fun, only some are viable on harder difficulties.
Communicating with a public group can be brutal. Better hope they all know what they're doing on the highest difficulties.
Tutorial? We don't need no stinkin' tutorial.
No dedicated servers, if a host drops you restart the level. Bad lag can end a good run.
The loot system isn't generous, and you will be underwhelmed at times.
The rats have gatling guns.
All in all, I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed L4D, or is interested in a co-op game that will have you at the edge of your seat cheering (or cursing) your friends as you wade through a sea of bipedal rodents with medieval weaponry against all odds.

reviewText:
Mage looks way too much like my 5th grade science teacher, that being said...

This is a great game about booping rat snoots, and has a strong left 4 dead vibe while remaining in the Warhammer universe. The gameplay itself is similar, but it has a progressive loot system, leveling, and 5 playable heroes over 13 maps.

It has some things going for it:
-Fun heroes
-Various gear to play with
-Plenty of versatile missions for it's price tag
-A fairly nice and detailed dark gothic enviroment set deep in warhammer lore
-Lots of rats and types of rats to slay
-Incredibly well voiced dialogue
-Sarcastic ***** of an Elf for you to hate

Also three real problems that seem to have been noticed by most folks
-Performance issues, that seem to be steadily improving each update, but there is still some FPS loss on even high end machines on lower settings.
-The loot system is basically flat out frustrating and most people are not enjoying it. (You need to roll at the end of a successful mission and even if you are lucky and get something half decent, you have to melt down other gear to unlock one of that weapons base bonuses, and it rolls for how much of a bonus again, via RNG. The entire system is RNG based, but in a way that mission rewards do not feel like rewards)
-A lot of hitbox and clipping issues. Any time a problem comes up that causes an exploit where heroes can beat a mission earier or such is fixed within days, but issues like the Rats that can hit well beyond their actual reach, grab you through walls and pull you through them, teleport around, etc etc... don't seem to be getting much attention

That being said, the game is throughly enjoyable regardless, especially with a group of friends. I highly suggest taking a look, more so if you enjoyed Left 4 Dead or melee based FPS games.

Edit: There does not seem to be any content coming for this game fast; and that is really what a game like this needs to stay relevent.

reviewText:
Incredibly similar to L4D with a focus on melee combat.  Overall a fun game but not without issues.

Performance is good overall though I wish the game would give you control over the post processing effects so people with sub-recommended specs could eek out more frames.  The game is CPU heavy.  I have a FX-8320 that I've overclocked to 4.0Ghz.  This is below the recommended CPU for AMD and I experience frame drops down to 30-40fps in heavy fighting and scenic open areas of maps.  My CPU temp approaches 58C and my mobo approaches 65C.  A little high, but doable.  If you have a comparable or lower end CPU be prepared to sacrifice visual fidelity for stable framerates.  I hope this improves after beta or we at least get more control over the graphics settings come launch.

With the exception of the gatling gun rat, the special enemies are carbon copies of L4D special zombies.  Managing supplies throughout the level works exactly the same as in L4D as well.  The developers played it very safe.  You have your main melee weapon, a secondary ranged weapon, a slot for a medical item, a slot for a buff item (extra speed/melee damage), and a slot for a bomb.  Sound familiar?  With Warhammer being such a diverse property, I'm disappointed the developers didn't try something new with special enemies or items.

As you play each level you find tomes.  Tomes are slotted in your inventory over medical items.  Having a tome in your inventory at the end of a level gives you a bonus die for the loot system at the end of each round.  You can also find bonus die on special Skaven.  At the end of each round, you roll dice to determine the quality of your loot reward.  The more die roll a glyph or rune or whatever it is, the better quality item you get.  Total RNG with no care given to what class you're playing at the time.  You could be playing a dwarf and unlock gear for the wizard.  This means you can swap heroes easily to try out new gear, but it also makes finding gear for a specific character you prefer a slog.  Gear can be upgraded to unlock special passive bonuses using material gained from salvaging items.  Alternatively, 5 items of the same quality can be upgraded to a random item of the next rarity level.

Co-op vs AI is the only game mode.  As far as I know, there are no plans for a competitive mode where players also control special Skaven.  At $30, I think it's a fair price for the amount of content promised and replayability via the loot system.  If you were expecting this game to be something more than L4D, you might be disappointed.

Edit:  Skaven have oddly long attack range for melee.  Melee attacks from even basic Skaven can hit you through objects and through other Skaven.  In choke points, you'll often be hit by melee attacks you never see because many of the models mush together.  All characters dodge the same distance and it's often useless unless timed perfectly since enemies will track you when telegraphing their attack.

reviewText:
This game gets a lot of comparisons to L4D2. These are fair in that the engine is basically the same. The highlighted items, characters, and pick-up are all very L4D-y. The immobilizing special enemies that you need your team to rescue you from are also there (and still as annoying). Oh, and the companion AI is still garbage. That being said, however, this does feel like a different enough game.

The graphics are really good considering the engine age. The mix of each character having a melee and a ranged is great an the characters seem unique enough from eachother but very well blanaced. The combat carries weight and is satisfying.

I held off for a while getting this game because I was conserned there wouldn't be enough persistant character development to really hold my interest but there is. There are a lot of weapon types and qualities to earn that make a huge difference in play style and effectiveness.

Due to not openeing at a ridiculous $60 price tag but instead being a very reasonable price, this is a recommend.

reviewText:
Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide is an first person survival horror with... rats?
The player can set on missions with other players to play along as five characters, each with their own specialties. This game can be seen as heavily influenced by Valve's Left 4 Dead games, as the players have two weapon slots, one melee, and one ranged, along side one utility item, one, grenade item, and one healing item, totalling out to five carriable items.

Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide would be identical to the Left 4 Dead series, but there is loot and progression in this one. At the end of each mission, if successful, the players may roll for loot, using die, and having a chance at white, green, and blue rarity items; with white being the lowest and blue being the highest. Unlike Left 4 Dead, the player also has a level to keep up with, like a normal account level. The higher the level, the more features may be unlocked in the inn.

Like Left 4 Dead, this game has special types of rats, as in the Left 4 Dead series. There are a few: the Rat Ogre, portraying the tank in Left 4 Dead, the Pack Master portraying the Smoker, the Assassin Rat, portraying the Hunter, and last but not least, the Ratling Gunner, portraying... well... it's a gunner, so I wouldn't know.

There may not be much to this game in the long run, as it does get repetitive, but it does offer a lot of fun times if played with friends.

-     7 / 10

reviewText: Gonna give a tenative thumbs up for now. I like the game but it is pretty difficult to finish on higher difficulty without a coordinated team, which means basically stick together and hit everything in sight. Graphics are nice and mindless combat can be fun but hopefully there is more planned in the future and the weapon upgrades become a little more dynamic. Right now I would give is a 3/5 with potential to increase moving forward.\n\nOne more thing every time a major Skaven rush occurs it seems the only objective is to find the rearest wall, put your back to it and swing your sword at the onslaught until the vermin are all dead. It can be fun and intense in a viseral way, but lacks depth and sophistication.
