reviewText:
I've thoroughly enjoyed this game and it has wittled most of my free time away these past few days.  Playing with friends is a joy and the development roadmap painted by the recent AMA has me excited for the future of this game.

Pros

+Simple gameplay, no tutorial is necessary.  Learning the nuances of loot acquisition took me one game.
+Different Characters have unique mechanics and feel distinct.
+ The atmosphere is spot on to what a warhammer fantasy game should be.
+Devs have been constantly at work, and their efforts are easily visible.
-Better matchmaking
- Better optimization of assets
- Item balancing
+Can play singleplayer with bots... but why would you want to?
+combat FEELS meaty and has weight.
+RPG elements are simple and easy to follow.

Cons

+RPG elements are too simple.  I would like to see numbers, not just sliding bars to tell me weapon stats.
+hard to hear audio ques for some of the special skaven types.  Even with nothing going on.
+The story feels a bit disjointed.
+Everyone plays the elf, good luck finding a game.
+Some controls (like instant heal/grenade) don't work well.

In conclusion, this game is worth the money.  All of the gripes I have are easily overshadowed by how much fun I'm having with this gem and by the DEVs obvious attention to the community and eye for quality.

reviewText:
TL;DR - This game is awesome. You should be playing it.

Ok, now for real:

Visuals: This game visually looks amazing. The team did an amazing job with cramming tons of detail into everything in this game.

Emersion: You really feel like you are a warrior/mage/whatever trying to help this city against an invading monster race. It's simplistic, but nails it in most aspects.

Story: The story is super simple, but if you're playing this game for the story then you probably shouldn't buy it. You pick up tons of small details about the story as you play the levels, but it's not a story driven game.

Combat: WOAH! Awesome...

Conclusion: I have never been so entranced by a midevil styled game before. Honestly they usually bore me, but this game is stellar so far.

reviewText:
Ok, I understand how some people have said that this game is more of a left 4 dead feel. It totally is 100% like left 4 dead. You have special classes that represent left 4 dead special infected. The game is really fun with friends but with randoms it is meh. I will go down a list to show the variants and how left 4 dead is similar in the parenthesis since vermintide is the main topic here.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-Gutter Runner (Hunter)
-Globe Lobber(kinda like the Boomer only thing is that this one deals damage over time without the mobs)
-Skaven Ogre(Tank)
-Packmaster (Smoker)
-Ratling Gunner (I would compare this to a witch only thing different is that the agro is instant when spotted)
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The game also has a levelling system in it that will give you items that you get after a certain level. There are also slots that open in customizing your character that will eventually open up items for you to use. For instance, you are a level 4 or below and there is a trinket slot that opens at level 5. (this is just an example, I don’t remember if that trinket slot is open in any certain level… more than likely not) you go to the end of a campaign and you roll for your loot (we’ll get back with that later) and you don’t see any trinkets that drop along the bar. But you have just levelled up to five and you get to roll and there is a trinket that is now droppable in the rolling sequence. If you have the slot open for a specific item, there is a fair chance that you would be able to get the loot drop for that slot when you have it unlocked for that level. Simpler terms, you get what you can use and you don’t get what you can’t even equip yet.

Now, about this rolling, every single time you finish a mission successfully you get to make rolls. In each mission depending on which one it is, you get to come across these items that can help boost up your roll.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-Tomes  (+100 xp and adds one die with more successful sides when rolled)
-Loot die (basic loot die that adds ontop of your normal 6 die pool)
-Grimoire (reducing the party health by 33% and is consumable. Once consumed it will make the waves harder and you wont get the guaranteed roll on the guaranteed one die you get if you don’t consume it.)

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Certain characters have certain traits about them that follow with the Warhammer age of sigmar realm or time. The elf is snarky towards the dwarf, the witch hunter is no fan of anyone but the soldier, the soldier is the all around whatever human that just chops ♥♥♥♥, the dwarf is not a fan of the magic that the wizard can conjure, and it is just overall an odd alliance.

Now for you people wondering if there will be DLC’s coming out. I honestly don’t know but once you finish the only acts that are available, which hits at the maximum of four, there is an ending cutscene that certainly leaves and opening for other DLC content and I for one am excited for it.

This game is the first game of Warhammer that I have ever owned. I knew about it and played a lot of D&D and I enjoyed the lore. After playing this, I most definitely want to move over to the lore in Warhammer Age of Sigmar. If you enjoy good ol swordplay with specific roles and classes and love the left 4 dead playstyle… get this game… I highly recommend it. I wouldn’t say that this game is the best co op game cause I will say that Payday 2 is more up on my scale but this game is really fun. Out of 5 stars I would give this game a 4/5.

reviewText:
TL;DR:  Very well-executed game, packs a bunch of lore into a 4-person co-op game in the veins of Payday 2 & Left 4 Dead 2.  Recommended for those fans of first-person-co-op games that enjoy playing with others, but less so for those people who aren't prone to play online.

Pros:
* Controls are smooth and (mostly) intuitive
* Graphics are very good-looking and a wide variety of settings are available
* Audio is excellent -- when you hit a rat, it sounds exceedingly satisfying
* Gameplay is good, but the RNG really hits hard when you start getting to the highest difficulty (cataclysm) if you're not prepared
* Story is well fleshed-out, brief enough to keep your attention and brush the top of the End Times lore
* Developers are very invested in their job, and frequently listen to players' input and comments

Cons:
* Still a little buggy in places, but much better than release
* AI improvements to rats make the game harder, but the AI for the bots still needs some tweaking
* Client-side hosting (P2P)!  Rat damage is calculated on the host's end, but the damage you do to rats is calculated on your end, working well for right now but making for awkward situations when one person (the host) has sub-optimal internet

I would heartily recommend this game to any of my friends, and I applaud Fat Shark (the Devs) for making such an awesome game.  Can't wait for any DLC or sequels!

reviewText: Vermintide is an excellent co-op shooter. Mechanically, the game is very similar to Left 4 Dead, but with a stronger emphasis on melee combat. There are a limited number of levels, but they are all extremely detailed and as fun to play for a tenth or twentieth time as for a second or third. The loot system also adds to replayability, not because you ever have to grind for loot in order to progress, but because it provides customization and a fun reward for completing harder missions. The difficulty is also well balanced, with the book pick-ups enabling players to make things harder for themselves during a mission in order to get better rewards. Also, while set in the Warhammer universe, this is certainly not just for fans of the franchise. The rats are an appealing enemy for just about anyone, with approachably flavorful animation and voice lines. The player characters are a lot of fun as well. Definitely recommend for anyone looking for a game to play with friends.

reviewText:
I cannot highly recommend this game enough.

Are you a fan of satisfying and viceral melee combat?
Do you like the L4D objective and special infected style?
Do you like having different classes/character/loot which radically change your gameplay style?

If you answered yes to any of these, I would recommend getting this game. At the price point of 30 dollars, it is a steal. On normal, the entire game will take you 4-6 hours to simply complete all the levels available on first go. However, due to the loot, and the increased difficulty of hard/nightmare/cataclysm, and of the hidden tome/grimoires on each level to find, you will want to come back and play more. Even 70 hours in im still finding new areas I haven't noticed on prior playthroughs.

The combat itself is incredibly satisfying. Every weapon acts differently, and the grusome decapitation and dismemberment of rat men will never get old. The special skaven make it so that sticking together is a necessity, and yet still incredibly challenging. Add in the fact of the random spawns, and each playthrough of the same map will always turn out differently, and sometimes really crank up the difficulty when a skaven patrol rounds the corner at the worst possible time.

Also count in the fact that the developer has announced a massive free DLC pack for new weapons/features december 3rd, this is worth your time to purchase and have a great time.

The game is brought down to the fact of numerous bugs (although quite small, only few times have I noticed game/match ending bugs, maybe 3 times), but only by a small amount. Also, a bit of lackluster netcode makes it incredibly annoying when the host leaves, forcing the entire mission to restart from the beginning. When playing with friends however, this is never a problem.

Overall, if your a fan of the warhammer universe, 9/10. If your not a fan, 8/10.

A very solid and engaging game, which cruel RNG loot system will make you come crawling back for more, brought down only by the fact of small bugs littering the game like so much skaven filth.

reviewText:
This is the true game of the year. Altough it does not feature as much content as a blockbuster fallout 4 this team still made the most solid game I have played in a lot of days. I cannot emphasis how right combat feels in this game, and how good the challenge level is. If you exit the comfort zone and play hard, you WILL have a hard experience. You will fail with your team, but the sweetness of finally clearing a level makes up for it.

Not only have they nailed the gameplay, but they release FREE DLC. From a businiess stand point this makes little sense, but from a quality stand point it's spot on. The game industry is decaying, favoring business plans and advertising over quality. I am glad to see that Fatshark goes against this trend, holding their ground and setting up an example for other game developers and publishers.

Graphics are not exceptional, but quite excellent non the less. Audio is great as well. The atmosphere makes you feel like your really in a murky city where a terrible war(slaughter) broke out from beneath. The weapons are varied, and you will find what suits your individual taste the best.

For the best experience, get some good friends and buy this game.
You will get your moneys worth two-fold if you're into co-operative survival games.

reviewText:
I've thoroughly enjoyed this game and it has wittled most of my free time away these past few days.  Playing with friends is a joy and the development roadmap painted by the recent AMA has me excited for the future of this game.

Pros

+Simple gameplay, no tutorial is necessary.  Learning the nuances of loot acquisition took me one game.
+Different Characters have unique mechanics and feel distinct.
+ The atmosphere is spot on to what a warhammer fantasy game should be.
+Devs have been constantly at work, and their efforts are easily visible.
-Better matchmaking
- Better optimization of assets
- Item balancing
+Can play singleplayer with bots... but why would you want to?
+combat FEELS meaty and has weight.
+RPG elements are simple and easy to follow.

Cons

+RPG elements are too simple.  I would like to see numbers, not just sliding bars to tell me weapon stats.
+hard to hear audio ques for some of the special skaven types.  Even with nothing going on.
+The story feels a bit disjointed.
+Everyone plays the elf, good luck finding a game.
+Some controls (like instant heal/grenade) don't work well.

In conclusion, this game is worth the money.  All of the gripes I have are easily overshadowed by how much fun I'm having with this gem and by the DEVs obvious attention to the community and eye for quality.

reviewText:
Disclaimer : I really love warhammer so I may have a more forgiving outlook on the game becuase of my love for the franchise. This experience comes from playing with friends to dropping solo with bots and with random players on Nightmare difficulty ( the 2nd to last hardest difficulty ).

Things I will answer.

1st: What are the mechanics of the game and how do they contribute to an enjoyable experience.

2nd: Community , is it Toxic or friendly?

3rd: Is it worth it?



For those who dont have much time I will simply tell you its a fantasy L4D with magic , swords and lots of dead rats. If you enjoyed L4D you may find a new game to play here and that you could try it out for and hour but if you dont like it then refund it.

Now to the questions...

Mechanics...
yourself and three others form a party of four seperate characters to take on the Vermintide , a horde of ratmen come to destroy your town. The first of these five classes I will go Into is the Soldier , he is mostly a melee character wielding either 2 handed hammers or swords to a mace and shield or sword and shield combo. The soldier usually will be in the front of a party and try to bash the mobs and tank it for the team. While most characters can also do this , the soldier and dwarf have access to shields that allow them to block and bash more often then their counter parts.

Next we have the dwarf who plays very much like the soldier , however the weapons at a dwarfs disposal very a bit from the soldiers , for instance while the soldier can have a repeater rifle the dwarf can get flare guns that light up mobs of rats setting crowds ablaze.

Then we have the mage ( My personel favorite ) This class is a power house that must manage their magic in the form of a heat management style where if you generate too much you will die but if you keep it under control you will kill EVERYTHING!!! ( insert power level joke here ). The mage has access to large AOE spells or very powerfull single target spells that can make or break the game depending on who uses it. The mage also gets a sword to help them ( I recommened the fire sword ).

Onto the Elf , Do you like fast weapons? Do you like bows? Do you like heat seeking arrows??????? Then here's the class for you!!! Behold my bow that never misses its shots, I found a Bow that has heat seeking arrows and its great. The elf is however a great character for killing the trash mobs , the bows help a lot ( just like most secoandary weapons ) to kill the bigger more prominent foes so save that ammo for something tough.

Last but not least the Witchhunter , This guy is great if you're looking for some gunplay , sporting duel pistols ( flintlocks actually ) and either a zwiehander or a sword and pistol. This guy is great for range firepower on a single target ( pistols with pierce would be awesome Fatshark! ) or you can get a repeater rifle for him aswell and use that to murder many rats. The pointy hat is also pretty great.


Onto question two. Is the community Toxic".... Kinda .... Ive been kicked simply becuase I wasnt level 100 ( which means nothing but you played the beta and had a lot of time on your hands ). Most players hate the grind like myself but becuase of the loot system
date: ( after each mission you roll dice to get loot
recommended: doing objectives gets you more loot such as tomes or finding dice in chests or of loot rats ) Players usually try to do all the objectives and most of the time a party will die trying to do most objectives and this has made my experience crap.. I'd rather pump out 3 matches on normal then try to roll for one good weapons becuase I can just craft weapons from the basic tier up.\n\nPeople in this game will boot you simply becuase they forgot to put the group on Invite only
hoursPlayed:
people will boot you becuase you use a mic or dont use a mic. Experience's may vary....  My experience with people on Vermintide is VERY negetive... some of you guys might find great people but I ended up just running with bots ( which has gotten me far more loot then running with people on my end of things ). Its better to simply complete a mission then risk lossing it and wasting 30 minutes of your time.



Complaints/cons: This game is brutal and I wish there was a moment where rats were not always coming at you even on easy. For some reason during my experience I encountered hordes far more often then people I watched on twitch.

This game doesnt really have a tutorial... It just kinda throws you in and points at stuff but sticks you with other players while you try to learn the game.


Finally is Vermintide worth it??? Yes it is worth it but I would buy it and try to play with friends."

reviewText: Lovely game, pretty difficult when it needs to be and a whole lot of fun. The only drawbacks really are that it's lacking...intelegent bot allies when they're in game and maybe some sort of trade system or ..little shop at the Inn. I love the game..great for warhammer fans and newbies to the end times era. But not polished, a lot of flaws..and pretty tricky..yet that's what makes it awesome. Better with friends too, the bots are useless.

reviewText:
Like so many reviewers noted before, this game is basically the Left 4 Dead 3 that never was. The skavens make for a great enemy and a well deserved break from the tiresome zombies that we see all too often in entertainment today. The looting system is what keeps the player coming back. Expect a lot of grind though, especially if you are aiming for good gear since loot is randomised. However, you get an opporunity to improve your chances for good loot if you pick up hidden tomes in levels. These tomes take up the inventory space that medical supplies would normally occupy, thus leading to some hardcore playthroughs on harder difficulties to ensure the tomes will reach the end of the level.  Sadly, the random nature of loot make for a game that can feel at times unrewarding, especially when you gain poor loot after beating levels at high difficulties despite picking the tomes.

On a more positive note, level design is greatl Some levels are linear, akin to Left 4 Dead, while others consist of picking up items, destroying skaven buildings, or defending locations while hordes of skavens storm at you from every side. The class based characters propose enough variety to encourage multiple playthroughs with each character and that is what makes the game better than Left 4 Dead to me. I love how different the Flame Mage and the Dwarf are, the first being a crowd control/AoE damage specialist and the second being a tank with an emphasis on melee although he is able to inflict range damage with his crossbow. All 5 characters feel different and that's what is so cool about it. Writing, voice acting and music are also excellent and fit the game nicely,.Special mention goes to the all-too-often hilarious dialogues.

All in all, if you're into Left 4 Dead, grab this game. I do not recommend playing the game solo since the bots are broken as of now and will more often lead you to your doom rather than the skavens.

It's also the perfect game to set up a creepy mood for Halloween.

EDIT- I will go on to say that http://steamcommunity.com/id/110230 Roy brought up some issues he doesn't care for, and I think it wouldn't be bad to read his review as well. This game is absolutely amazing. If you liked L4D2 and are a fan of killing things violently and with melee weapons, you'll love this game. It can be hard, it's fun, it's got plenty of loot / upgrades, it's got multiple characters.

The maps are really open for a game of this type, allowing you to explore and gather more items for better loot!

It really shines in the way each character is important, and teamwork is a MUST. Each and every character can be useful at range or up close depending on which weapons you equip and how you play.

The only thing I want to see from this game is more of this game.... And a 40k version....

reviewText:
Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide is an first person survival horror with... rats?
The player can set on missions with other players to play along as five characters, each with their own specialties. This game can be seen as heavily influenced by Valve's Left 4 Dead games, as the players have two weapon slots, one melee, and one ranged, along side one utility item, one, grenade item, and one healing item, totalling out to five carriable items.

Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide would be identical to the Left 4 Dead series, but there is loot and progression in this one. At the end of each mission, if successful, the players may roll for loot, using die, and having a chance at white, green, and blue rarity items; with white being the lowest and blue being the highest. Unlike Left 4 Dead, the player also has a level to keep up with, like a normal account level. The higher the level, the more features may be unlocked in the inn.

Like Left 4 Dead, this game has special types of rats, as in the Left 4 Dead series. There are a few: the Rat Ogre, portraying the tank in Left 4 Dead, the Pack Master portraying the Smoker, the Assassin Rat, portraying the Hunter, and last but not least, the Ratling Gunner, portraying... well... it's a gunner, so I wouldn't know.

There may not be much to this game in the long run, as it does get repetitive, but it does offer a lot of fun times if played with friends.

-     7 / 10

reviewText:
Incredibly similar to L4D with a focus on melee combat.  Overall a fun game but not without issues.

Performance is good overall though I wish the game would give you control over the post processing effects so people with sub-recommended specs could eek out more frames.  The game is CPU heavy.  I have a FX-8320 that I've overclocked to 4.0Ghz.  This is below the recommended CPU for AMD and I experience frame drops down to 30-40fps in heavy fighting and scenic open areas of maps.  My CPU temp approaches 58C and my mobo approaches 65C.  A little high, but doable.  If you have a comparable or lower end CPU be prepared to sacrifice visual fidelity for stable framerates.  I hope this improves after beta or we at least get more control over the graphics settings come launch.

With the exception of the gatling gun rat, the special enemies are carbon copies of L4D special zombies.  Managing supplies throughout the level works exactly the same as in L4D as well.  The developers played it very safe.  You have your main melee weapon, a secondary ranged weapon, a slot for a medical item, a slot for a buff item (extra speed/melee damage), and a slot for a bomb.  Sound familiar?  With Warhammer being such a diverse property, I'm disappointed the developers didn't try something new with special enemies or items.

As you play each level you find tomes.  Tomes are slotted in your inventory over medical items.  Having a tome in your inventory at the end of a level gives you a bonus die for the loot system at the end of each round.  You can also find bonus die on special Skaven.  At the end of each round, you roll dice to determine the quality of your loot reward.  The more die roll a glyph or rune or whatever it is, the better quality item you get.  Total RNG with no care given to what class you're playing at the time.  You could be playing a dwarf and unlock gear for the wizard.  This means you can swap heroes easily to try out new gear, but it also makes finding gear for a specific character you prefer a slog.  Gear can be upgraded to unlock special passive bonuses using material gained from salvaging items.  Alternatively, 5 items of the same quality can be upgraded to a random item of the next rarity level.

Co-op vs AI is the only game mode.  As far as I know, there are no plans for a competitive mode where players also control special Skaven.  At $30, I think it's a fair price for the amount of content promised and replayability via the loot system.  If you were expecting this game to be something more than L4D, you might be disappointed.

Edit:  Skaven have oddly long attack range for melee.  Melee attacks from even basic Skaven can hit you through objects and through other Skaven.  In choke points, you'll often be hit by melee attacks you never see because many of the models mush together.  All characters dodge the same distance and it's often useless unless timed perfectly since enemies will track you when telegraphing their attack.

reviewText:
I honestly was not expecting much from this game, the developer is unknown and lets be honest, only about 1 out of 5 Warhammer games are even considered passable, let alone good. But I really am enjoying this game.


EXPLANATION AND POSITIVES
________________________________________________________________________________

It is essentially Left 4 Dead 2, combined with a loot/upgrade system, character classes, and set in a Warhammer Fantasy setting.

The combat itself is about 80% melee (depending on what character you are playing) and the melee itself is a mix between Skyrim and Mount and Blade. A mix as in, a lot better than Skyrim (but similar), but not as good as Mount and Blades melee combat.

The Skaven (Rat people that take the places of zombies) are honestly fairly fleshed out, and seem to have alright personalities, they have their own banter towards the characters, and some even cower in fear when you show up, until they decide to mass rush you.

The loot system takes place after each wave, you are given a number of dice (That number changes depending on the difficulty, and what optional things ((Such as carrying around bulky tomes the entire map)) you have undertaken that map) You are then showed a scale of items, and the higher you roll, the better the items. Those items you can go on to upgrade in other ways as well.

The character classes have a bit of overlay, some weapon types are shared (Dwarf and Empire Soldier both get Two handed hammers for instance, but the hammers look and function slightly different), and they can all function well in both melee and ranged.

The characters also have a fair bit of...character....banter is common, and they are all fairly well fleshed out and voiced.

The graphics in this game are, honestly, fairly stunning, the metals, woods, and characters all look very well textured.

________________________________________________________________________________

NEGATIVES OR APPREHENSIONS:

This game is honestly, fairly Warhammer...with that comes a very grimdark" and different setting

reviewText:
There are already a number of great reviews on here regarding this game, so I'll just throw this in there to bolster the game.

tl:dr - If you like Warhammer and/or you like Left 4 Dead then you will love this game.
I went into this game a bit apprehensive, I had never heard of the team that made this game before and most recent Warhammer games (mainly 40k) in recent history have been very sub-par…

However, I kept in mind that back in the early 90s when I was a kid, the Skaven were my army of choice when playing Warhammer tabletop and after seeing a lot of glowing reviews (Total Biscuit etc) and finding the game at a decent price, I thought stuff it I’ll give it a punt. And I’m glad I did.

The game play really took me back to the days where me and 3 other mates would jump on Left 4 Dead and just have a blast. This game seems to have taken all the good aspects of that and improved on them by adding classes, loot and collectables to improve the chances of getting better loot.

However, that’s not to say that this game doesn’t have faults. I have experienced a number of graphical glitches where instead of heads being severed, the neck will extend with the head giving the character models a kind of crazy giraffe effect.  Clipping issues where I would for whatever reason get stuck in the ground or in a wall resulting in me either having to hope a special unit comes and kills me or I quickly reconnect (no good if I have a grimoire on me).

Speaking of the special units, the 5 that they have got (gutter runner, packmaster, poison wind globadier, ratling gunner, rat ogre)…. Let’s face it, they are direct copy and pastes of the Left 4 Dead specials. (in order, hunter, smoker, boomer…. Ok so the ratling gun is new but the rat ogre is the same as the tank). Vermintide even has its own version of the witch in the form of a patrol of Stormvermin (which should be avoided at all costs, especially on harder difficulties).

I would STRONGLY recommend first playing this in a private server by yourself with 3 bots on easy to understand how the game works, get used to combat, how to dodge/block, when ogres are going to appear so that you know not to pick up the grimoire till afterwards (as it reduces your health). This in itself is not fun and does not give a good representation of the game BUT it means that you learn the basics in your own time and will not be a burden to your team. Remember this is a team game, you do not want to be the one that holding everyone else back.

I hope this game continues to be as highly supported as it has been so far. It could do with some extra maps, more varied weapons and maybe dare I say it…microtransactions for skins (and I mean ONLY skins). I say this so that there is a flow of money that could be used for developments/free dlc etc…. but… we will see what happens when the expansions come out.

All in all, a pleasant surprise and would highly recommend

reviewText:
If I could leave a neutral review on this particular game, I probably would.

If you're looking for a melee-focused, first-person, shield-and-slash kind of loot-farming L4D-like game, this game's for you.

I've played enough of this game to have a lot of fun with it, but this is one of those games that's almost unplayable without people/friends. Sometimes there's not enough teamwork to succeed either, and eventually you might just get tired of playing the same maps over and over with very little entertaining end-game. Some players might continue though, because of the randomized loot system, which, although randomized, still feels pretty rewarding. Sometimes.

CONTENT AND MISSIONS - There's a bit of a lack of content for Vermintide, not that there isn't enough to feel like a 'full' game, but you'll end up replaying maps quite soon into it. This is sort of to be expected of an early access title, but it needs more missions to play somewhat badly. Also, I think the game should be finished and released out of early access before they start making paid DLC's. Sure, the first is only $2.99, but it's a slippery slope.

But on the topic of missions, it almost feels like the variety doesn't matter since most people just run Horn of Magnus to grind loot, with a handful of other missions... It's a little disheartening for only 1 mission to be played so consistently.

TEAMWORK - You'll probably spend the first 10 hours having fun and learning the game's mechanics. After that, you'll try your hand at the Hard, Nightmare, and Cataclysmic difficulties, as there isn't much of a point to run Normal or Easy difficulty if you want good loot. Sometimes you'll get teamed up with people who fall all at once and fail the mission, but you'll just have to keep at it to get better. Along with that, the bots are sadly not a viable alternative. In my early playtime, I tried to play Horn of Magnus on NORMAL with bots, got to the elevator at the end, where 1 rat hit me, knocked me to the ground so I'd need a revive, and Kerillian (the Elf bot) and Bardin (the Dwarf bot) just stood over my corpse, they didn't help me up.

LOOT - Next 20-30 hours, you'll get some Greens (Commons) and Blues (Rares), an Orange (Exotic), maybe even 1 or 2 Trinkets, which really help out as their effects are independent of the Hero you're playing. These'll help you survive and deal better damage.

But I have some extreme gripes with the rewards system, as you collect special dice in missions that are used at the end to get a random reward of a loot item. It's either a weapon or a trinket, but on a very rare chance, it's a hat. But in order to get even this chance, you have to BEAT the mission, make it ALL THE WAY to the end and succeed. If you don't, all you get is exp, and even if you make it to the end but DON'T beat it, all you get is 8 CRAFTING TOKENS. The dice give you better chances at getting higher tiers of loot, but only if you win. And even then you might not get loot for the character(s) you play.

Overall, it's a really fun and hectic game. It's visually great and pretty fun when things go right, but it's not without problems.

reviewText:
Do you like L4D2 sort of horde gameplay? Would you wish it had emphasis on melee instead of ranged weapons? Do you like the idea of killing ratmen? Do you NOT require a vs mode? If so, this is the game for you!

For a relatively low price you get an awesome way to kill your time in co-op horde gameplay. Vermintide is hard but rewarding on higher difficulties, forcing you to pay attention to crowd control as you methodologically hack the ratmen to pieces. The different weapons offer significant changes to gameplay, and there's enough of them to offer you something refreshing when you want to mix things up a bit. I'm not sure if the axes are quite on par with the others on higher difficulties, but maybe I've just not learned to cc well by relying on pushes or to take advantage of the other player's cc. Even so, I find the axes to be most satisfying weapons and just go for lower difficulties when I want to use them.

Loot grind used to be more grindy than it is, but with the introduction of the Last Stand mode it's easier to upgrade the gear you like to the higher levels. Even so I'd recommend enjoying the gameplay and taking the loot as an additional creaming on the cake, offering nice rewards that open up new options as you play.

If you like the genre or are intrigued, I think you will most likely enjoy this game.

reviewText:
Extremely fun cooperative action game, similar to Left 4 Dead. To say its a clone of Left 4 Dead I think does a disservice to this game. The game does enough where it sets itself apart from Left 4 Dead.

The levels are fun, and the loot although it can be frustating at times, gives a reason for replayability. The difficulty in the game doesn't come from cheapness, but from player skill. When you first start you'll think the highest difficulty level is genuinely impossible to do, but as time goes on you feel yourself getting better at the game and figuring out tactics and strategy with your party.

With that said, the game is alright to play with random people, but truly shines when you have friends to play with especially if you can all play it consistently.

I look forward to any expansions or additional content. At the price as well, I don't feel uncomfortable paying for DLC provided its substantial enough and looks fun. When it comes to cooperative fun, all other games are Umgak.

reviewText:
TL;DR - This game is awesome. You should be playing it.

Ok, now for real:

Visuals: This game visually looks amazing. The team did an amazing job with cramming tons of detail into everything in this game.

Emersion: You really feel like you are a warrior/mage/whatever trying to help this city against an invading monster race. It's simplistic, but nails it in most aspects.

Story: The story is super simple, but if you're playing this game for the story then you probably shouldn't buy it. You pick up tons of small details about the story as you play the levels, but it's not a story driven game.

Combat: WOAH! Awesome...

Conclusion: I have never been so entranced by a midevil styled game before. Honestly they usually bore me, but this game is stellar so far.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Ok, I understand how some people have said that this game is more of a left 4 dead feel. It totally is 100% like left 4 dead. You have special classes that represent left 4 dead special infected. The game is really fun with friends but with randoms it is meh. I will go down a list to show the variants and how left 4 dead is similar in the parenthesis since vermintide is the main topic here.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-Gutter Runner (Hunter)
-Globe Lobber(kinda like the Boomer only thing is that this one deals damage over time without the mobs)
-Skaven Ogre(Tank)
-Packmaster (Smoker)
-Ratling Gunner (I would compare this to a witch only thing different is that the agro is instant when spotted)
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The game also has a levelling system in it that will give you items that you get after a certain level. There are also slots that open in customizing your character that will eventually open up items for you to use. For instance, you are a level 4 or below and there is a trinket slot that opens at level 5. (this is just an example, I don’t remember if that trinket slot is open in any certain level… more than likely not) you go to the end of a campaign and you roll for your loot (we’ll get back with that later) and you don’t see any trinkets that drop along the bar. But you have just levelled up to five and you get to roll and there is a trinket that is now droppable in the rolling sequence. If you have the slot open for a specific item, there is a fair chance that you would be able to get the loot drop for that slot when you have it unlocked for that level. Simpler terms, you get what you can use and you don’t get what you can’t even equip yet.

Now, about this rolling, every single time you finish a mission successfully you get to make rolls. In each mission depending on which one it is, you get to come across these items that can help boost up your roll.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-Tomes  (+100 xp and adds one die with more successful sides when rolled)
-Loot die (basic loot die that adds ontop of your normal 6 die pool)
-Grimoire (reducing the party health by 33% and is consumable. Once consumed it will make the waves harder and you wont get the guaranteed roll on the guaranteed one die you get if you don’t consume it.)

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Certain characters have certain traits about them that follow with the Warhammer age of sigmar realm or time. The elf is snarky towards the dwarf, the witch hunter is no fan of anyone but the soldier, the soldier is the all around whatever human that just chops ♥♥♥♥, the dwarf is not a fan of the magic that the wizard can conjure, and it is just overall an odd alliance.

Now for you people wondering if there will be DLC’s coming out. I honestly don’t know but once you finish the only acts that are available, which hits at the maximum of four, there is an ending cutscene that certainly leaves and opening for other DLC content and I for one am excited for it.

This game is the first game of Warhammer that I have ever owned. I knew about it and played a lot of D&D and I enjoyed the lore. After playing this, I most definitely want to move over to the lore in Warhammer Age of Sigmar. If you enjoy good ol swordplay with specific roles and classes and love the left 4 dead playstyle… get this game… I highly recommend it. I wouldn’t say that this game is the best co op game cause I will say that Payday 2 is more up on my scale but this game is really fun. Out of 5 stars I would give this game a 4/5.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Warhammer: End Times- Vermintide is a COOP FPS survival game with five playable heroes (four of which are in a game at any given time) against a merciless tide of Ratmen. The game plays quite similarly to the Left 4 Dead franchise, which is great for those already familiar with the gameplay there. Different weapon types for each Hero offer a great deal of variety, and the upgrades you can get to these weapon can differ from those that another person gets from an identical weapon, making no two weapons alike (For the most part). Loot quality is improved by collecting certain items throughout a map to be rolled as dice at the end. I've had no frustrations with the items I've gotten, and I was able to hold my own on Hard mode the second I started this game without much trouble. I haven't experienced much in the way of bugs, and the 13 different levels offer a variety in the areas you play in.\n\nIn conclusion? Buy it. You probably won't regret it.

reviewText: Tough game. Players are thrown into the game with no idea of how hard it is. Many players will fail their first few games because of this, and it turns them off from the game. The game itself is pretty cool. I really like the setting, and the graphics are good. Missions are REALLY long, usually around 30 minutes for one mission. If you don't play with friends, just hope and pray you find an expierienced player or two, because new players really pull down the team. There is a decent amount of missions, gamemodes, and enemies. Events are generated randomly, so you don't know what will be waiting for you. Loot system is interesting. In order to get good loot at the end of the mission, you have to find in-game items hidden throughout the mission which make the mission  itself harder by reducing total health and taking up the potion slot. They increase the chance of a higher level item. This system is good in theory, but it leads players to play the same mission over and over and over because they know the locations of these hidden items. This gets pretty boring, and if you fail the mission it is very irritating. It's fun for a while. 6/10

reviewText:
This game is basically Left 4 Dead: Exterminator Edition.
Pros:
Every weapon feels satisfying to swing, or shoot. The crunch of a rat skull under a warhammer will send shivers down your spine.
All 5 characters feel unique, and because groups are made up of four, you'll never get stuck without a choice.
Unrelenting difficult at higher levels unless you work as a team and communicate effectively.
It will make you tense up. You will be anxious, wondering when the rat ogre is going to show up.
Rat Ogres.
When you win, you'll feel like you've earned it.
Gear doesn't make the player. Skill does.
No pay to win at all.
Free DLC.
Cons
Not all weapons are made equal. While they can all be fun, only some are viable on harder difficulties.
Communicating with a public group can be brutal. Better hope they all know what they're doing on the highest difficulties.
Tutorial? We don't need no stinkin' tutorial.
No dedicated servers, if a host drops you restart the level. Bad lag can end a good run.
The loot system isn't generous, and you will be underwhelmed at times.
The rats have gatling guns.
All in all, I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed L4D, or is interested in a co-op game that will have you at the edge of your seat cheering (or cursing) your friends as you wade through a sea of bipedal rodents with medieval weaponry against all odds.

reviewText:
This is the true game of the year. Altough it does not feature as much content as a blockbuster fallout 4 this team still made the most solid game I have played in a lot of days. I cannot emphasis how right combat feels in this game, and how good the challenge level is. If you exit the comfort zone and play hard, you WILL have a hard experience. You will fail with your team, but the sweetness of finally clearing a level makes up for it.

Not only have they nailed the gameplay, but they release FREE DLC. From a businiess stand point this makes little sense, but from a quality stand point it's spot on. The game industry is decaying, favoring business plans and advertising over quality. I am glad to see that Fatshark goes against this trend, holding their ground and setting up an example for other game developers and publishers.

Graphics are not exceptional, but quite excellent non the less. Audio is great as well. The atmosphere makes you feel like your really in a murky city where a terrible war(slaughter) broke out from beneath. The weapons are varied, and you will find what suits your individual taste the best.

For the best experience, get some good friends and buy this game.
You will get your moneys worth two-fold if you're into co-operative survival games.
BUY IT AND THEN BUY IT AGAIN AND GIFT IT TO YOUR MOM AND CAT
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: Gonna give a tenative thumbs up for now. I like the game but it is pretty difficult to finish on higher difficulty without a coordinated team, which means basically stick together and hit everything in sight. There does not seem to be a lot of sophisticated tactics involved in the game or the environment at the moment. Occasionally you will use a bow or gun to snipe a difficult mob from a distance but the A.I. for the most part just focuses on constant zerg as it's main tactic. Graphics are nice and mindless combat can be fun but hopefully there is more planned in the future and the weapon upgrades become a little more dynamic. Right now I would give is a 3/5 with potential to increase moving forward.\n\nOne more thing every time a major Skaven rush occurs it seems the only objective is to find the rearest wall, put your back to it and swing your sword at the onslaught until the vermin are all dead. It can be fun and intense in a viseral way, but lacks depth and sophistication.

reviewText:
To sum it up, it's Left For Dead's gameplay in a Warhammer setting with a few twists.

As with Left for Dead you're stuck in a city overrun by an endless horde of monstrosities. (In this case, it's the rat-men known as Skaven)
You and 3 buddies are charged with completing a variety of missions such as collecting supplies and gunpowder for the resistance, clearing paths for smugglers through the sewers or destroying Skaven war machines in their own camp ets.
In each you will be faced by a variety of enemies ranging from tiny, one-hit to kill, slave rat hordes to massive Rat Ogres who can soak up damage like a drunkard soaks up alcohol.

It's enjoyable and can become quite challenging at higher difficulties with more enemies and less pickups. (Even friendly fire is an option.)
There's a decent variety of weapons and classes to try out ensuring there'll always be something to suite your playstyle.

It's not perfect mind you, there's a bug or two that pops up every now and then but they're small enough to ignore or share a giggle at. Otherwise this game is good entertainment at a reasonable price.

Recommended for anyone who enjoys taking on hordes of enemies with a handful of friends but is tired of zombies.

reviewText:
Left 4 Rats 3 - The Vermining; A lot of people compare this game to L4D, and rightly so. It's almost a perfect clone. I know this because I've read nearly every review on Steam for it. Consumer research folks. I don't say the former in a negative light though. Left 4 Dead was / still is one of my favorite games, and one of the few online multiplayers I've sank any time into. Instead of making vermin jokes and talking about the similarities of the two titles, I'll leave some footnotes;

Pros:
+ It's fun with all one other person I know who plays it. (if you're reading this, add me, I'm not total trash at it) We beat the story mode, and all the side missions and had a ball. Even when we died horribly.

+ The learning curve isn't so steep that new players are handicapped at the start screen. (Smite...).  Kill stuff, beat the mission, and get a new (sometimes dupe) weapon, or Trinket. Revel in glory, and repeat.

+ The random encouters make each run feel different, as with the random item spawns. It makes you have to adapt to the situation, and adds some excitement. Nothing makes you crap harder to burn all your ammo on trash enemies for fun, only to be met with a Rat-Ogre around the corner.

+ The sound design is great. The enemies feel 'alive' right before you turn them into paste with a hammer. Their little squeeks and insults are darling. It's worth mentioning that the enviromental effects are also very good. Lightning sounds like lightning. The steel sword clinks when it his armor. It's all very well done.

+ Level load times are quick, considering the size of the maps. Im sure they load mostly on the fly, but it doesn't hiccup when the map is being generated. I'd take one big map over 5-6 little grinder maps. Keeps me engaged in the game more, I think. 2-3 of the maps feel similar, but aren't purposed the same. i/e One may be a straight run, while another is a objective (protect / destroy target), and another may be an item collection mission.

Neut:
= I run a potato, so I have no idea what the game 'should' look like.

= The 360 controls, while better for dodging attacks, feel sloppy. KB controls just fine.

= It's Left 4 Dead with rats. Special / Boss enemies are entirely transparent to that extent. It works though. [oops]

= The end-game loot system / character progression doesnt break anything, balance wise.

= The in-game 'Tomes' and 'Grims' you can collect is hard to do with less than 3 human players. You can manipulate the bots into carrying one, but it's a chore making sure they dont dump it for a medki- Health potion. So your end game rewards often suffer as a result.

= Has hats... At least there's no pay to win B/S. Item crafting works well enough, despite the grind it takes to get anything worth while. It's slow, but atleast it's all in-game, and not credit card dependant.

Cons:
- The game does not feel finished, not to the point of a gold code release (1.0+). I dont have a top-end machine, I have a morgage. I have all the settings down to potato, and there are times when the game dips to 10-15 fps. I can only deduce that there is some engine problems, that I HOPE get fixed / patched / what have you.
---->  If I can run Fallout 4 on 'med' at [read; playable] 45+ fps, than antything else should run at atleast 30+ on low. And Fo4 is optimized like pure ♥♥♥♥.


- Often times, you will run right into a random enemy pack spawn, and as a player, really breaks the flow of things. It looks like a blackhole is giving birth to 100 Jimmy Falons'. SOME GAMES are much better at enemy spawns, you know, like L4- nevermind. Either way, that shouldn't happen. It just looks / plays gross.

- The bots. Period. I know it's meant to be played online with people. But still, there's no excuse for how dumb they are. If I want to be a socio, and not play on a team, I shouldn't witness death, after defeat, after death, because the bots thought transversing the map to kill a Gas-Rat was Delta-Level 5 Mission Priority.

Overall;
I feel like this could, and should be a household name like it's older, uglier brother 'Lefty'. It's fun, addictive, and has tons of replay value. I know I personally have to upgrade my setup, but despite that I have a good time playing. Maybe I'll wet my feet into an actual 4 man game. Until then, pardon me while I go scoure the wasteland for glue...

8/10 - notIGN

While the special boss" enemies all aren't too original
date: that's really not the point of this game. It's derivative but it's also a lot of fun. Even with strangers. Lopping heads and arms off ratmen never really gets old.\n\nThe only disappointing part of this game is the lack of maps to go through and the declining community. Perhaps the developer needs to release more DLC more quickly because the loot system is amazing
recommended: the world is rich and the characters that you play as are all quite unique.\n\nI highly recommend giving this game a try. Just hope you have some people on your friend's list with it or you may have trouble finding a match unless you play above Normal difficulty."

reviewText:
This game is basically Left 4 Dead: Exterminator Edition.
Pros:
Every weapon feels satisfying to swing, or shoot. The crunch of a rat skull under a warhammer will send shivers down your spine.
All 5 characters feel unique, and because groups are made up of four, you'll never get stuck without a choice.
Unrelenting difficult at higher levels unless you work as a team and communicate effectively.
It will make you tense up. You will be anxious, wondering when the rat ogre is going to show up.
Rat Ogres.
When you win, you'll feel like you've earned it.
Gear doesn't make the player. Skill does.
No pay to win at all.
Free DLC.
Cons
Not all weapons are made equal. While they can all be fun, only some are viable on harder difficulties.
Communicating with a public group can be brutal. Better hope they all know what they're doing on the highest difficulties.
Tutorial? We don't need no stinkin' tutorial.
No dedicated servers, if a host drops you restart the level. Bad lag can end a good run.
The loot system isn't generous, and you will be underwhelmed at times.
The rats have gatling guns.
All in all, I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed L4D, or is interested in a co-op game that will have you at the edge of your seat cheering (or cursing) your friends as you wade through a sea of bipedal rodents with medieval weaponry against all odds.

reviewText:
My first Warhammer game. Its basically Left 4 Dead 2 with giant rats, a focus on melee combat, classes, and loot.

So far my only complaints are the occassional bugs I've seen involving teleporting and flying skaven specials, and the fact that certain weapons like the handgun and blunderbuss don't have reloading animations, they just move off the screen like how weapons in Star Wars Battlefront 2 would in first person. Its kinda awkward and makes it difficult to tell how much longer the reload will take, but I'm sure it won't bother some people.

Desync has a habit of instantly killing you for whatever reason. Pretty annoying.

As someone who actually didn't enjoy L4D2 that much, so far I've had a lot of fun with Vermintide. I'll update the review more once I've played a bit more.

reviewText:
To sum it up, it's Left For Dead's gameplay in a Warhammer setting with a few twists.

As with Left for Dead you're stuck in a city overrun by an endless horde of monstrosities. (In this case, it's the rat-men known as Skaven)
You and 3 buddies are charged with completing a variety of missions such as collecting supplies and gunpowder for the resistance, clearing paths for smugglers through the sewers or destroying Skaven war machines in their own camp ets.
In each you will be faced by a variety of enemies ranging from tiny, one-hit to kill, slave rat hordes to massive Rat Ogres who can soak up damage like a drunkard soaks up alcohol.

It's enjoyable and can become quite challenging at higher difficulties with more enemies and less pickups. (Even friendly fire is an option.)
There's a decent variety of weapons and classes to try out ensuring there'll always be something to suite your playstyle.

It's not perfect mind you, there's a bug or two that pops up every now and then but they're small enough to ignore or share a giggle at. Otherwise this game is good entertainment at a reasonable price.

Recommended for anyone who enjoys taking on hordes of enemies with a handful of friends but is tired of zombies.

The only thing I want to see from this game is more of this game.... And a 40k version....

reviewText:
I've been playing Vermintide since it officially launched, and I have to say that I am thoroughly in love. This game has all of the finer elements from the Left 4 Dead franchise that made it so replayable, and it puts them through the filter of the gritty Warhammer Fantasy universe. As a long time fan of Warhammer and Warhammer 40k, I am always watching for titles with the franchise name and giving them a thorough investigation before I would ever deem something that fell within my all time favorite fantasy universe great simply for having the name attached. Vermintide for sure delivers. You truly are pitted against the hordes of Skaven set during the End Times and it feels like a constant struggle to mix quick movement with thoughtful decision making. Sometimes you see a patrol that can easily be avoided or fought in a fierce melee, while other times you are moving safely through back alleys and suddenly a Gutter Runner has one of your party on the ground and a Packmaster is dragging another away and your group now dances on the knife edge of a full on wipe. These moments come all too often and really bring a good life to the game.

The loot system is another thing I found pretty interesting and acceptable. Loot is only earned on a successful mission completion, so it truly does force one to not rush forward hastily, however taking more time seems to draw in more ambushes and waves which can easily grow overwhelming.

Positioning is an important aspect of the game and is to be used at all times.

I really REALLY hope they make some Chaos force maps or other evil force DLC's, because thats what I think we'd all love to see.

Cons: The cons I do have are mostly with the servers and hosting. There is NO dedicated hosting, so hosts are on a player by player basis, which means that if your host decides to up and leave 3/4 through the mission, you are restarted back at the beginning of the mission with another player as the new host.

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying I've never played Warhammer or Left 4 Dead. Matchmaking FPS's are not my thing and I do not like them.

With that being said, I absolutely love this game. I have stuck with my dwarf sword/board so far and even though right now in beta there are only 3 maps. The game has great replayability.

I will admit sometimes the hitboxes are weird with my ranged weapon and a few little glitches here and there, but nothing game breaking. The AI for the bots is very good, if you get stuck with them. It doesn't feel like you're escorting them.

The game has gear slots that you obtain through running these maps. Higher difficulty = Better chance at loot.
Slots include head, weapon, ranged, and 3 trinkets.

I really hope in the future we get a little more to customize our character, even if it's just cosmetic.

The combat feels like a fast paced and more responsive version of Skyrims combat.
The maps do a very good job at moving along, without feeling like that linear arcade style story.

Very happy with my purchase. I wasn't so sure at whether or not this would be something I would enjoy, but took a shot in the dark and it paid off. I hope the development team continues to make content/DLC/expansions for this game.

reviewText:
Vermintide takes the L4D formula and improved on it tremendously. It is just as unpredictable and replayable with the added loot mechanism. The loot system is pure RnG and with my luck, I rarely get good rolls - but I try not to get hung up with the loot. I still unlock and find enough weapons to give my plays some variety. It is not a Diablo replacement for me, but an improved L4D. A good communicative team with a strong common understanding is far more important in this game.

The level designs are top notch and the maps are full of detail which create interesting atmosphere. The sound and music complements the action exceptionally well. I've played about 6 maps so far and i've been impressed with all of them. The Skaven AI do behave like the sneaky and cunning vermin they are - creeping up or dropping behind you to steal a stab in your back. They are annoying and extremely satisfying to butcher en masse.

The melee combat is impactful and satisfying. Far more so than L4D's. Also, getting quick ranged headshots and clever item use is more crucial than ever to survive. Many of the special Skavens like the gutter runners, ratling gunners and pack masters are really overpowered against individual heroes. They can easily take out a straggling player. This game can be unforgiving even at normal difficulties and requires good team tactics to succeed. Try playing alone with the (weak)AI BOTs on your side and you'll realize just having 3 more characters fighting on its own will easily get all of you killed. This game is not to be enjoyed as a single player game.

In terms of bugs - there are still some weird stuff like mobs hitting you through walls, clipping animation and fps drops when things get really busy, but otherwise I havent encountered anything gamebreaking. To me, it is a good game for a fair price at this stage. I just hope the developers will continue to be generous with content and reasonable with the pricing for future content. This game and Fat Shark has tremendous potential and I would love to keep playing this game for some time to come.

Would try to swim in game and die instantly again - 9.5/10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
GREAT GAME
Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide  is an all-around great and entertaining game that has a lot of content and with a great sound track and stunning visuals, along with plenty of atmosphere, which is never bad.

This game combines some of the best qualities of online team play and zombie (skaven in this case) butchering creating this amazing product. Each player has a choice from five champions, each with unique abilities and weapons to choose from. In each level you play you have a certain goal you need to accomplish as a team where you will also be fighting waves upon waves of various skaven. At the end of each successful level, there is also a great random loot system based on how successful you were.

Although much of the game is fast paced, occasionally stopping and looking at the surroundings is  amazing ; you can clearly tell that the developers put a ton of work into this.

The developers in this game are always trying to improve the game and add new content
☆☆☆☆☆☆☆ 7/7

reviewText: Granted, Vermintide gets a huge Warhammer bonus in my book. I have always loved the setting and I'm love the game's atmosphere - the surroundings, sound and the banter between the heroes.\nDetached from my fanboy-ish love, Vermintide is a really fun game. It's fast, it's brutal and it's challenging, even on the lower difficulties. Usually compared to L4D, the similarities between those games are indesputable and it is quite obvious where Vermintide took its inspiration. In my opinion, however, it is the better game - of equal rank, at the very least, I assume, if you don't feel strongly about the setting. Obviously, meele combat is a huge part of the game, so get upclose, ♥♥♥♥♥♥, and don't buy Vermintide if you're looking for L4D or Ewww-volve like shooting action. There are ranged weapons and they are fun, but let's face it: nothing is as fun as a hammer to the face. If you're the owner of the hammer, not the face...\nOne thing you should bring into the streets of Ubersreik are friends. The bots, while not half bad, are bots and the randoms are...way worse than the bots. People who behave as stupid as they (probably) look, with the sole purpose to make other players' lives miserable. If, however, you happen to bring your buddies along, you're gonna have a fun time with lots of action, gore and dead rat-things.

reviewText: Played during free weekend - its one of the best games I ever played! L4Dead feels boring childish point-and-shooty arcade comparing to this!\n\nPeople whining about horrible" loot system

reviewerDisplayName: LITERALLY DOG SHIT AT THIS GAME
reviewText:
Product received for free

This is a fun game, but I feel like the player base is too small to justify even the sale price.

The graphics are good
The game ran fine without FPS issues. I got into a few games with bad hosts and that really ruins the game since the AI tends to lag real bad and do nothing.

This game has no host migration. I was on that level where you have to grab the black powder canisters and we had 7/8 of them. The host got knocked down and on the middle of us killing the mob on him he rage quit and we had to do the whole thing over.

The melee weapons appear to be hit scan weapons. The bolts have no drop they shoot like a laser beam. You really do not even need to use zoom since a single body shot with most of the ranged kills.

The RNG based weapon acquisition is complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Sorry I don't want to play Destiny: Warhammer edition.

reviewText:
I simply have to add that this is NOT like L4D. Sure its 4 player co op but there is no versus (which for me always was the most fun), no mods and for new maps you will have to pay. No fan made content!

I am however a big fan of the Warhammer universe and coop and I had a ton of fun during the free weekend. However lacking the things stated above one will indeed get tired way to quickly. I would recommend it on sale and if you have friends to play with. Even I will probably end up buying it at some sale. It was however a dissapointment that the new DLC didnt add new enemies. I mean really? 9 euro for a couple of new maps?

I played L4D 1 and 2 for hundreds of hours and I still play the second one at times. Why? Because they offer a lot more and being zombies creates diversity. As well as being 4v4 is more fun then you versus a computer all the time. It would be really cool to add a 4v4 to this game and it would have given it a longer lifespan.

I recommend the game on sale for people who like coop but how a guy put 246 hours into this I have no idea. I lost my main interest after a few knowing the game would mainly be the same after that point.

reviewText:
This game is absolutley one of my favorite First-Person games I've played in a couple years. I love the combat system in this
game, though it may remind you of a certain series (Left 4 Dead, also one of my favorite games of all time). Using the lore of Warhammer: End Times is a great concept and though I am prasing this game I still have some issues with it. So here is my list of Pros and Cons with the game.

Pros: 1. The combat system: The use of both hand to hand and ranged weapons in the game gives that since of immersion that a lot of FPS' don't have these days.

2. The lore: I myself didn't know a lot about Warhammer lore before I played this game, as a matter of fact I was hyped about it because of the new Total War title that was coming out. After playing 5 hours of this game I was hooked, I researched a lot about Warhammer fantasy and now I'm looking at 40K(and it is amazing)!

Cons:
1. Repetition: Like it says though I've only played 15 hours of this game and it is not because I don't like it, I love this game. The reason I don't play this game like I used to is because I just got repetitive. The main villian of the game are known as the Skaven, ( giant rat people) and its like Left 4 Dead in the sense that you fight the same enemies ever level.
Same bosses, same infantry, the one redeeming factor about this is that you can counter the enemies quickly.

2. The Grind: This part of the game makes me sad. To get descent weapons you are going to have to play the same levels
over and over and over again just to get enough XP and gemstones to upgrade and get loot. With the each DLC comes more objectives and weapons, but to get them takes close to 8 hours of grinding. My group of friends and I would try and get loot and it took us 4 hours of playing the same exact levels! That is a major problem with this game.

Overall, this game is great for the price and it will definitely provide you with hours of fun and grinding
83/100

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying this game is fantastic. It is NOT just a re-skin of L4D. There is so much more to it than that. Every character/class is unique in their own way, whereas in L4D all the characters are pretty much the same. Even the 'Specials' have their own unique flavor, AND they correspond to actual units used in the Warhammer Fantasy Skaven army, which is pretty darn cool. And not only are the classes different, but they all get types of weapons that are completely unique to their class, too.

I do have a problem, though. So recently, my brother let me play this game on his super beefy gaming computer. The game ran like a dream; 75 fps running it on Extreme (this game's version of Ultra). The game was immersive and atmospheric. There were no bugs whatsoever, and it was fantasticly fun.
Skip to me playing on my less-than-beefy laptop. I'm having to play this game on lowest at a reduced resolution than what is native to my laptop, and I know it sounds ridiculous, but i feel like lowering the graphics hinders the performance of the game. A whole slew of bugs that weren't there before emerged when i began playing on my laptop. Skaven would spawn in heaps and not even move; just waiting for me to pull out my blunderbuss and shred them all to pieces. A rat ogre even spawned on a rooftop! The bots were unbelievably stupid (they were already pretty dumb, but here they were even dumber). It was so strange. A game that previously had been almost flawless was rendered buggy and far less fun to play.

So my summary? This game is fantastic.... when it works correctly. I can't think of any instance where a game's graphics cause it to function incorrectly, but that really seems to be the problem here. I still recommend it because i've seen what it can be.
My brother and I haven't had a chance to play online yet, so i've only played local with bots. But i'll update this review if these problems listed above persist when we play online.

reviewText:
Vermintide is one of those rare games where it's pretty much a rip-off of a great game but where it expands upon it in pretty much all the right places, and underline that pretty much. The Warhammer setting works amazingly with the L4D2 gameplay, and the slight changes over the special enemies combined with the different class purpouse system, with 5 different classes to choose from, adds an RPG like feel to the whole game that really makes you appreciate the effort of the developers in keeping the game as close as possible to the Warhammer universe. Bombs, health packs and potions, all remind you of the '09 valve classic that inspires this game and it's pretty much a blast to go back to campaigning with your friends against countless enemies, scarse supplies and the all new quest for the sweet old loot introduced in Vermintide. The five difficulty levels on each level also add to the replay value, aswell as improving your loot and rewards from completing missions.

Teamwork is essencial in Vermintide and, pretty much as L4D, its live toguether or die alone. Small aditions like patrols to hide from, loot mice running arround and special tokens that increase your end-level rewards also add a fresh feel to the game to break from the monotonous routine of doing the same levels over and over again. The levels themselves come extremely well designed, with 13 very well crafted levels that brings the city of Ubersreik to life in a very dark, gritty way and that follow the journey of five heroes trying to save the town in the Warhammer: End Times setting. The sound design is very good aswell, creating an enjoyable atmosphere throughout the gameplay. The games controls are very much like L4D's with improved, more visceral melee combat that makes combat a very fun experience, with body parts flying arround and piles of corpses painted with blood crowding the heroes as they follow their missions. At the end of each turn, you earn experience towards your player level, something which seems to have no effect other than an ego-booster but it's fun to watch your number grow. The search for loot is also one of the games most atractive points, making you strive for better gear and making your risk leave behind health supplies, or even health points, in order to bring back special Tomes and Grimoires that make your end-mission loot better.

The game is not, however, perfect in what it attempts to do. One of L4D2's most incredible parts was the Director 2.0 AI that pretty much reacted to every move you made in your matches, creating uniquely balanced, varied and challenging experiences for the players and at the same time improving the overall replay value of the game due to how enjoyable it made it. While I find Vermintides AI competent, I think at some point it proved to be quite unbalanced in some aspects, and I won't talk about the usual BOT mind numbness. The game can at some point attack you with large number of very, very difficult opponents, from Rat Patrols to Ogres, and at some points I've met the game sending them all at once against an already debilitated team with very scarce supplies. While I appreciate a challenge, several times I came across impossible to go through situations that would be impossible even at full health, at least in the Nightmare or harder difficulties. Some balancing issues in the technical department make the game run not-so-well in it's highest graphical settings, with unstable framerates plaguing it at some points, something on which the developers seem to be working on, to their credit. Some bugs and exploits are also yet to be fixed, but two patches since the game and its release make me hopefull that the developers are fully aware of the incredible potential of their own game. The games loot system, besides being one of the games most fun mechanics, is also one of the most frustrating due to how limited it is in your part in the looting process. At the end of each match, you roll a set of dice that decide which reward you get from a pre-set random scale of items. Although the items themselves are varied and well designed, the system makes it very hard for you to collect the pieces you want, and it's so frustrating to see that item you so desperately need be lost due to you rolling your dice not too low, but too high!

Overall, Vermintide is a wonderful game full of personality, grit, violence, teamwork and fun. If you enjoy collecting loot, killing mice, RPG-like classes, spending time at an inn jumping arround while you wait for your next mission in your quest to save Ubersreik, L4D's gameplay, the Warhammer setting or any of those combined, then you'll probably love this game. It has it's flaws, but it's also being developed by a dedicated independent team that has struck gold with their revival of one of Valve's most revered classics, and I hope they continue to improve their already great game. The memories Vermintide brings back are priceless, the long nights of L4D2 campaigning, victory, defeat and frustration were sorely missed by gamers all over, and this game's just right to fill that space until valve releases some info on the third instalement of their series. Whether you play alone or with your friends, you'll find many hours of excitement and fun in Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide.

8/10

reviewText:
Vermintide. This is one crazy game. Sadly overlooked by many with the imminent release of Fallout 4 (understanderbly), it's like LFD2 cranked up to the max. Gore everywhere, levelling systems, crafting (although basic) and sweet loot later on.

You've got five characters to choose from - a gun-wielding swordsman, a wood elf archer, a ridiculously fun Bright Mage (fire mage, basically), a chubby dwarf tank chap, and a two-handed imperial swordsman. They all play differently and there's some great synergy in the smooth four-player coop modes. You can also play with bots, if you like.

Overall a rather brutal and intense game, but hey, it's only rats you're killing, so it's fine, right? Recommended.

reviewText:
I still didn't understand what kind of game this was, but what attracted me to it was the graphics, the art design, the theme, and the up close brutal combat. I had no idea it is actually secretly a better current Left 4 Dead. It is Left 4 Dead with the theme you see in the trailer. Instead of zombies, you get rat people. It is JUST like Left 4 Dead, but it is new and instead of guns, you have different classes, each with their own ranged weapon types and melee weapon types. Each class so far from what I have seen, have two different types of weapons you can have, maybe more, same goes for ranged weapons as well I assume, haven't seen those yet. There is also a sort of random loot system as well.

It has that great co-op fun feeling as L4D had. It doesn't feel like a reskinned version, not by a long shot, but it takes all the great elements that made L4D fun, and makes it a different theme, and it makes it much more challenging and diverse. I highly recommend this to everyone that likes co-op centered games. Of course you can play by yourself with bots, but it is the same as playing L4D with bots, and therefore not recommended.

Get this game. It is beautiful and fun as hell. I hope they keep working on this game and release more player classes.

reviewText:
This game is often described as left4dead but with rats. I don't think that does it justice. Vermintide plays more like a cross between Payday 2 and Skyrim.

I say Skyrim because melee combat is a mechanical focus and is executed so that it's easy to pick up and hard to master. Payday 2 is a mention for me because of the team challenge factor Vermintide features. Careful communication and teamplay is absolutely necessary in the higher difficulties and even on normal-hard when picking up Grimlores.

Vermintide has left me wanting more of everything it provides: haunting and intruiging level design, fun and interesting characters, a diverse range of special enemies and quirky AI. Having said that, the game isn't at all lacking in content or replayability and is worth its full price as is.
