reviewText:
The dark and gritty fantasy world of Vermintide should make any Warhammer fans right at home. You find yourself in Ubersreik; a large human city in shambles while being overrun by large rat-like creatures known as the Skaven.

This game takes inspiration from a few big games, the most noticeable being Left4Dead. (Which is not a bad thing) There aren't many games out there like L4D, and since I've been praying for L4D3 to come out for years now, I'm happy to see another developer make a L4D style game so well. That's not to say this game is just a reskin of existing games. Vermintide has a fun and easy to jump in to combat system, making use of many weapons from daggers to giant war hammers and even to flaming combustion magic if you choose to play as the Bright Wizard.

Vermintide also sports an interesting loot system. The 5 classes all start with completely different weapons that all function differently and have different stats. As you complete campaigns, you will get guaranteed weapon drops for leveling up, but also a chance to get rare loot by rolling dice at the completion of a mission. Your party can improve their odds at getting better loot by working together to bring certain items to the end of a campaign, adding a huge risk vs reward element.

Check it out with some friends and have some good fun.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: An improved LFD. Combat is fun, easy to get familiarized with. Loot system, for all those weapon collecting fanatics. And a generally friendly community. The only real progression is levels and better loot on harder difficulties. So the game may feel old from time to time, with friends the fun never ends. Bot players need to be tinkered with, so generally online multiplayer is more enjoyable then solo. Updates and patches come out fairly often, and the game only improves with them. Beware the Skaven blight
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Love this game.

Definitely should buy if you loved left4dead and dead island series. The combat mechanics are well-polished and fluid, deviating from the standard hack and slash instead requiring teamwork on the harder levels to survive as well as mechanics such as dodge, block and push especially when dealing with commanders, vermintide and rat ogres. Also, the ability to be any kind of player with any character is quite encouraging. You can play a fodder clearing dwarf with a dual wielding battle-axe and dual fire pistols or a defensive dwarf with a shield and a single handed thor hammer responsible for protecting your teammates. Also, the maps are well- made, expansive and immersive almost as if open world, the visuals stunning living up the quality of the newer games and the enemies diverse requiring different approaches to deal with. Also the devs seem to take a proactive approach to continuously update this game  and the future looks bright.

Only concerns i have would be the loot system as it may not be to everyone's taste and liking. Furthermore, hopefully more gamemodes will be added to the game for a larger diversity.

Regardless, this is a fantastic game that i would recommend for all audiences. It will be a wonderful, fullfilling experience well worth the price to pay.

reviewText: Wasn't sure if it was going to be good or not, but I've had a great time so far.   The level designs are entertaining, and the battles are adrenaline inducing.  Usually I go in for PVP games, not coop PVE, but this game is challenging enough that working as a team is quite fun.  The banter between characters is surprisingly well done and situation appropriate.  And the art work is VERY well done.   My favorite classes to play are the Dwarf, the Elf, and the Bright Wizard.   Definitely worth the $30.  Would buy again.\n\nThe only downside is that there are a few players who try to do gimmicks and terrain cheats which usually end in utter failure, but mostly people just want to have fun and support each other the way the game intended.  In my limited experience, my groups succeed every time they play a level with legitimate skill  But every time they try to cheat, they die anyway.  Which is good imo.

reviewText:
Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide is a great co-operative survival / slash'em up game for up to four players but has some room for improvement.

The game is quite similiar to other games like Left 4 Dead, but is instead set in a grimdark medieval world.

The games combat mechanics are very agile, every weapon, staff and shield feel like they connect as they should, and every weapon also feels equal to its counterpart. All the classes are distinct from each other and each class feels different from the other. The class haracters all have distinct and funny personalities which I quite enjoyed. While the gameplay is very enjoyable, there are some problems I feel could be worked on.

The loot system rewards players with a new item after completing every stage, by using a dice system. You can obtain more dice depending on how many collectibles (tomes & grimoires) you found during the level. There are 3 tomes and 1 grimoire in ever level. This is a good system that motivates you to complete a level. However, I have experienced that, since I know the location of all the 3 tomes and the one grimoire in a certain stage, I will just replay that stage over and over. There is little actual motivation to try any of the other levels once you know the optimal way to run one stage, since the loot system only gives you one item at the end of the level, and each level only has 3 tomes and one grimoire to collect anyway.

As for the technical aspects, some have reported poor performance. I am able to run the game at a constant 80+ FPS, but will experience frequent frame drops, something I believe will be fixed in the future, with the addition of new drivers, and such. The graphics are pretty, but nothing out of the ordinary, so the framerate should be a lot smoother.

In conclusion, the loot system and variety could be improved, but Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide is still a great and fun game that I definitely recommend you pick up and try if you have a couple of friends willing to play with you. It comes at 28€ which is a great value for this game.

7.8/10

reviewText: This is Left 4 Dead reskinned to the Warhammer Fantasy setting.  Seriously... the differences between the characters are minimal, the game plays exactly like L4D did.  The special enemies are almost identical... one that jumps on you and pins you, one that grabs a player and drags them away, one that throws poison clouds, and one that's a giant death melee machine.  There are a few more specials like the gunner that mows you down at range, which is a nice change-up.  But really the biggest difference between this game and L4D is the loot system.  In L4D you get weapons as you play in each level.  In this one you pick your weapons going in, and you stick with them for the map.  But, you get new gear as you play and can upgrade that gear.  It's L4D with a loot and experience system.  XP doesn't unlock abilities or anything, it just unlocks a couple more trinket slots as far as I can tell.  But then I don't have a trinket for my starting slot...\n\nIf you liked Left 4 Dead, you'll like this game.  All the same strategies and tactics apply.  Unfortunately, that also means just like in L4D bots are nearly worthless and human players that go rambo charging in will only hurt your team.  But overall, quite fun with a competent team of players.

reviewText:
A smashing co-op rat brawling game that draws heavily from and adds to the Left 4 Dead games. Battles are fought furiously over a range of stunning locales and each weapon and every class has a well-defined role to play in vanquishing the nefarious Skaven horde. Vermintide's loot system adds replayability to the game and encourages players to take on tougher missions. 9/10.

Grapes:
+ Well-balanced character classes that complement each other well and require effective teamwork on the harder difficulties. This is enhanced by changing each characters' weapon loadout - do you take a crossbow for range and accuracy or a repeater pistol for mowing down smaller rats?
+ Gorgeous graphics and thumping sounds. Fighting in the Warhammer world has never looked or sounded this good. This makes fighting/ bisecting/ decapitating/ shooting the Skaven a real pleasure.
+ Beautiful and well-designed levels that aren't necessarily the same in every playthrough (check out The Wizard's Tower level!).
+ A loot system that rewards finding hidden items and playing on the hardest difficulties (which also improves the game's replayability).
+ A range of enemies that all require a slightly different approach (although Fatshark twists some Warhammer lore to get them in their roles).
+ A solid and helpful community that play the game; sharing the location of tomes and grimoires (to improve the chances of better loot) and generally helping each other out in a game. I've only been knowlingly trolled once in 30+ playthroughs, by some fool who read the grimoire and waited till the end of the map to put a tome in a location inaccessible by the rest of us.

Gripes:
- The biggest con for me is host player dropouts. If the host drops out of a game, the map restarts. That's it. The game simply doesn't allow you to continue or even provide you the option of going to the inn to choose another mission. So you have to sit in a loading screen mulling over your fury. While this issue is generally limited to public servers, it is infuriating. Please fix this Fatshark!
- Whilst being one of its biggest strengths, the game's loot system also causes the most controversy. If players are defeated in a mission, no rewards are provided, only some crystals that allow you to unlock gear traits. The level of gear awarded at the end of a mission is also effectively down to a random number generator, which many find madening, but I actually quite enjoy to a certain extent.
- The game's matchmaking can be rather poor, attempting to find/ join missions and seemingly failing over a period of ten minutes or more. Fortunately the player can simply select a mission from the server browser to get around this gripe.

reviewText:
This game will draw from you your inner mental sickness.

The whole game is about murdering and genocide.
You are murderous hero who must murder murderous rats, but it's not so simple because there are murderous types of enemies with unique murderous abilities or tools which can murder you.
For example: murderous rat throwing na*i globes filled with Zyklon B which can murder your whole camping team (the bast*rd) or murderous rat the size of f*cking truck which was fed with elephant growth hormone can jump on you and murder you just with 1 murderous strike (the bast*rd). Even if you (murder) can beat them because you have tactic, remember that soon you can drown uder thousand small screaming murderous rats. The game is full of murderous surprises.
Once you will finish mission you will get loot, in other words - murderous weapons, trinkets, guns or less murderous but very rare hats. Several hats have spikes so maybe you can use them to murder rats as well. Items are balanced because even if you roll better tier it will not give you massive advantage but only better chance to survive or will add a percentage chance to use special (murderous) affix.
In this game you can really feel the atmosphere of warhammer - dismembered bodies, impaled bodies, blood, overall gore, the combat is really good and characters are well designed.

The game is not recommended for kids under three years of life.

reviewText:
This game is very much like a Melee focused L4D The setting and the maps are a bit darker mostly due to the asthetic and setting which isnt a bad thing but worth noting. It deviates from the L4D formula slightly in a few areas most noteably the loot system, the characters offer banter to each other in game which is a nice little touch when fighting off a tide of rats.

One of the things i really like about this game is way you earn drops, firstly you have to complete the level and while running through you can pick up 3 tomes" these books replace your medical supply slot but you can put a tome down to pick up a health pot or kit then pick the tome back up which is fair. if you get these 3 tomes to the end of the level you get3 bonus gold dice on your loot roll.

An added challenge that brings more risk but offers better rewards is the Grimoire
date: there are 2 of these and they take up a buff potion slot
recommended:
they also take away from your maximum health the first one takes about 25% of your max health away the send one leaves you with only 25% of your max health. If you succesfully bring these grimoires back you get 2 green dice on your loot roll.

you can also find random loot dice laying around the map in chests but i dont know too much about them yet.

On the store page the 3rd video trailer shows how the loot is rolled and the success ratio of each dice at around the 3 min 50 second mark.


So far i have only played on normal in public games and most people are helpful and tolerant but i have met people who refuse to help or carry those who have only just started the game for the first time. I look forward to playing this game with 3 friends on the higher difficulties and finding better loot."
hoursPlayed: November 2, 2015

reviewText:
Have you ever wished Left 4 Dead had a progression and/or customization? Vermintide is for you.

I do not know much about the warhammer universe, but this game is incredibly enjoyable with friends, and has charismatic characters that actually interact with each other.

At the moment of the review there's only one gamemode so far (Complete the objective) but there future updates and future maps and gamemodes  with the already announced Survival mode. And even with only gamemode the replayability is quite big, thanks to the high level difficulty sets and the weapon/trinket collection and improvement system.

reviewText:
Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide is a great co-operative survival / slash'em up game for up to four players but has some room for improvement.

The game is quite similiar to other games like Left 4 Dead, but is instead set in a grimdark medieval world.

The games combat mechanics are very agile, every weapon, staff and shield feel like they connect as they should, and every weapon also feels equal to its counterpart. All the classes are distinct from each other and each class feels different from the other. The class haracters all have distinct and funny personalities which I quite enjoyed. While the gameplay is very enjoyable, there are some problems I feel could be worked on.

The loot system rewards players with a new item after completing every stage, by using a dice system. You can obtain more dice depending on how many collectibles (tomes & grimoires) you found during the level. There are 3 tomes and 1 grimoire in ever level. This is a good system that motivates you to complete a level. However, I have experienced that, since I know the location of all the 3 tomes and the one grimoire in a certain stage, I will just replay that stage over and over. There is little actual motivation to try any of the other levels once you know the optimal way to run one stage, since the loot system only gives you one item at the end of the level, and each level only has 3 tomes and one grimoire to collect anyway.

As for the technical aspects, some have reported poor performance. I am able to run the game at a constant 80+ FPS, but will experience frequent frame drops, something I believe will be fixed in the future, with the addition of new drivers, and such. The graphics are pretty, but nothing out of the ordinary, so the framerate should be a lot smoother.

In conclusion, the loot system and variety could be improved, but Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide is still a great and fun game that I definitely recommend you pick up and try if you have a couple of friends willing to play with you. It comes at 28€ which is a great value for this game.

reviewText:
TL;DR: A very enjoyable Left4Dead clone with some RPG-like tweaks and a nice dark art style. Some bugs and connectivity issues.

Vermintide gave me exactly what i expected it to give me. It is a great game for playing an hour or two and then going to do something else. Quests take a felt 15-25 minutes and are nicely balanced. The voice acting is quite nicely done and helps to immerse in the game world at least on the first playthrough.
Like in L4D missions are much easier with a crew that keeps together and uses the classes well. Playing through the campaign on normal took me a combined 6 hours but the loot system keeps me wanting to play and i would like to see some dlc adding more missions and equipment.
The combat mechanics are fun and the game encourages you to use all of your abilities and try different characters.
Enemies work very similarly to l4d, you have your basic fast attackers, assassins, swarms of weak enemies and a big tank enemy. Since those enemies are not brainless zombies though (but indeed pretty awesomely designed intelligent rat creatures destined to bring the apocalypse upon the world) there are some more advanced ctitters with poison grenades, chokehold sticks and miniguns which require teamwork to be defeated.
I did have some connectivity issues which were probably host-dependent since the game has a system which automatically assigns a host. Failing missions over and over due to suddenly losing connection to a host is frustrating and i hope future patches will fix this issue.
Overall i can recommend this game to anyone who enjoys first person hack and slash games and wants a quick rewarding experience with a dark, bloody art style,
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
RATS RATS and MORE RATS!!  If you were a fan of L4D or Dynasty Warriors... then this is the game you've been waiting for.

If those two games had a baby.. it would be this.  Imagine the horde/special system from L4D series and the random loot from say Dynasty Warriors 3 boxes on the battlefield.  Then you'd have a vague notion of what you're getting into.

There -is- a loot system but you should not go into this with a loot-minded mentality.  It will only set you up for aggrivation currently.  The loot system is still very much RNG-y and unless you got that magic mojo.. you can expect to be disappointed repeatedly.  However that is a good thing because once you've earned your first orange" or "red" weapon.. it makes that moment that much more memorable.  The devs have made some good tweaks to the loot system and have some impending updates as well that will smooth things out abit.

All in all
date: despite early release bugs (most of which have been patched)
recommended: this has been a fantastic trip down to rat town.\n\n9/10 would throw barrels at Rat Ogre while yelling "Donkey Kong *****" again"

reviewText:
First and foremost i like the game, but here is what can be changed for a more positive gameplay experience.

Some Balancing Issues:

- If a rats spear doesnt touch my body, i shouldn't recieve damage. I know how much of a pain hit boxes are, but hit detection needs to be improved.
- small window of frontal invincibility when shoving. currently (tho it doesnt happen too often) i take damage from the front when shoving. thats fine on lower difficulties but on Nightmare its a significant amount of HP.

SPECIALS (because its vermintide not L4D):
-I'm just going to say it. Gutter rats do not add ANYTHING to the experience. I can slay a rat ogre single-handed but i cant get a 50lb rat of my chest -_-
Imagine playing a game that incorporates a random black hole spawner that you cant evade 80% of the time no matter what and kills you instantly... sound like fun to anybody? yea, me neither

-Rat Ogres: not anything really that wrong with them, however, i think they could be implemented better.
1) need more damage indicaters.
At 50% health the rat ogres limbs can be hacked off it's body(ogres attack pattern would have to change             accordingly)
At 25% health ogres head can be taken, slaying it instantly

2) ogres are fun to fight, its a cool enemy type, but you only get to fight one per level(if that). You could lower the health of the rat ogre so that you can spawn more of them without overpowering the player(s)

-Gas Rats: perfectly fine, except when more than one spwns at a time

-Pack Master: <-------THAT is what have replaced your L4D hunter not the gutter rat. The pack master at least makes sense. Also think a horde of pink rats to accompany each one would be neat as it is called a PACK master.

-Ratling Gunner: once again perfectly fine except when two spawn at once

I get that the specials are there to keep players in a group, but dont twist the players arm into doing it because
1) sometimes you have to play with bots
2) sometimes you just feel like soloing, to be an ♥♥♥ and say we dont care how you want to play, you have to play the game as origionally intended and not go outside the lines because we'll ♥♥♥♥ you with our instagibbing special rats. Giant middle finger to the players..

This is my opinion, change it or dont change it. add shelf life to you game or do not.

reviewText:
Wow just wow, this has everything you would want in a game.
when i picked this up it was because i had seen someone play it on youtube, my initial reaction
was that this game was going to be boring tedious and poorly optimized.
I was wrong... oh so very wrong... the game is a mixture of Left 4 Dead and Killing Floor but with rats... many, many rats.
You essentially play as a team of exterminators. I wont spoil to much of the game just incase you want to find out about it on your own but trust me this game is worth it.

RATINGS:
10/10 In game mechanics fighting/throwing/blocking/etc.
7/10 For missions since they arent super unique (still fun as hell though)
8/10 For graphics (i cant play on max so this is based off of high settings)
8/10 For character animations (some of the rats tend to have unatural feeling movement)
9/10 For emmersion (i really get stuck into the fight, i feel like i am my character when slashing through rats lol)
9/10 Overall great game in my opinion.

pros:
-smooth mechanics
-great graphics
-detailed team play
-you get to kill giant rats (how can you not like that)
-plays a lot like the left 4 dead series (almost exactly)
-not much of a learning curve (relativly easy to pick up off the bat)

Cons:
-people tend to pick favorites so its hard to get into a match with a character you like
-some of the character models (such as the tank rat) get glitchy, but its tolerable.
-havent met many people using VOIP but its not a big deal.
-the harder difficulties can be really hard especially when you get hit by a swarm


Over all though this game is wonderfull and i would really like to see more people join in on it,
the community is still pretty small but i can see this game kicking off really well especially for those who like left for dead but want a little more depth.

If anyone is interested these are my basic specs i have and i hit a solid 60-70 frames with nearly no drops
CPU- I5 2550 3.5ghz
GPU- GTX 960
RAM- 16G
MOTHERBOARD- ASUS motherboard (cant remember model but its a decent one)

reviewText:
TL;DR: Left for Dead with swords, and that's a compliment.

So after playing a fair amount I can now say that this game is a blast. Seeing how this is a Left for Dead clone and everyone knows it, I will simply discuss what sets this game apart from the game series we all know and love.

First and foremost it's the melee combat. This game is all about it, and even though there are ranged-focussed classes as well, melee remains an unavoidably large part of the game. And it works well enough. I am kinda missing the option to differentiate between strikes (instead of light/heavy they could have gone full chivalry and made left-swing/right-swing/overhead/stab attacks), but the hit detection and feedback are awesome. I am especially enjoying the dwarven hammer, which gives a satisfying thump and will bounce off armored targets but just sweep lighter targets along. The feedback is phenomal and feels brutal. Swords were a tad less over-the-top, but they still feel sturdy and hard-hitting. Also blocking. Whereas in L4D you have to shoot infected before they can even hit you, there is no such ranged option in Vermintide. Blocking, shoving and dodging are essential to prevent being damaged. This makes large hordes and being surrounded particularly dangerous, as you cannot block all around you, and you can't dodge anywhere when there's rats everywhere. It makes it all feel a lot more engaging than just mindlessly blasting the hordes. It makes staying together even more important, as a good group of commons can and will kill you, and in L4D I didn't even see commons as a threat.

Then there's the five classes, which all have a unique role. There's a crowd-focused melee, a single-target melee, an allrounder, a crowd-focused ranged and a single-target ranged. Collectible loot gives some flexibility in the role a character has, and of course all the character have the ability to fend off hordes, some are just better at it than others. The loot system will drop you a single weapon after each mission based on a dice roll (yes, literally a virtual dice roll), with some items scattered around each map that give better chances for rare ones, and grimoires that lower max hp for the rest of the mission in return for a fairly hefty boost to your odds. Failing a mission, however, nets you nothing.

The enemies are virtually the same as in L4D2, there's commons, armored ones, and a range of specials like the spitter, stalker, smoker and tank. Of course all reskinned as rats. They do the same job as the ones in L4D2, force teamwork. If you stray too far, a packmaster will simply sweep you up and hang you. But I feel the rats are a welcome change in the zombie-ridden gaming scene. I like having a horde game with more inspired characters than your every-day zombie. Speaking of inspired characters, this game does a phenomal job of bringing the Warhammer lore and universe to life. The characters have clear personalities that are reflected in each line of dialogue and there's a clear story for every mission. There's not really a story mode, but it's more like an overarching story and a bunch of lore interwoven in the individual missions. Combined with some ridiculously gorgeous levels this game does suck you into its universe. The detail even comes back into some cool weapon discriptions and cosmetic description, though sadly the background on weapons is reserved for the rarest ones.

Some of the less awesome parts of this game, however, have to be the fact that the game is very short if you wouldn't replay it (hence the 30 dollar price tag I suppose). With 13 missions that aren't much longer than 30 minutes at best, and some missions being only a few minutes, about 5 hours would be enough to see it all. You'd have to be the kind that seeks a challenge on the more insane difficulties to really get your value out of this one. The fact that more difficult mission yield more interesting loot will help with that. There's also the fact that matchmaking is rather dumbed down (though it covers the basic options) and the fact that the inventory and crafting system are represented with a forge and your storage chest. Perhaps this is keep immersion up, but it is also less functional than a good old menu. Now you'll have to virtually walk, which is tiresome. Another minor gripe is that while playing, the busy streets and weird architecture combined with the in-style HUD can't help but slightly disorient you and have you lose your overview. L4D did an amazing job of making clear what you have to do and what the team's status is, Vermintide is just a little less in that regard. However, you will get used to it to the point where you'll barely notice it once you start to learn the levels.

Gameplay-wise my major gripe is the 'a.i. director', which is also taken from L4D and 'intelligently' spawns enemies and hordes. I found that on occasion, he was ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Though he is essential to keeping the replays actually worth playing, he can also pull the most enfuriating and unavoidable ♥♥♥♥. He has to be there, but he has to be smarter. Spawning a rat-ogre on a cliff-walk is not okay. Neither is spawning a suicide bomb on us just as we're getting in the escape vehicle. Then finally, the mission length and difficulty are wildly irregular. One mission can be a 30-minute adventure while another is a 3 minute cake-walk. They all look awesome and they have a varied setting though, some taking place underground or in the woods, others in the city, at the docks etc. I never found myself bored with the scenery, it all has a very grim and gritty vibe to it that actually brings across the end-world feel.

So, in total, this game is well worth the 30 dollar price tag for anyone who enjoyed L4D or anyone who enjoys hitting vermin with metal. Qualitatively it's still a step below L4D, but not a large one, and it's uniqueness is a welcome change. Judged as its own game, this stands well above the average with one of the best co-op experiences combined with a super cool setting, and I can only hope that in these uncertain days of gaming, the devs will continue to support and care for their community. Adding in some more maps in the form of paid DLC would be most welcome, but let's not turn into Overkill Studios. Please. I have trust issues.

Aaron's score card score: 8

1. Drinking bleach > playing this game
2. Less bearable than Russell Brand.
3. Complete garbage worthy of no-ones time.
4. Obviously the developers just don't care about games.
5. Bland and rough around the edges.
6. MEDIOCRE!
7. There's some merit to this game and some fun to be had.
8. A damn good piece of work.
9. Phenomal work that you CANNOT pass up.
10. Absolutely out of this world, a legendary game that will shake the industry for decades.

reviewText:
Have you ever wished Left 4 Dead had a progression and/or customization? Vermintide is for you.

I do not know much about the warhammer universe, but this game is incredibly enjoyable with friends, and has charismatic characters that actually interact with each other.

At the moment of the review there's only one gamemode so far (Complete the objective) but there future updates and future maps and gamemodes  with the already announced Survival mode. And even with only gamemode the replayability is quite big, thanks to the high level difficulty sets and the weapon/trinket collection and improvement system.

reviewText:
This game is often described as left4dead but with rats. I don't think that does it justice. Vermintide plays more like a cross between Payday 2 and Skyrim.

I say Skyrim because melee combat is a mechanical focus and is executed so that it's easy to pick up and hard to master. Payday 2 is a mention for me because of the team challenge factor Vermintide features. Careful communication and teamplay is absolutely necessary in the higher difficulties and even on normal-hard when picking up Grimlores.

Vermintide has left me wanting more of everything it provides: haunting and intruiging level design, fun and interesting characters, a diverse range of special enemies and quirky AI. Having said that, the game isn't at all lacking in content or replayability and is worth its full price as is.

reviewText: This is Left 4 Dead reskinned to the Warhammer Fantasy setting.  Seriously... the differences between the characters are minimal, the game plays exactly like L4D did.  The special enemies are almost identical... one that jumps on you and pins you, one that grabs a player and drags them away, one that throws poison clouds, and one that's a giant death melee machine.  There are a few more specials like the gunner that mows you down at range, which is a nice change-up.  But really the biggest difference between this game and L4D is the loot system.  In L4D you get weapons as you play in each level.  In this one you pick your weapons going in, and you stick with them for the map.  But, you get new gear as you play and can upgrade that gear.  It's L4D with a loot and experience system.  XP doesn't unlock abilities or anything, it just unlocks a couple more trinket slots as far as I can tell.  But then I don't have a trinket for my starting slot...\n\nIf you liked Left 4 Dead, you'll like this game.  All the same strategies and tactics apply.  Unfortunately, that also means just like in L4D bots are nearly worthless and human players that go rambo charging in will only hurt your team.  But overall, quite fun with a competent team of players.

reviewText:
This game will draw from you your inner mental sickness.

The whole game is about murdering and genocide.
You are murderous hero who must murder murderous rats, but it's not so simple because there are murderous types of enemies with unique murderous abilities or tools which can murder you.
For example: murderous rat throwing na*i globes filled with Zyklon B which can murder your whole camping team (the bast*rd) or murderous rat the size of f*cking truck which was fed with elephant growth hormone can jump on you and murder you just with 1 murderous strike (the bast*rd). Even if you (murder) can beat them because you have tactic, remember that soon you can drown uder thousand small screaming murderous rats. The game is full of murderous surprises.
Once you will finish mission you will get loot, in other words - murderous weapons, trinkets, guns or less murderous but very rare hats. Several hats have spikes so maybe you can use them to murder rats as well. Items are balanced because even if you roll better tier it will not give you massive advantage but only better chance to survive or will add a percentage chance to use special (murderous) affix.
In this game you can really feel the atmosphere of warhammer - dismembered bodies, impaled bodies, blood, overall gore, the combat is really good and characters are well designed.

The game is not recommended for kids under three years of life.

reviewText: This game.. damn.. It's l4d2 but you know much better. It's basically l4d with rats and better graphics. This game has much more to do in it than l4d does. I'm finding myself torn between which one I like better, and so far this one is winning. I love games with RNG, also hate them but, that's love right? This game has like 6 raritys it goes white-green-blue-purple(cosmetic)-orange-red. I still have yet to aquire a weapon of orange or red rarity. What they did with the Tomes and Grimiores was amazing.. it gives you a side objective to look for while doing the level. (although not all of the levels have these) I do enjoy playing the different difficulties of gamemodes, although.. cataclysm is like slamming your head against a brick wall over and over again until you beat it. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND GETTING GRIMIORES AND TOMES ON LOWER DIFFICULTIES THAN HARD! Although most of the time I get them on hard.. lol. Overall this game has given me a great time! Most of the people I meet on there are nice and they will help me get better. Although there are those people who like to ♥♥♥♥ with you, so I recommend this game to anyone and everyone! It's allot of fun!

reviewText:
+ great combat
+ weapons have good weight
+ teamwork is so damn crucial. it really makes the game fun when you have a team that communicates.
+ lots of different weapons per class, both ranged and melee
..............................
~ extremely left 4 dead-e, right down to the core gameplay and, ffs, the special rats. Seriously there's a 1-to-1 mapping for the L4D specials to Vermintide. I can understand wanting to pay tribute but it's just unapologetic at times.
..............................
- the loot system. This is what keeps the game from being nearly as played in my group. You only get to roll for one piece of loot at the end of the mission, so if you gathered tomes and dice to enhance your rolls on loot, it's all for naught if you die. This is pretty harsh considering the times it can take to complete some of these missions. Even if you do things perfectly you may just be rewarded with yet another common item for a class you never use. If the loot system was updated to be more frequent or dropped more per mission, then I'd say this is a game worth placing a lot of hours into. As it stands my group has cleared all the missions at least once and, seeing the shlog in front of us that is this terribly long grinding, I doubt we're going to continue. This absolutely SUCKS considering how great the game is.
..............................

This is a weird game to recommend. If you hate doing 20 minute missions just to get one item for most likely a class you don't play, you'll probably put this game down after 10~ hours. I mean if you love that grinding then yeah go for it. In short it's super fun but until they fix the terribly slow loot system I'll probably stop playing here.
